TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, will be absent from Question Time today, or at least for most of it, due to a delayed flight from Sydney. Questions relating to the Transport and Communications portfolio and Senator Collins's other responsibilities in the Senate should be addressed to Senator Cook.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Notwithstanding last week's disastrous figures—record foreign debt, disappointing growth, which will not even sustain current employment, and the worst balance of payment figures in almost three years; or, in other words, further evidence of the failure of Labor's economic program—Mr Keating said at the weekend that Labor did in fact have a plan. I ask the Minister to let us in on the secret. What is Labor's plan to reverse its record of economic failure, to create jobs and to restore living standards?

—I have said in the Senate on a number of occasions that over its nine years in office this Government has made announcements about policy when it considered it appropriate to do so. We are not here for the edification of the Opposition in the Senate.
—Or for the Australian public.

—If I were the honourable senator I would not talk too much about the Australian public. Opposition senators are sitting on the revised Fightback, waiting for Sir William Cole to tell them what Fightback is all about. I would not make these criticisms too stridently, if I were he.

PARA.TAB: As I said last week in answer to a question about this matter, in terms of growth in the Australian economy we are doing better than most other countries in the OECD.
Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose those opposite think we should do better and lead the rest of the world—something which they did not ever do when they were in government in terms of growth rates or anything else. The fact of the matter is that on growth this economy is coming out of the recession better than most other economies with which we compete.

PARA.TAB: As we have said on many occasions, there has in fact been employment growth and there will continue to be employment growth as the economy improves. Senator Hill has again asked me about the balance of payments. Let me just make the point that as a percentage of GDP, the balance of payments figure is not the worst figure. As a percentage of GDP, it is nowhere near as bad as the figure the coalition had in its last full year in office. It is certainly not as bad as it has been at other times during this period of government.

It is not incumbent upon us at this stage to announce any particular plans for the benefit of the Opposition. We will do that when it is appropriate and the Opposition will have to deal with them then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, to ensure that we all understand the position, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying to us and to the Australian people that the Government has no plan or program for economic recovery of this nation, after the disasters it suffered in recent years, other than offering more of the same, more of the plan that has already been demonstrated to have failed?

—We are not offering more of the same and we have not been in the last couple of years. For example, in the 1980s we presided over the highest growth in this economy we have seen for years. The circumstances are different in the 1990s. In terms of encouragement of growth in the economy, we have announced a number of matters which will take a little time to take effect. We are not going to be panicked into doing anything silly by a lacklustre Opposition, and why should we be? To say that the Government is offering more of the same is totally incorrect. What is being offered by the Opposition is more of the same of the Margaret Thatcher vintage of the 1970s. That is the decade the Opposition's policies are relevant to—the 1970s, not the 1990s.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Minister confirm that, under proposals to destroy the award system and introduce individual employment contracts, workers would have no real protection against unfair dismissal; workers could be faced with the choice of `contract or the sack'? Is the Government considering adopting any such proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not proposing to abolish independent arbitration in Australia. We are not proposing to introduce a system which amounts to `the contract or the sack'. We are not proposing to introduce an individual employment contract approach, which is the policy of the Opposition. We are proposing to stick with the flexibilities and rights that are inherent in the century-old Australian industrial relations system.

PARA.TAB: Last Thursday's Sydney Morning Herald carried a report of a person who had been directed to be re-employed and awarded back pay because that person was unfairly dismissed. The report concerns a security officer who did not seek time off but sought a re-rostering of his shift so he could attend to the birth of his son when his wife was in labour. The employer dismissed that worker. On appeal to the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commissioner, in the judgment that was handed down, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, the Commissioner said:

I am satisfied that the termination of Mr Baker's employment as a result of his non-attendance at work to be with his wife for the birth of their child was, in all circumstances, a harsh, unfair or unjust dismissal of the highest order.
Working men and women are not automatons with no working lives other than their occupational existence and who answer to no demands other than those made by employers.

ANSWER.PARA: On that basis, this worker was reinstated in employment and awarded 13 weeks back pay. I understand that the employer in this case, South West Security, regards this as an outrageous decision and wants to appeal it. I therefore will not go to the merits of the case. What I simply say about it is this: under our system, that worker had a place to go to be reinstated or for redress, and that worker had a chance to put a fair case and be judged appropriately. The employer has a right to appeal, and it will go to appeal if the employer lodges one, and have the matter finally determined. Under the industrial relations system, that is possible.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition's proposal is to introduce common law, where the relationship is that of a master and a servant and where the servant—in this case, the worker—would have no rights and would not be able to resist being dismissed in those circumstances; indeed, it is doubtful whether he would be allowed off to attend to the birth of his son with his wife at the time at all. So the stark difference here is between a system that denies rights and one that confers them on both parties. I hope there is a speedy conclusion to this case. The truth of the outcome is that it will be fair and reasonable, something that is accessible under us but not under the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's answer, can the Minister inform the Senate of any other action the Government has taken to make sure all Australian workers are protected against unfair dismissal? Could the Minister expand on what he said.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Prime Minister and I announced last Wednesday, basing ourselves on the United Nations agency, the ILO, and the international standards it has declared as minimum international standards governing issues of industrial relations, we will legislate to introduce the minimum international standard concerning termination of employment. That will ensure that there are no unfair dismissals, that there is no victimisation at the point of termination of employment, and that there is a right for fair redundancy payments, properly determined.

PARA.TAB: The Government will be conferring basic human rights as a safety net underpinning industrial relations in Australian society. That will provide a stark choice between our approach and that of the Opposition where, as I said in my previous answer, the master and servant relationship will apply at common law.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the Treasury document released under the Freedom of Information Act which, despite massive selective editing, showed overwhelming support for the former Labour Government's GST in New Zealand. I remind the Minister of the Government's refusal to release the full or partial document at a Senate Estimates committee hearing on 20 October. Will the Government table immediately in the Senate the full, unexpurgated and previously suppressed document, the censored version of which has now been released under the Freedom of Information Act to the Sydney Morning Herald—with most of it having been absolutely obliterated by the Government's propaganda police?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question contains a number of pejorative suggestions which I do not accept, of course. The Sydney Morning Herald did obtain a copy of a document under the FOI Act. I have not seen the report. As Senator Short claims, much of it was deleted in the version released to the Sydney Morning Herald. I understand that the headline `"Kiwis love GST", says secret Treasury paper' cannot be justified by the Treasury report.

PARA.TAB: In October Senator Bishop asked Treasury officials in Senate Estimates Committee B whether she could have a copy of the report on the trip to New Zealand. The Government decided against releasing the document, and that stands. The Government response was tabled on 10 November and it said:

The trip report is mostly records of confidential discussions between Australian officials and New Zealand officials and of discussions in confidence with New Zealand business representatives and academics . . . To release reports of such discussions would violate the confidences surrounding them and reduce the value to the Australian Government of future consultations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasury has advised the Treasurer that releasing any more of the report would damage Australia's continuing interest in obtaining information from foreign governments and non-official sources. The Treasurer has accepted that advice.

If I wanted a judgment on the level of support for a GST in New Zealand, I certainly would not ask the Australian Treasury for it. Whatever its skills and expertise, the Treasury is not a public relations pollster, it is not a public relations firm and it is not an advertising agency. It is only in Australia that political parties like the Liberals have to go to consultants to have their policies prepared for them.

PARA.TAB: As the Prime Minister said yesterday, Treasuries are always interested in collecting revenue. In the past he has commented on what the GST and other economic policies have done for New Zealand over the past decade. New Zealand's official 1992 yearbook provides some interesting information, which I invite all Government senators to read—those opposite will not want to read it—on what happened to real disposable incomes in New Zealand following the introduction of the GST. Basically, the truth is that the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. First, as Senator Button claims not to have seen the document released under FOI, I seek leave to table it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that extracting the truth from this Government has become a virtual impossibility, I ask the Minister: is his refusal to table the full document not a blatant contradiction of the statements by the Prime Minister yesterday and by the Treasurer that it was `garbage'—to use their word—that the report has been suppressed? What reason other than sheer political expediency can the Minister provide for denying the Senate access to this document? When will the full, unexpurgated report finally be released, as surely it must be?
—If, as some people have said, the report is garbage I would not table garbage.
—Garbage that has been suppressed.

—I am not in the habit of doing that. I indicated in the earlier part of my answer the attitude of the Government to this issue. I know that those opposite are desperately trying to seek comfort in some circle or other from the goods and services tax, but if they think they can get it from a couple of Treasury officials who are not in the position of public opinion pollsters—
—Why did you send them over there?

—They were sent over there to discuss a whole range of matters. The fact is that low income full time wage and salary earners in New Zealand have had a 7.8 per cent drop in salaries and middle income earners have had a 5.5 per cent drop since the goods and services tax was introduced. That is very sad. This is the sort of information which is crucial for Australians, not the opinions of a couple of Treasury officials.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Has the Minister seen press reports on the Industry Commission's annual report for 1991-92 which was released last week? Did these reports accurately reflect progress made to date in reforming the transport and communications sectors of the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Since I am substituting for Senator Collins today in Transport and Communications, perhaps I should answer this question from the wider perspective of the whole portfolio. I note that the Industry Commission's 1991-92 annual report states:

PARA.TAB: Despite the effects of the recession, reform efforts of earlier years are producing positive results in many areas of economic activity. They have reduced costs for many industries and consumers, and increased choice and quality. The burden on taxpayers from public sector inefficiency has also been lessened.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to advise the Senate that many of the examples of the reform dividend come under the umbrella of the Transport and Communications portfolio, including significant falls in domestic air fares and record numbers of passengers travelling, with the flow-on benefits to the Australian tourism industry; Civil Aviation Authority cuts in charges to industry in real terms of $96m in 1992-93; turnaround times for grain ships at Australian ports dropping from an average of 4.5 days to 2.4 days, saving farmers $10m per annum; and AOTC reducing its charges for long distance calls, including a 13 per cent reduction from Melbourne to Sydney on the previous year and further reductions likely with increased competition.

PARA.TAB: I add a few more examples to those provided by the Commission: Australia Post has achieved real reductions in the basic postal charge for the past six years; a reduction in the stevedoring industry work force of 57 per cent; a reduction of over 50 per cent in shipboard crewing levels for grain handling operations; and falls of 20 to 25 per cent in stevedoring charges negotiated for new contracts. All these improvements reduce charges to industry and consumers and increase Australia's productivity and its ability to compete internationally.

This Government has put in place the legislative and structural framework to achieve ongoing micro-economic reform in the Transport and Communications portfolio. In aviation, shipping, the waterfront, telecommunications and broadcasting, reforms are achieving benefits which will flow progressively throughout the Australian economy. More recently, measures have been announced to develop rail and road infrastructure. The Government agrees with the Industry Commission that the reform process is ongoing. Major challenges ahead focus on areas of joint Commonwealth-State responsibility and State responsibilities, including rail reform and uniform road transport regulation, and on ports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How important is the maintenance of effective consultation with industry and employees to the success of ongoing micro-economic reform in the transport and communications sectors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The micro-economic reform achievements so far have occurred with minimum industrial disruption, despite the significant impact of those changes. A major reason for that has been that the reform program has been carried on in consultation with all the parties concerned: industry, unions, employers and employees have been a fundamental component to gaining the commitment in order to achieve the reform.

PARA.TAB: The consultative approach to reform advocated by the Government is in stark contrast to the Opposition's confrontationist approach. This Government is committed to the continuing development of the critical transport and communications infrastructure of this country. The coalition has given no such commitment but, rather, has adopted a hope-something-will-happen approach to most key infrastructure developments and an approach where government commitment goes missing and consultation plays little part. This is surely not good enough to ensure that Australian infrastructure does not once again fall into the run-down state which occurred under the previous coalition Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to last Saturday's Age, in which Tim Colebatch concluded that the great bulk of the 16 per cent rise in imports in the first four months of this financial year has been in consumer items and industrial goods `from taps to car jacks, from knickers to AC generators, from postcards to padlocks'. Given the information in the Age, does the Minister accept that he was wrong in claiming that consumer items make a `minuscule contribution' to our total import bill in answer to my question of last Tuesday? Given that growth in manufacturing imports is outstripping manufacturing exports by 4 : 1, when will the Government finally accept that strong new remedies are needed—in particular, a pause in tariff cuts and higher levels of targeted industry assistance?

—I did see the article in the Age on Saturday morning. Tim Colebatch is up to his old tricks. Tim Colebatch is an expert in what is called peak-trough analysis of figures. He has done this before. A few months ago he picked the highest peak of activity in the economy and then related it to textile, clothing and footwear industries in particular in order to establish the trough and the import effects of that trough.
—You people are more into pig troughs.

—I know Senator Baume is an expert on troughs. I should not get into his area. Tim Colebatch's main emphasis was not on things like taps and car jacks but toilet paper. That was his big go in the article on Saturday. If one looks at that industry alone, there is a lot of intra-industry trade. Australia is a very big exporter of paper products, and there will inevitably be some imports of paper products. That is true across a whole range of industries.

PARA.TAB: In the last two financial years, strong growth in exports has more than paid for our imports. Further, as exports grew, imported components into a variety of industries took up a larger proportion of the total import bill. The highest growth in imports in 1991-92 occurred in the `other goods' category, which contains these components which go into manufacturing industry. The importation of investment goods is essential for a sustained recovery for manufacturing industry itself. Last year, imports of investment goods were higher. I make the point that, as the effects of the depreciation of the dollar take effect and Australia's low inflation rate takes hold, local producers and all Australians will reap the benefits of competitive advantage over foreign producers. That is a process which is already taking place.

As I have said to some of Senator Coulter's colleagues, what we have to be concerned about in this country is having our exports grow at a faster rate than our imports. The figure that Senator Coulter gave in his question of imports outstripping exports by 4 : 1 is just not correct. If he wants to take the little period that Mr Colebatch took, it may be right. But, over the last year or so, it is not correct.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister also concerned about the statement made last Thursday by the Austrade Chairman, Bill Ferris, when addressing the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: Much more can and should be done to provide positive incentives to successful exporters and import replacers.

If he does not share Mr Colebatch's view, does he share Mr Ferris's view that much of the success of externally oriented Australian business has derived from market intervention; for example, in the steel and car plans and the 150 per cent research and development tax deductions? Does he agree with Mr Ferris that more targeted intervention to improve our trade balance is urgently needed? If not, on what grounds does he disagree with Mr Ferris?

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept the proposition that some industries which have had special attention from governments have been high growth export areas of the economy, such as pharmaceuticals, shipbuilding, telecommunications equipment, and computers and associated equipment. So I accept that as a general proposition. Senator Coulter mentioned some others.

PARA.TAB: In general, in answer to Mr Ferris's proposition, I think a society can always do more effectively to help exporters, and I think that is desirable. But one has to take into account the cost of all of that. We do have a number of schemes available to help exporters. I think the general export issue is very much a cultural and attitudinal thing, which results at the moment in some of our best exporters being small- to medium-sized firms and not some of the dinosaurs of the Business Council of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Will the Minister confirm that Portugal is selling weapons to the SLORC in Burma, despite the European Community's embargo on the sale of arms to the region? Will the Australian Government consider joining an international embargo on the sale of arms to the SLORC, the State Law and Order Restoration Council? What is the extent of trade of any kind between Burma and China and Burma and Japan? Has the Minister any information on the connection between the trade in heroin and the SLORC regime?

—The Government is aware of reports of the acquisition of Portuguese-manufactured weapons by the SLORC in Burma. We are seeking to verify them. If confirmed, we will certainly express our concern directly to the Portuguese Government, as we have done in respect of other countries known to export arms to Burma. We would express that concern in very strong terms. It does not sit very happily with Portugal's professed concern for human rights so far as East Timor is concerned.

PARA.TAB: We have made it clear on many occasions that the Australian Government would support the implementation of an international embargo on the sale of arms to Burma. However, our soundings—and we have taken many of them—indicate that there is simply not sufficiently wide support for such an embargo to be successful, particularly one administered through the United Nations, which would require Security Council endorsement. It could not be expected to get that, given that China, unhappily, is a major continuing arms supplier. We have instituted our own unilateral ban, however, on the sale of arms and defence-related goods.

There is a serious dearth of accurate statistics on Burma's foreign trade. The situation is particularly unclear because of the extent of smuggling across Burma's borders. However, trade between China and Burma has, by all accounts, increased very sharply in recent years. According to a recent academic study which uses official Burmese figures, China received 29.4 per cent of Burma's exports and supplied 11.3 per cent of its imports in 1989-90. In the same year, Japan—about which Senator Chamarette also asked—is reported to have received just 4.2 per cent of Burma's exports and to have supplied 23.8 per cent of its imports.

Finally, as to the question of narcotics production, increased narcotics production in Burma, which has been widely reported, is clearly one result of the parlous economic and political situation in the country, including the continuing conflict between Burmese authorities and a number of ethnic minority groups. I am aware of detailed allegations, such as those that were made last week at the seminar on Burma that we conducted or co-sponsored at Griffith University.

The Burmese Government's programs, ostensibly designed to eradicate opium production and processing, have in fact been conducted in parallel with politically and economically motivated tolerance of, or even support for, narcotics traffickers. We are examining these continuing allegations very carefully, particularly in view of the fact that Burma is considered these days to be the source of up to 60 per cent of the world's total supply of illegal heroin.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Industrial Relations relates to a police report about powerful unions in Victoria being infiltrated by organised crime and international terrorist groups. I refer the Minister to his response to my question on 25 November 1992 in which he said that the report by a task force of the former Victorian Government had been discredited and that the Victorian police had given it—to quote the Minister—a `horse laugh'. I ask the Minister: how does his answer square with the evidence of an official minute by Chief Inspector D.A. Cairns, the author of that damning report, obtained by Senator Short, in which the author unequivocally confirms that these alarming allegations are indeed correct and, far from being a laughing matter, deserve serious consideration? I again ask the Minister: as a responsible Minister, what action does he intend to take about this most serious matter, or is he involved in a cover-up designed to protect his union mates in Melbourne?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane cannot get out of the gutter yet again. He said, `as a responsible Minister'. I am a responsible Minister; I take responsibility for my portfolio. I am not responsible for policing matters. If anyone has done anything wrong in law, they should be dealt with according to the law, and the law should always be just. But if Senator Crane wants to ask me about a police report, he has the wrong Minister. He should ask someone who is responsible for policing matters.

—I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister report on the United Nations efforts to secure the release from detention of Burmese opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi? What is Australia's response to rumours of her deteriorating condition?

—Last Friday, 4 December, the third committee of the UN General Assembly adopted an important resolution by consensus, which includes a call upon the SLORC to release Daw Aung San Suu Kyi unconditionally. That resolution, which Australia strongly welcomes, does underline the international community's very grave concern at the continuing failure of the Burmese Government to move towards democracy and the continued seriousness of the human rights situation in that country.

PARA.TAB: The resolution also urges the Burmese Government to ensure full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and the protection of the rights of persons belonging to ethnic and religious minorities whom, it notes, have been particular targets for oppressive measures. It calls upon the SLORC to facilitate the speedy repatriation of refugees, to cooperate fully with the UN organs in this matter and to fully cooperate with the Special Rapporteur appointed by the UN Commissioner on Human Rights to examine the situation there, and to permit him access to any person he considers it appropriate to meet during his visit to that country. The fact that this resolution, which we co-sponsored and were actively involved in drafting, was adopted by consensus will again send a very clear signal to the SLORC about the breadth of international concern at the situation in that country and Burma's increasing political isolation, even from countries within its own region.

Also on the UN front, I should perhaps mention that UNESCO, through Dr Frederico Mayor, the Director-General, and Barry Jones, our own Australian representative on the executive board, has been taking active steps to try to get into Burma and, in particular, to see Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. Unhappily, a recent further effort to expedite that has met, like efforts before it, with failure.

As to the reports of hunger strikes, we do not have any evidence yet of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's embarking on any fast, let alone a fast to the death. There has been a public statement made by her husband, Dr Michael Aris, expressing his extreme concern that her resources available for the purchase of food and suchlike are fast running out, re-emphasising that she refuses to accept any supply of food or other necessities from the Burmese authorities and that, accordingly, the question arises as to how long her physical condition can be sustained on that basis. We are certainly concerned about this situation as reported by Dr Aris, and we renew our call upon the Burmese Government to release her from detention immediately, to transfer power to a democratic government as soon as possible and to respect human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the seriousness of her condition, when will the Australian Government reconsider the operations of the Austrade office and future diplomatic relations with Burma?

—If we thought that closing our very small Austrade office there would be productive in either enhancing Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's position or ensuring a fast return to democracy, we would be very quick to do just that. Unhappily, we do not believe that that would be anything more than a minor symbolic gesture—certainly not matching in its impact the kinds of efforts we have been making, which I have just described, through the UN and elsewhere. It would make sense if it were part of a wider international economic sanctions exercise. Over recent months we have explored very actively the possibility of sustaining such an exercise but, unfortunately, have not been able to gather sufficient support for that, in particular from the countries actually trading with Burma. There is a degree of support in principle from Europe, North America, Japan and elsewhere, and we would be prepared to go along with that if it were meaningful in practice. Regrettably, there is no evidence at this stage, again because of the situation with the Security Council I mentioned before and the situation among other neighbouring countries, to suggest that that support will be there.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer the Minister to an official report submitted to the former Victorian Labor Government into the building industry in that State in which it is alleged that organised crime and international terrorist groups have infiltrated powerful unions. When precisely did the Commonwealth Government become aware of the alarming allegations contained in that report, which was raised in the Parliament last week and received extensive coverage in the media this morning? Considering the serious nature of the police allegations, what discussions did the Commonwealth Government have with the Victorian Labor Government to satisfy itself that the matter was being dealt with satisfactorily? Finally, who decided that responsible Commonwealth agencies, including ASIO, should not pursue these serious matters, and why?

—There is an allegation of certain activity in the Victorian jurisdiction being dealt with, according to the report that Senator Vanstone mentions, in an unsatisfactory manner within the Victorian police force. I understand that that is the subject of a report called for by the present Minister for police in Victoria, Mr McNamara, from the Acting Police Commissioner. I imagine that that will give the fullest and most comprehensive understanding of the role of the Victorian police force in that investigation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone asked when Commonwealth authorities became aware of this matter. I will have to take that on notice as I think it goes back some three or four years. In so far as that, though, may be linked to questions of the participation of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, Senator Vanstone makes certain assumptions in her question to which I am unable, by convention, to respond, but the usual silence in relation to ASIO's activity in the context of any allegation such as this will be maintained by this Government in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand the Minister to be saying that the Victorian Government is presumably looking at this, but my question is: what is the Commonwealth Government doing about ascertaining whether these matters are being dealt with satisfactorily in so far as they may relate to areas of Commonwealth interest? Is he saying that organised crime and international terrorist groups infiltrating unions or behaving in some other way is not a matter for the Commonwealth to know about? Why can the Minister say nothing more today than that it is up to the Victorian Government to look at it when this matter clearly touches on Commonwealth responsibility in his area? If the Minister does not have anything to say now, will he get an answer and come back to this chamber with it before the end of Question Time?
—Don't protect your mates.

—I find it extremely offensive for Senator Kemp to suggest that in the discharge of my responsibilities as Minister for Justice, I would be protecting my mates, whoever that is a reference to. The honourable senator would not say it outside the chamber, would he? He would not say it outside the chamber because he does not have the guts. He does not have a deep enough pocket either, because I would sue him.

PARA.TAB: On the question of the role of Commonwealth agencies in relation to this matter, of course there are various elements of this which may require Commonwealth agencies to have a look at the matter. I will examine that particular matter. But this is primarily a matter for the Victorian police. In so far as there are other elements of Commonwealth interest and concern, there are conventions which are applied by all governments of any persuasion at the Commonwealth level in relation to certain activities of certain agencies, and I will adhere to those conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the submission by the South Australian Manufacturing Advisory Council, fully supported by its three members—the South Australian industries, manufacturing unions and the State Government—seeking a pause in tariff cuts and other industry assistance, particularly for TCF and car industries. Is the Minister prepared to repeat his pre-Budget advice to the Prime Minister, as reported in the Age newspaper, that tariff cuts should cease while unemployment was high? Does he think he will now succeed since unemployment has continued to rise since he gave his pre-Budget advice and is now at a record 11.3 per cent?

—I am aware of the views of the South Australian Manufacturing Council. Governments get views from bodies of this kind all the time on these issues and we have to discuss them as we get these representations. There was a discussion, as Senator Spindler points out, about these representations before the Budget. There were no recommendations. There was a discussion about some of the representations we had received. I will not be advising the Prime Minister or anybody else to have a pause in tariff cuts, particularly not now, because in the last few months there has been something like a 15 per cent depreciation of the Australian dollar, which, of course, adds significantly to the level of protection given to local manufactures. So I certainly would not be tendering that advice at this time.

PARA.TAB: I just want to take Senator Spindler up on one point of his question about which we seem to be in continual disagreement: the question of employment. Senator Spindler always asks in these questions whether we will halt the tariff cuts. The implication in his head is apparently that that will do something about the present unfortunate employment situation. I want to make it clear that I do not believe that. I believe that while tariffs may have made a marginal impact on employment in this country, the major contributors to unemployment in Australia have been the recession and a high level of structural adjustment in a number of government instrumentalities and major firms. Many of those major firms are not in areas which are protected by tariffs. Look at where the big slugs of disemployment have come from—the banks, the financial sector and the construction sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It is not rubbish. The highest levels of disemployment have come from the banks, the financial sector and the construction sector. For example, in our State of Victoria, by far the highest loser of employment has been the construction sector. Tariffs have nothing to do with that. It is a process arising from the recession, asset priced deflation and a number of other factors which have affected that industry. If Opposition senators want to believe that it is due to tariffs, they can go on believing that—but they are fairies at the bottom of the garden if they think that.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer, but he is not basing it on facts. I would be happy to supply him with detailed information as to the job losses that were occasioned by tariff cuts. Even if he is not prepared to stop tariff cuts, which are destroying our manufacturing industry, I wonder whether he is prepared to go along with his colleague Senator Richardson, who says that Australia is uniquely unwise in not supplying targeted assistance to industry. Is he prepared to consider tax based concessions to industry to assist it?

—I do not want the benefit of Senator Spindler doing a whole lot of work to prove to me what is not a fact. I simply say to Senator Spindler that if he looks it up he will find that the highest levels of unemployment, particularly in our State, have occurred in industries such as the construction industry. Tariffs have nothing to do with these industries. Of course there has been some loss of employment in the manufacturing sector. But in 1989 and the first quarter of 1990 employment in manufacturing industry grew to an all-time high for the last two decades, and the loss of employment has been against that figure. As to the second part of the question—I have forgotten what it was.
—Richo.
—Yes. I agree that there is a role for government in these matters, and I think it is an important role. I have not had the opportunity of discussing it with Senator Richardson.

—My question of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce is prompted by his response to an earlier question by Senator Coulter. I refer the Minister to the latest national accounts data, which reveal that private equipment investment in relation to GDP is presently 6.5 per cent, the lowest in 10 years—in fact, the lowest recorded figure ever. What does this disastrous level of investment mean for employment prospects in Australia? Further, what does it mean for future deficits on the current account, given that the deficit has again surged but the economy still has not reached its pre-recession levels?

—Investment in manufacturing plant and equipment reached its highest just prior to the recession. Of course, with the recession, investment in plant and equipment has been extremely disappointing. That is something which always happens when there is a downturn in the Australian economy.
—Recovery is on the way!

—I cannot predict precisely when that improvement in investment will come, but I am confident that it will because, as Senator Parer interjects, recovery is on the way. The effect of investment on the current account is varied from time to time. Because we do not have a comprehensive manufacturing sector such as that of Japan, a lot of capital goods are imported into Australia and that affects the current account adversely. For example, we do not make aircraft here; we do not make a lot of items of sophisticated computer hardware; we do not make a lot of machine tools—just to give three examples. Those things inevitably are imported. The importation of those things adversely affects the current account but is very good for manufacturing industry, or for industries generally. So that is a good thing. We will always get differential effects on the current account from time to time, depending on the overall situation of the economy.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I understood Senator Button to be saying that he was unable to predict when we would see a recovery in investment in capital private equipment. Does he accept that this is an indicator which has a very significant influence on domestic private capacity which, in itself, will be directly reflected in employment and the deficit?

—Senator Crichton-Browne can try to read anything he likes into what I have said. All I can say is that investment intentions across industry are higher than they were a year ago. They are the sort of advance indicators we have about investment. These things happen when a recovery occurs. —When will that be?

—I am not like Senator Crichton-Browne. I do not go around the place making predictions about precise dates and months. —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of an agreement between Optus Communications and the Communications Workers Union which provides wage increases for workers in return for measures to improve productivity? Is this agreement an example of the many agreements reached under the Government's system of cooperative workplace bargaining which are increasing productivity and competitiveness of Australian businesses? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the current number of workplace agreements registered with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, and what percentage of workers covered by Federal awards are now working under workplace agreements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The flexibilities afforded under our system of industrial relations are now encouraging more and more Australian companies to enter into workplace agreements with their employees and unions. This does not make headlines because there are no disputes about it. It is done without disputation and without conflict and with cooperation. Thus, it is not something that features in the daily press, which tends to report bad news not good. However, the effect is that we are now seeing the spread of workplace agreements which generate higher levels of productivity and reward workers as contributors to those agreements, as they indeed reward the shareholders and customers of those companies, too.

PARA.TAB: The latest in this list is Optus Communications, a company with 1,300 employees in the telecommunications industry. Optus has concluded an agreement which will enable those workers to increase their skills, to use those skills more flexibly, to be paid under a performance based pay scheme, which provides for a 10 per cent annual bonus subject to the productivity levels being achieved. It incorporates the annual leave loading and other allowances in a base rate, and provides for time off in lieu of overtime. This is an agreement which demonstrates, beyond any doubt, the flexibilities available in the present system—flexibilities to vary above a minimum, fairly and freely determined by recourse to arbitration; not a flexibility to go below unacceptable minimum standards.

There are nearly 600 such agreements now registered in the Industrial Relations Commission. They do not disadvantage workers. They set the climate for workplace reform in this country. On Friday, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission ratified the Australian Public Service agreement. This is an agreement that covers 150,000 Australian workers in the Australian Public Service sector. This is primarily a performance based agreement. In other words, they will find levels of higher productivity in order to pay for wage increases, and if they do not find them, the wage increases will be restricted to a couple of adjustments to make sure that living standards in this country do not fall behind. It is basically a decentralising of what up until now has been a relatively rigid structure for the Australian Public Service—decentralising that to the agencies that make up the Public Service, to enable the public servants to chase the productivity changes that are available at that level, but to do so with a proper safety net. It is not what the Opposition proposes. What the Opposition proposes is effectively the law of the jungle, and devil take the hindmost; everyone will be pushed and pressed and sacked if he disagrees. This is an agreement based on cooperation. It underpins our level of workplace reform, and is yet another example of how successfully we manage reform in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the recently released study by the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia which shows that its 140 member companies, representing 19 industries, do not believe they have received any of the supposed benefits of the Government's micro-economic reform. I also refer to the comments of Professor Garnaut, who says he would like to see micro-economic reform going faster, and the Industry Commission annual report released last month—which the Minister alluded to earlier today—which also criticises the Government's record on micro-economic reform. In light of this criticism from the very people who are in a position to know whether the Government's micro-economic reforms are working, does the Minister support the statement by the Prime Minister on Lateline recently when he said that most micro-economic reform is completed? If the Minister does support that statement, why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair enough for the MTIA, the Industry Commission and commentators such as Professor Garnaut to make those remarks. Their remarks are about encouraging a quicker pace for reform. Our concern is to perform at the highest and fastest level. But remarks that are about quicker, faster, higher, more, more, more, without any regard to the quality of change remind me of the old rag trade saying, `Never mind the quality, feel the width'. The essential issue here is to make reform that is genuine, irreversible and reflects a real change in the culture of the community.

PARA.TAB: In answer to an earlier question today, I referred to what the Industry Commission really said as opposed to selective quoting of what people pretend it asserted. The Industry Commission said that there was significant micro-economic reform in this country. I am prepared to table my list of quotes so that Senator Ferguson can go to the actual source material to see that that is demonstrated. It is for those reasons that the Prime Minister made his remarks. They were made on the basis—if we take, for example, the shipping industry or the waterfront—that a number of structural changes that were necessary have been made, with the Government playing a positive role in their making. Now it is over to the private sector; it has to take advantage of those changes.

Where the full value of the reduction in waterfront costs has not been passed on to exporters or importers, the companies that use it, but is captured by the shipping companies—as Professor Fels found in the Prices Surveillance Authority report on the waterfront—it is for those companies in their commercial negotiations with the shipping companies to extract that full value; and we would urge them to do so. As a positive step to encourage them to achieve that, we are making available transparently to the whole community the levels of the reform.

There is never an end to micro-economic reform in a country such as Australia. We are on a reform continuum. It is a question of the Government's role and the private sector's role. The Prime Minister is right in saying that a number of essential things that were necessary to be done by government have been completed successfully.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is there any evidence of a structural change occurring in the balance of Australian international trade? If so, what part have Government programs played in this change?

—There is a significant structural change in the composition of Australian exports. Australian manufacturing is now making significant inroads into the Asia-Pacific region with growth rates of 25 per cent into the ASEAN countries in each of the last two years.

PARA.TAB: This trend was noted in the November issue of the Reserve Bank Bulletin. Because a variety of explanations have been offered to account for the consistent and widespread growth of manufactured exports, some have sought to dismiss it as cyclical while others suggest that it may be due to only one or two markets growing quickly. But the Reserve Bank article rightly dismisses these views, pointing out that the growth is too widespread and too consistent.

My discussions with many manufacturers from a wide variety of fields confirm that manufacturers intend to stay in export markets after the upturn in the economy. Indeed, through periods of high growth in the mid-1980s, the export propensity of Australian manufacturing firms increased very steadily. For example, there were 15 per cent growth rates in manufacturing exports, even at a time when the economy was growing strongly. Those exports have continued to grow through the recession.

The Reserve Bank article to which I referred notes that assisted industries have made a substantial contribution to the growth—and this is the point of Senator Faulkner's question. A little over half the growth from 1986 to 1992 was in an industry supported by government programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit of intervention?

—Yes. So these government programs are working. Only the Opposition in Australia would now not acknowledge that fact. As the Opposition spokesman recently indicated to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, he would have a very careful look, as he put it, at any of these programs. The onus would be on DITAC staff to persuade him that they were beneficial. That is fair enough—I accept that people have to be persuaded—but Mr McLachlan clearly needs more persuasion than others. For example, if he looked with an open mind at the automotive industry and the growth in exports which has taken place there, he would see that the policies espoused by the Opposition for that industry are sheer lunacy and show no understanding of what generates exports in an industry of that kind.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do the manufacturers that the Minister spoke of acknowledge the positive role that the Government is playing in this area?

—I am sure that there is plenty of acknowledgment by manufacturers of that role. The results can be seen in terms of successful export and quality award winners. Both export drive and quality performance drive have been generated by government programs. The response from the manufacturing sector to those sorts of things has been magnificent.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Ministers for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and Justice (Senator Tate), in response to questions without notice asked by Senators Crane and Vanstone and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill), this day relating to allegations concerning building unions.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook's answers to the questions asked by Senator Crane and Senator Hill today, quite frankly, are totally unacceptable and unbelievable. They very much smack of a major cover-up on an issue of very significant national importance, going, amongst other things, to perhaps the most significant of all matters of national importance: national security. Senator Cook is trying to tell us today in his responses to the questions that he was asked that, in effect, he is taking a different tack to what he took on 25 November when he responded to questions on this matter when they were first raised by my colleague Senator Winston Crane.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that honourable senators will recall those reports in the West Australian that were brought to the attention of the Senate by Senator Crane. Senator Crane said that a police report into the Victorian building industry had claimed that organised crime and international terrorist groups had infiltrated powerful unions in Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: It went on to detail examples of that. When that was brought to the attention of Senator Cook, he, in effect, took the question on notice. Senator Cook then came back a couple of days later and said in relation to it that he had indeed made inquiries; his Department had inquired of the Victorian police about the existence of the report. He further stated:

From the other end of the phone in Melbourne it got a horse laugh and a guffaw that it was unbelievable that anyone would have even bothered with this; and that they could not understand why my Department—
that is, Industrial Relations—
was inquiring about a backdated document which had no current relevance.

He then went on to say that the document was in fact `a discredited document'. Senator Cook did go to the trouble of investigating this matter last time because he obviously felt it was a matter pertinent to his portfolio. Indeed, he went so far as to absolutely ridicule that report. Since then, there have been some very significant developments, the most important of which is the production and preparation of a minute to the Deputy Commissioner of Police in Victoria—now the Acting Commissioner—Mr Frame, from Chief Inspector Cairns, dated 27 November 1992, just 10 days ago. That minute was prepared as a result of the West Australian press report and the questions asked here by Senator Crane, which puts an absolute lie to the statements and answers that Senator Cook gave here on 25 November. He said it was a discredited report. Chief Inspector Cairns says that the report in the West Australian which prompted the questions was an accurate report. He goes on to say:
The information contained in the article is a `direct lift' from reports that I wrote and passed onto the Victorian Government (at that time).
Chief Inspector Cairns says that there were several things that they were advised not to pursue. He further states:

We were advised that we were not to pursue the issue of the "I.R.A. soldiers" entering Australia although we did pass on some information to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (A.S.I.O.).
I have never been advised as to what, if any, action has been taken by A.S.I.O.
He also says:

During the course of the inquiry there was a reasonable amount of intelligence uncovered in respect of the activities of the B.L.F. and other Unions. Those issues were included in our reports to the Government but were not pursued as our "brief" only required of us to investigate . . .

This is a matter of very considerable importance. I ask for leave of the Senate to have Chief Inspector Cairns's report incorporated in Hansard. Parts of this report have appeared in today's press; it is not a confidential minute.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: TO:Deputy Commissioner Frame
FROM:Chief Inspector Cairns
SUBJECT:The West Australian Newspaper Article dated November 24, 1992—"Terrorist Link to Unions Seen

Between April, 1987, and May 1988, I was seconded to a Victorian State Government Task Force the objective of which was to investigate the activities of the deregistered Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation (B.L.F).
The Task Force was required to enquire into the activities of the B.L.F. in respect to the manner in which it accounted for and used money, property and other assets belonging to the Union.

As a result of the investigation by the Task Force the Governor in Council signed an order on the 13th of October, 1987, directing that the "Possession, custody and control of the funds and property of the B.L.F. be committed to Ian Gordon Sharp (the Custodian)".
I executed that Order on the 13th of October, 1987 at 11 Lygon Street, Carlton.

During the course of the inquiry there was a reasonable amount of intelligence uncovered in respect to the activities of the B.L.F. and other Unions. Those issues were included in our reports to the Government but were not pursued as our "brief" only required of us to investigate, as previously stated, the "use of money, property and other assets belonging to the B.L.F.".
The report in the West Australian is accurate.
The information contained in the article is a `direct lift' from reports that I wrote and passed on to the Victorian Government (at that time).

We were advised that we were not to pursue the issues of the "I.R.A. soldiers" entering Australia although we did pass on some information to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (A.S.I.O.).
I have never been advised as to what, if any, action was taken by A.S.I.O.
Matters relating to the training of Australian Union Officials in Libya and funding by that country were not pursued by us.

The raising of money by the Sinn Fein in Australia, particularly in the Building Industry, was also an area that we were advised not to pursue. Direct contacts with that organisation had been made, both in Melbourne and Sydney.

I am satisfied that the information contained in the newspaper article could only have come from reports of which I was the author. Further, there were no other copies of these reports other than those handed to the Government.

This was a Government enquiry and all documentation, other than the authorities given to me by the Governor in Council and associated papers were handed over to the Victorian Government on completion of the Task Force on May 7, 1988.
D.A. Cairns
CHIEF INSPECTOR
27 November 1992

PARA.TAB: This Minister for Industrial Relations seems totally oblivious to the fact that very serious allegations have been made about a number of unions—not one union; not just the BLF. To bring this matter home, if Senator Cook does not understand why it is so very important that this be properly investigated, I point out that in this report there is the suggestion that the officials of a number of unions were trained in Libya, at the same time as there is massive militant unionism in Victoria which is seeking to rock the very Government that has just been elected. That in itself is cause for concern.

It is not unreasonable for this Senate to ask: which unions were involved in having officials trained in Libya? Were they or are they the same unions that are now, at this very point, seeking to bring down a democratically elected government? Are they the same unions that are seeking to advance their militant claims, to the disgust of many ordinary Victorian workers? Why is it that we have a Minister who wishes to put his head in the sand when perhaps the most serious allegation made in this country in the last 10 years in relation to industrial relations has been made in this chamber? Why is it that a Minister in this chamber, where this matter has been raised in good faith, wishes to stick his head in the sand?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or walk out the door.

—Or, as Senator Tambling says, why is it that the Minister chooses to walk out the door? It is wholly reprehensible. He did not even have the courtesy to stay in this chamber. If he does not do anything, he will be deserving of blame and condemnation, not just by this Senate but by every working man and woman in this country who finds this sort of conduct thoroughly reprehensible.

—It would be most unfortunate if this Parliament or this Minister were to pursue, in an investigative way, matters that have been raised in this article. As Senator Cook has said, the main allegations were made in reference to the BLF. He has dealt with that, and I do not want to go into that. Where would we end up if we, as a parliament, were to investigate every allegation that is made in the context of the industrial relations area?
—This is an allegation of terrorism.

—Senator Crane says that there is an allegation of terrorism, and that is all it is. Nobody has been named. No union has been specifically named as taking on people from the Republican Army. All that has been referred to is allegations. But what if, for example, we were to take this course and we did have evidence about an area of industrial relations? Should this Parliament investigate that? As Senator Crane would know, there is some very strong evidence of what was done at the Camperdown abattoirs in October 1991 when a Mr Warwick Leeson acted allegedly and, on the evidence, probably correctly, in terms of inferences that can be drawn, as an agent provocateur. People were prosecuted on the basis of the allegations he made, all of which prosecutions were brought against meatworkers who were picketing and all of which prosecutions were dismissed, with costs being awarded against the police. This was in circumstances where the senior police officer said that he had, in effect, been duped and where the instructions to Mr Leeson came from a firm of solicitors, Kroger and Kroger.

PARA.TAB: Very serious matters took place at the abattoirs at Camperdown—very concerning in terms of the industrial relations ramifications they would have. It would be my position that that should not be investigated by the Parliament because parliaments and Ministers are not the appropriate institutions—

TALK.START.PARA: —Instruments.

—I thank Senator Baume. They are not the appropriate instruments to investigate these matters. We all, properly so, try to take political advantage of situations in this chamber, but it becomes a very worrying feature if we are to call upon the Parliament or upon Ministers to exercise investigative powers. That is why there is a separation of powers between people who should investigate matters and people who should not.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought it was up to the Victorian police, if there were sufficient evidence—it seems to me on the basis of this article that there was not sufficient evidence—to investigate it or for ASIO to take the matter further. In either case, politicians and Ministers should not be part of that investigation and should certainly not be invited to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join with my colleagues in taking note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, in Question Time today. It is an alarming situation when we have a Minister responsible for any portfolio who is happy at one time to answer questions in relation to that portfolio and in less than a week announce that questions relating to the same matter have somehow shifted themselves out of that portfolio responsibility. Senator Cook now seeks to wash his hands of any involvement by him or his Department in the future in relation to this report. He says that it is not a matter for him; it is a matter related to Senator Tate's portfolio. But it is a matter for him; that is why he answered the questions last week.

PARA.TAB: If there is any suggestion that unions have been infiltrated by organised crime or by terrorists, that must be a matter of interest for the Minister responsible for industrial relations, for a variety of reasons. The first reason is quite obvious—it is simply a misuse of the unions and the cause to which they are meant to be directing their attention. In all probability, there may be a diversion of funds and capacity from the unions into areas not for the benefit of the workers on whose behalf they are meant to be acting. Once we get to the question of funds, we realise that Senator Cook's Department is responsible for a large amount of funds that go towards unions. Therefore, he should be concerned as to whether these allegations are correct.

My colleague Senator Cooney said that it is not up to the Minister or the Executive to be doing the investigating because other people can do that. That may be true, but all that has been asked is whether the Minister will ascertain what the current state of affairs is. Who he gets to do that is his business. Senator Cook has said, `Look, this was all a few years ago. How am I expected to know? It is not my problem'. Then he tries to mislead the Senate by saying, `Look, you might not realise this but we got rid of the BLF and therefore this is not a problem'. But the minute that has been tabled refers to the BLF and other unions. I noted in Senator Cook's response that he has not ruled out the involvement of other unions.

In my view, Senator Cook is not entitled to come into this place and say that three years later he does not know anything about it and he does not think it is his place to investigate it. More particularly, he should not be able to say that the fact that the Victoria Police has not done anything is in itself a reason for the Commonwealth not to do something if there is a matter of substance to be looked at. One has only to look at the Commonwealth's view in industrial relations to see why it is happy to let the Victorian Government do what it likes. The Victorian Government is not allowed to do some things in industrial relations because the Commonwealth does not like it, so it is seeking to take some steps to do what the Commonwealth wants in that respect. So I do not see why this matter is any different from the debate we are having over industrial relations policy. The Commonwealth says it has a right to intervene there and look after its interest and to intervene here and look after its interest if it wishes to do so.

I would like briefly to make some remarks about the answer given by the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, in Question Time today. I understand the degree to which he is required to avoid making remarks with respect to ASIO, but the question he was asked did not relate solely to ASIO; it related to other Commonwealth agencies as well.

In conclusion, it is simply unsatisfactory that a Minister will acknowledge in one week that serious allegations do concern his portfolio, that he will go and get someone to get some information, that information will be brought forward from the Victorian police and, then, in seven or eight days following his first response that Minister will try to wash his hands and say, `It's nothing to do with me', when it has everything to do with him. Millions of dollars worth of taxpayers' money is going to the unions. He is responsible for industrial relations and he is responsible to see that the unions are working well.
