TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—At the request of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) and pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence over all other business to a motion to order the production of the Treasury document on the goods and services tax in New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: I have moved to suspend standing orders in order to obtain the release by the Government of a report by Treasury officers on the operation of the goods and services tax in New Zealand. The matter is important because of the report's release and exposure in the last few days. For well over 12 months the Government has suppressed a report by Commonwealth Treasury officers following a visit that they made to New Zealand in September 1991 to examine the effects and operation of the goods and services tax which the former Labour Government in New Zealand introduced in about 1986. Since the coalition released its Fightback documents a year or more ago, the Australian Government, particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), has engaged in a mixture of distortion and misinformation. On many occasions the Prime Minister has told outright lies to the public concerning the operation of the goods and services tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short, you cannot say that the Prime Minister has told outright lies. It is unparliamentary and I ask you to withdraw it.

—I withdraw, Mr President. But there has been a campaign of massive distortion and misinformation about the operation of the goods and services tax, particularly in New Zealand. Through a freedom of information request, the Sydney Morning Herald has obtained a massively censored version of the report written by the two Treasury officers and one senior officer from the Taxation Office after they were sent to New Zealand in September 1991 obviously to fossick around for any information that the Government might be able to use against the coalition's Fightback proposals—particularly the proposal to implement a goods and services tax to replace, as part of a major beneficial reform of our taxation system, the wholesale sales tax, which is the archaic and secret consumption tax system that we have, payroll tax and the very heavy petrol tax that we have in Australia. The coalition proposes to reform the indirect tax system to make it much simpler, fairer and equitable as well as to reduce personal income tax in Australia on average across the board by about one-third.

PARA.TAB: The report by the Treasury and Tax Office officials on their return to Australia appears to have been a very different sort of report to that which the Government had been expecting. Although virtually all of the report was obliterated and censored by the Government before skerricks of it were released to the Sydney Morning Herald under freedom of information, it does say that `the implementation of the goods and services tax was universally reported to have gone very smoothly' in New Zealand. Any comments in most of the rest of the report are of a favourable nature.

But there are enormous parts of the report which have been obliterated and not made public. For example, all pages from 9 to 24 of this 24-page report have been totally deleted. Some sections in the early parts of the report—it is inconceivable why they would be obliterated or kept secret in any way—have been obliterated. For example, almost all of the material under the subheading `Attitudes to GST' has been deleted. Other than to say that there is virtually no lobbying for change to the GST and that there is further evidence of the acceptance of GST, the rest is wiped out. For all those reasons, it is a very important report. That is why I have moved that Standing Orders be suspended.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not waste a lot of the Senate's time debating this motion to suspend Standing Orders as I understand it will be supported. But I think it is fairly important that we do put on the record why the Government does not support the motion. Quite simply, it is a very irresponsible proposal. Senator Short actually knows it is, but he is rather desperate to find something to prop up the Opposition's ailing policy.

PARA.TAB: If there were a crisis about the failure of the Government to provide this information, if it were a matter about which immediate action should be taken, it is remarkable that nothing happened six weeks ago when, at an Estimates committee meeting, the Treasury was asked whether the Government would provide it. We said no. About a month ago we advised why we would not do so. This is a quite straightforward matter under freedom of information, under the proper management of government business and under the proper management of a relationship between countries.

The trip report is mostly records of confidential discussions between the Australian officials and the New Zealand officials, and of discussions in confidence with New Zealand business representatives and academics. In the course of the normal conduct of bilateral relations between friendly countries, we send our officers regularly to New Zealand and New Zealand officers regularly come here. Discussions are held with senior representatives of government, business and others on the basis that those discussions will be confidential.

It is very important that we maintain that liaison and the capacity to have those discussions. Therefore, it is important that we do not wantonly undermine the confidential basis upon which these discussions have been going on, as I understand it, for quite a long time. If we were to table here and release the results of the report of confidential discussions with New Zealand, it would not only impact upon our relationship with New Zealand but also it would have a profound impact on our relationship with every country with which we wish to have confidential discussions—as everybody understands we should and must do as a proper government responsibility.

We are quite happy to have a discussion about all those things on the public record pro and anti the impact of the GST in New Zealand, Canada, the UK and wherever else people want to discuss it. What a fascinating objective to have in public life—to aspire to turn Australia into New Zealand! What a fantastic objective! But I will not go too far into that debate, although I would love to do so.

Let us talk about whether or not it is proper, as a matter of public policy, to seek to require that a document be tabled when it is quite clearly against the national interest that it be tabled. It is not a question of the Government having put its arm into the bureaucratic process and required that a document that normally would be made public be not made public. It is the very opposite.

As the Treasury has made clear—and as any rudimentary examination of the freedom of information legislation makes clear with regard to the original document—although those same principles do not bind the Parliament, they should apply in this instance to the Parliament's interpretation of whether it should require these documents to be tabled. It is very important that we—as a chamber of the Parliament; as representatives of Australia—make responsible decisions with a long term view rather than irresponsible decisions in the fervent hope that some short term benefit may flow. In my view, that clearly is what would be involved in the release of this document, and that is why the Government will not be supporting either the suspension or the motion.

The motion and its achievement, to the extent that it will make the GST more of a focus of public debate in Australia, clearly are in the Government's interests. We are quite happy to have the GST as the focus of debate today, tomorrow and every day until the election. That is not a problem for us at all. The more that is the case, the better. But we do have an obligation to seek to protect the public interest in this matter. That is why this document, which is not a major document and which has not been in any way suppressed by political decision, will not be released. People who are entirely partisan in their life cannot understand that that might not be the case for others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the suspension of Standing Orders and make an appeal to both Senator Short and Senator Hill that, immediately after the suspension debate has finished, the motion be put. We can then dispense with the motion—we will also support the motion—and get on with the legislation. We make this appeal for a very brief debate. We do this, recognising that this document probably is not of any great moment.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the Treasury officials concerned went to New Zealand for three days—and it is a 24-page document. It is very

SPEECH.PARA: difficult to believe that there was much substance to the Sydney Morning Herald claim that this in any way reflected public opinion in New Zealand, because I do not believe that Treasury officials would have gone to New Zealand and carried out a survey of public opinion in three days, nor were they capable or competent to do that. I have difficulty in believing that there is a great deal of content in this document. Nonetheless, we believe that it should be in the public domain and we will support the suspension and the motion.

PARA.TAB: It is well known that in 1986 the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), then Treasurer, favoured a GST. On previous occasions I have made the point that the Prime Minister may be double-dealing not only the Australian public but also his own Party with respect to the GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —For once I think you are right.
—Senator Kemp is actually supporting me for once.
—Watch it!

—`Watch it', says my colleague. This may be a document which indicates that Mr Keating would very much like to have a GST in Australia. Nonetheless, our position on the GST is clear: we are opposed to it. Anything coming from New Zealand will not sway that opinion, particularly in view of the short time which the Treasury officials spent over there.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition is on record as saying that it does not respect Treasury very much. In recent days it has criticised Treasury when a number of other issues have been raised. It is not particularly good for the Opposition to debate this report of Treasury, nor is it very logical of it to place a great deal of store in the report, when in other contexts it has rejected Treasury advice and Treasury analysis. For that reason also, one could not place a great deal of emphasis on what use the Opposition may make of this document once it becomes public.

We understand that the Treasury officers spoke to academics in New Zealand. I think Senator McMullan has mentioned that. I would be very surprised if any academic in New Zealand is concerned about having his or her views revealed publicly. I think it is very much to be regretted if any academics who hold views on an important issue such as this should express those views to Treasury officials and then object to those views being released to the public. It is in the nature of academic discourse that those views should be known quite widely.

Again, I would be disappointed if business people in New Zealand who had views which were of sufficient strength to influence Treasury officials in their report also were now embarrassed by the release of that sort of information which should be in the public domain. Of course, it is just possible that some of the New Zealand Treasury officials in New Zealand said certain things, but surely that would be a relatively small part of this report which we are led to believe is dealing with the impact of a GST on New Zealand.

We believe that very little harm would flow from this, and not a great deal of good would flow from it either, because it is probably a report of little moment, but we would support the motion to suspend Standing Orders and also urge Senator Short to immediately put the substantive motion which we will support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

That a motion to order the production of the Treasury document on the goods and services tax in New Zealand may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business till determined.
Motion (by Senator Short) agreed to:

That the Minister representing the Treasurer table in the Senate before the adjournment on Tuesday, 8 December 1992, the full, unexpurgated note for file dated 27 September 1991 of Treasury Officers J. Wright and T. O'Brien relating to the New Zealand experience with its goods and services tax.
