SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with much pleasure that I take the passage of this Bill on behalf of the Liberal-National Party coalition because it is a Bill for which I have a great deal of sympathy. It fulfils one of my wishes. As I have stated on previous occasions in the Senate, the Government has no business in running a pure commercial enterprise like an airline in the 1990s. Indeed, probably for the last 20 years or more government has had no business trying to run an airline.

PARA.TAB: So the Senate has before it this afternoon the Qantas Sale Bill 1992, the purpose of which, broadly, is to define the terms and conditions of sale of the airline. Qantas is a government owned company. It is proposed that the government holding be sold to the private sector both within Australia and overseas.

I cannot help reflecting upon the irony of the situation, because Qantas was bought by a Labor government. Now, 47 years later, Qantas is being sold by a Labor government. Those of us who have been in the Parliament for some while will remember that, when we put the case years ago that Qantas should be sold, we had enormous opposition from the Labor Party on purely ideological grounds—that one could not sell this great Australian icon; that it would go to rack and ruin if it were sold. So it really is quite ironic that today I am here speaking on this Bill for the sale of this airline.

The Opposition's main criticism about this sale is that it has taken so long in coming. The reason that Qantas is being sold is that the Government can no longer afford to keep the airline. So we have the situation, again with a touch of irony, that the airline is being sold by the Government for the wrong reasons. But, historically, the Government bought the airline for the wrong reason; it was a Labor government that bought it, and it did so on purely ideological grounds because it believed in nationalisation. The Government that bought the airline tried to nationalise the main airline in Australia at the time, which was Australian National Airlines. The Government was defeated in that and it turned around and bought another internal airline, which was Qantas, but which was also involved in overseas passenger and freight travel.

In 1990 the Labor Party changed its view in a very bitter conference and decided to sell 49 per cent of the airline. That was quite an illogical decision. Why would the Government sell 49 per cent if it were prepared to sell some of it? This year the financial pressures were so heavy on the Government that it changed its position once more and decided to sell 100 per cent of it. The Government had to sell 100 per cent because it knew, and was advised repeatedly, that no-one would buy 49 per cent of the airline, which was the original proposition. Who would go into a commercial contract with a government that has run the country as badly as this Government has? We have seen the national debt go from about $32 billion up to somewhere in excess of a gross figure now of over $200 billion in 10 years. So the only way the Government could sell Qantas was to sell the whole lot.
The truth of that is shown on the first page of the second reading speech. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) said:

SPEECH.PARA: From 1988 on, the boards of directors for both Qantas and Australian Airlines had repeatedly raised with the Government the question of their being given greater access to equity capital. The airlines were weighed down by grossly uncommercial debt to equity ratios at a time of rapid business expansion.
That is at the heart of the matter. The Government can no longer afford to keep this airline.

PARA.TAB: When I was preparing the material for this speech, I was very interested to talk to two advisers from the Department. I am grateful for their advice, but I could not help a wry smile when, through the course of the discussion, one of the advisers said, `Of course Qantas was originally a private company'. I refrained from saying it but, with the greatest of respect to the advisers, I think I know a little more about the history of Qantas than they do.

It is perfectly true that Qantas started out in 1920 as a private company. It was founded in Queensland. It was a company that started in the face of enormous difficulties. It faced a great deal of financial difficulty. It was restrained by the government of the day in every way possible. It was not allowed to compete with the railways, which in the early 1920s were very strong. The only air routes Qantas could get were linking the rail heads through western Queensland from Charleville to Cloncurry and even before that from Winton to Longreach.

It is history that on 2 November 1922 the Armstrong Whitworth FK8 flew the first service. From there, the company has prospered. I believe it has prospered through the quality of the men who founded that airline: Hudson Fysh was the Chief Executive for many years, long after the Government bought the airline. Hudson Fysh and Paddy McGinnes were two light horse soldiers from the First World War. McGinnes won a DCM at Gallipoli; Fysh was also at Gallipoli. They later transferred to No. 1 Squadron—the first Australian squadron and arguably the squadron with the greatest history of any of the squadrons in the RAAF. Both of them won distinguished flying crosses in that squadron.

After the war they joined with one of the engineers from the squadron, Arthur Baird. He was as legendary a figure as McGuinness and Fysh. They came together with a western Queensland grazier, Fergus McMaster of Moscow station. He raised the funds to form what was called the Queensland and Northern Territory Aerial Service. From that point on, in the face of great difficulties and with very primitive equipment, the service grew at a rapid rate.

I may be wrong, but I think for every year that the service was in operation, and that includes the years of the Great Depression, the company always showed a dividend—it always made a profit. That is no mean achievement and it is something that the airline has not always been able to manage while it has been owned by governments of various persuasions.

The airline grew very rapidly from a small outback airline until it branched out of Australia, in partnership with Imperial Airways, to run a passenger service between Australia and the United Kingdom—first of all with the DH86s and later with the Empire flying boats, four of which came along in 1938-39.

As a private company the airline rendered a very great service to Australia during the war. It lost a number of its crew through war service, although they were officially classified as non-combatants. It operated a freight and passenger service right to the front line when the Pacific war developed. It is no overstatement to say that the service the airline rendered to Australia was as good and as praiseworthy as any service the RAAF offered this country.

In 1947 Mr Chifley was the Prime Minister and the airline was bought by the Government. From then the airline expanded into a major international carrier—the sole Australian flag carrier. It has been apparent for the last 10 to 15 years that the shortage of capital in the airline has caused problems for the company. It simply has not had enough capitalisation to keep its interest payments down and to grow the way it should have.

The Bill before us starts by defining two points—the 50 per cent sale day and the 100 per cent sale day. It then moves into the articles of association, which define how the company will operate. Foreign ownership is defined as being limited in aggregate to 35 per cent. There is a good reason for that. If foreign ownership goes past 35 per cent the international traffic rights, which are fundamental to an international airline, will be null and void because Qantas will not be deemed to be an Australian owned airline.

The total foreign holding in any one hand is limited to 25 per cent. While I would prefer to see 100 per cent of Qantas ownership remain in Australian hands, I recognise that in today's market 25 per cent is the figure that we would probably need to offer to attract foreign airline bids. Make no mistake about it, if a group has a holding of 25 per cent in one hand, it has a very powerful influence on a company. It is not true to say that the rest of Qantas, the 75 per cent, will rule the roost without any reference at all to the 25 per cent foreign holding. It will be quite a powerful influence on the policies of the company.

Under the articles of association there are provisions limiting the number of foreign directors and denoting who can vote for them, requiring that the chairman always be Australian, and stipulating that the company maintain Qantas as its name, have its headquarters in Australia and be incorporated within Australia. The proposed procedure is that the initial sale of 49 per cent will take place and subsequently there will be a float to the Australian community of the remaining 51 per cent.

Originally, that was going to be towards the end of this year or in the early part of next year. The latest information from the Minister for Finance is that it will take place after the end of the financial year—that is, after the end of June next year. If that happens there will be an interesting problem for the Government. I do not think the Government will take any notice of it because how big a debt we have does not seem to worry this Government. An amount of $1.6 billion from the sale of Qantas was included in this year's Budget, and quite clearly that sum is not going to be realised within this financial year.

Part 3 deals with the requirement for the airline to trade under the name of Qantas when operating international services. I did raise the matter of Australia Asia Airlines with the advisers and I am assured that that will not be in any conflict with the provisions of the Act. Australia Asia Airlines is the subcompany set up by Qantas to trade with Taiwan.

The next part of the Bill deals with the debt and capital reconstruction. Because it is undercapitalised, Qantas does owe a very great deal of money and most of that is covered by Commonwealth of Australia guarantees. I cannot recall having seen a balance sheet in the immediate past. I think the last one I saw for the company listed debts of around $4 billion against assets of about $8 billion. This part of the Bill deals with the procedures by which the Government will remove itself from being guarantor for those loans in return for some shares in the company.

Part 5 deals with the maintenance of long service leave entitlements. Part 6 repeals the Qantas Empire Airways Act and the Australian National Airlines Act. Qantas Empire Airways was formed when Qantas became an international carrier in 1934. There was a joint shareholding with half of the company owned by the original Qantas and the other half owned by Imperial Airways, the precursor of British Overseas Airways Corporation, which has now become British Airways. It is rather interesting because it appears as though the successor to Imperial Airways—British Airways—will be the company which takes up the 25 per cent holding in Qantas. Part 7 deals with conditions of service of employees and part 8 tidies up some miscellaneous matters.

In conclusion, I wish to make a few general comments. There is a lot in this Bill about how the sale will take place, but there is very little about who the company will be sold to, apart from defining very clearly the overseas limits. That is one of the great weaknesses of the Bill. The overseas sales are very clearly defined: a maximum of 25 per cent to any one group, presumably an airline, and then a tranche of 10 per cent going to investors overseas. The inference—indeed, the comment in the newspapers recently of British Airways being in partnership with the Australian institutions, the superannuation funds and life insurance companies—is that they will take up the remainder of between 25 per cent and 49 per cent.

There is a very good case for the Bill to have made some provision for the sale of this great airline to the Australian public—first of all, to the employees, because I believe that the employees should be encouraged in every way. Certainly the policy of the Liberal and National parties is to do just that: to make it attractive for employees to take a shareholding in their company. I do not know what the size of Qantas is today. It used to have approximately 10,000 to 12,000 personnel. Since it has been merged with Australian Airlines, which had 8,000 to 10,000 employees, it probably has anywhere between 18,000 and 22,000 employees.

The management of a big block of employees such as that is very difficult. It is hard to motivate them and get the best out of them. It requires very high management skills. A good way of doing that is to encourage them to take a shareholding in the company so that they can see the effect of their work, reflected in both their job security and their financial reward. I believe there is a case for discounting some of the share float to the employees and encouraging them to take up the maximum shareholding in the company.

Beyond that, the Australian public—and I am talking about individual investors and family investors as opposed to the big institutions such as AMP, Bankers Trust and all those other investment houses—should be encouraged to take a maximum holding in the company. The institutional holders have a great deal to answer for in the last 10 to 15 years. They are entirely motivated by profit: if shares go up by a few cents or a dollar or two, they move out to get a profit for their own investment portfolios. That leads to very short-sighted policies and does not help the stability of the company at all. I would like the general public to be encouraged to take a maximum holding in this company, but we do not hear a word from the Government about that.

Even though times are hard, I do believe the public would support with their pockets the sale of Qantas stock. There are a couple of companies in Australia which are institutions in the public mind—institutions that encourage very great feelings of nationalism. One of them is Arnotts Biscuits, as one can see from all the debate that is running at present, as Campbells tries to take it over. Another such company is Qantas; there is a very great national pride in Qantas. I do believe that the general public would be prepared to get behind that national pride and support it with their own savings.

The next point I make relates to the current belief in mega-carriers. There is a feeling around the world—and it has been around for about 10 or 15 years—that one has to be very big to survive in the airline business. As I have made it clear to the Senate on numerous occasions over the years, I do not share that belief. I do not deny that the trend is running very strongly that way. It may well be that in 10 years time we have only six to nine giant carriers in the world. It might even be as few as four to six; the situation certainly looks as though it is going that way. The management problems of those mega-carriers are enormous. If we look at the history of the international airlines which exist at present, we see that only about four or five of them made a profit in the last financial year. They are in great difficulties; they have great managerial problems.

There will always be a place for a well-managed airline which gives outstanding service. Qantas, provided it changes some of its practices with respect to its cabin attendants, certainly could be in that category. It certainly provides outstanding service technically and through its aircrew. We do not have to join and submerge the company with one of the large international airlines in order for it to survive. We certainly need strategic alliances. A 25 per cent holding would give us that and we would have access to the computer reservations and the booking services of another company.

However, there are not the economies of scale in airline traffic that exist in the manufacturing industry. If a company is manufacturing cars, the more it produces, the lower its unit costs; whereas, once an airline gets beyond a certain level, it does not enjoy the same benefits.

The final matter I raise relates to the defence needs of this country. I believe that the Defence Act should be modified and amended so that there is provision in a national emergency for all transport resources, not only the airlines but also road and rail transport, to be taken over in the national interest. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was with some joy that I listened to Senator MacGibbon's remarks in relation to the symbolic nature of Qantas because, undoubtedly, over all the years that Senator MacGibbon reviewed in his speech, Qantas has increasingly come to occupy a special place in the Australian psyche. It is very much a symbol of Australia. Even though most people probably never travel in an aircraft, they nonetheless recognise the national carrier as a uniquely Australian symbol and they are quite proud of it.

PARA.TAB: As a national carrier, Qantas has fostered an exceptional goodwill in this country. Australians abroad have learnt to trust and rely on the national carrier, especially in difficult times when deserted by other airlines as a result of flight time changes, ticketing errors or whatever. I have been in that situation when overseas. The Qantas tradition, perhaps born of longevity and the tyranny of distance, is unique. It has provided an excellent service to Australians. It also has an excellent record of safety as an international carrier—a record unparalleled by other international airlines.

The Bill before us contains legislative changes to finalise the 100 per cent sale of Qantas. I was interested to hear what Senator MacGibbon said about ordinary Australians buying shares in their airline. Of course, when the airline is entirely government owned, it is the fact that, by proxy, every single Australian has a share in it. The Democrats are firmly of the opinion that, in the national interest, the Government should retain at least 51 per cent ownership. We will be voting against this Bill when the motion that it be read a second time is put, as we are opposed to the airline's privatisation. As we expect the Opposition to support the Government, we intend to move some amendments at the committee stage. I will be interested to know exactly how Senator MacGibbon and the coalition feel about those amendments because they seek to do some of the things that Senator MacGibbon spoke about. While we will not attempt to amend the Bill along the lines of having 51 per cent government ownership, we will be attempting to safeguard the national interest against undue foreign ownership and the control of our national carrier.

I was particularly interested in several other aspects of Senator MacGibbon's speech. He seemed to be relying on a philosophical view that private is good and government is bad. He would know—in fact, he mentioned this in his speech—that many of the very large international overseas carriers, some of them totally privately owned, have been unable to continue. It is not necessarily a mark of government ownership which puts Qantas in any difficult position.

There are many large privately owned companies in Australia which have fallen on very hard times in recent days. One wonders just what Senator MacGibbon thinks of those. The evidence is not that government is bad and private is good; the evidence is that some government is good and some government is bad, and some private is good and some private is bad. It is not a function of whether a business is government owned or privately owned; it is whether the business is run efficiently that is significant.

I would also like to make the point—I would agree with Senator MacGibbon on this—that Qantas has suffered from a lack of adequate capital to meet its needs. If the issue is the injection of capital, I make the point that the capital eventually comes from the community. Again, it does not matter too much whether it is a government owned business because the capital will find its way from the community to that business by way of taxation. If a private business receives capital from the community, essentially the profits of those shareholders and their businesses, which ultimately come from the community, will flow into the business by way of underwriting increases in share capital. The capital comes from the community, either by way of a government tax or by way of a private tax, if you like, which is essentially the profits that some people take and re-invest back into other businesses. It is important to recognise that there is nothing essentially good or bad about doing it through government or privately; it is just a different way of finding the capital which goes into those businesses.

We will be proposing amendments to further restrict foreign ownership of Qantas and to weaken the influence of foreign players, something that Senator MacGibbon referred to in his speech. At the same time, our changes would stem the flow of profits offshore. They would increase the scope for participation by small Australian shareholders and would make it easier—should the public ever wish—to repatriate Qantas wholly into Australian hands. We are hoping that Senator MacGibbon will support these amendments when the time comes.

The Democrats oppose the full privatisation of the national carrier. Public ownership in general is essential to provide a showcase for innovation in work practices and progressive employment practices. With a proper injection of funds, Qantas could have provided substantial returns to the Australian people—indeed, in recent years it has made profits, albeit small profits. However, for nearly three decades Liberal and Labor governments have been starving the enterprise of funds. It is absolutely incredible that the airline has survived so long with this low capital injection.

It has been negligence in funding that has been central to the financial and efficiency problems faced by Qantas. Lack of capital has been an issue since the early 1970s. The initial injection of government funds was small. This has never been adequately followed up. Qantas made it plain in its 1990-91 annual report that undercapitalisation was the predominant factor in its financial loss in that year.

For a number of years the airline has consistently argued that its profitability was being badly affected by what it called its `grossly inadequate level of capital'. At the end of the 1990-91 financial year its debt to equity ratio stood at 77 : 23. Financing costs exceeded equity by $206m. Its level of equity would not even buy a jumbo jet. Yet at that time the airline had 43 aircraft in its fleet.

There can be no doubt that if the Government had not starved our national carrier of funds it would not have had to borrow so much. The Government has been playing a game of financial brinkmanship with the airline. Qantas is so highly geared that it is indeed amazing that it has not gone down the path of the recently failed Compass Airlines venture. It has barely twice the amount of capital of the failed Compass Airlines. Qantas says it needs an injection of $1 billion to reduce its debt to equity ratio to similar levels of its competitors.

A strong case exists worldwide for governments to gain expertise in the aviation industry. This industry is regulated by way of bilateral agreements between governments. This has evolved through the industry's historical connections with national security and disaster aid. It is unique that free market forces do not prevail and that government involvement is the order of the day.

Another broad issue that is central to this debate is the question of foreign ownership of Australian enterprises. It must be asked whether it is in the national interest for six digit profit figures to go offshore and the extent to which limits should be applied to foreign control over Australian culture in the broadest sense of Australian icons such as Qantas.

National interest is central to this debate. A fully Australian owned and controlled company is more likely to act in the national interest. As I said in my opening remarks, Qantas has a special role in the Australian psyche. It has this very deep cultural connection. It is important that its identity should not be confused in the minds of Australians abroad, nor in the minds of visitors to this country. Tourists worldwide tend to travel with the national carrier of the country they are visiting as part of the cultural experience. Seasoned travellers are well aware of the differences in flying with, for example, the German owned Lufthansa as opposed to our own Qantas. Both reflect the ambience of their origins.

Qantas has acted in the national interest in national emergencies and disasters. Senator MacGibbon mentioned such emergencies that occurred during the Second World War. In the protracted 1989 pilots strike, Qantas ferried domestic passengers, offering relief at a time when belligerent union activity brought domestic air travel in this country to a virtual standstill for months. Again, when Cyclone Tracy struck Darwin on Christmas Day in 1974, the national carrier evacuated tens of thousands of stranded residents out of the wrecked and ravaged town. Qantas also airlifted hundreds of Australians stranded in Beijing in the horrific days following the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989. The impact of commercialisation on humanitarian service traditions such as these, particularly when such commercialisation involves a large percentage of foreign control, is at the heart of many of the Democrat concerns.

Qantas is a major earner of foreign currency, which is badly needed to reduce our ballooning foreign debt—a problem of which the last few days should have made us all too aware. Tourism in this country is widely acknowledged as having a bright future. We are all aware of the vertical integration of the tourist industry, particularly as it affects Japanese tourism in Queensland, the acquisition of tourist resorts, the travel by Japanese tourists on Japanese airlines and so on. This burgeoning industry is already Australia's largest export earner, reaping $7.3 billion in foreign currency annually.

Questions must be asked about the wisdom of allowing foreign players access to a sizeable chunk of valuable profits which would otherwise make massive contributions to reduction of that debt. The larger the foreign equity in Qantas, the more the profits flow offshore. Foreign dollars earned through Australian enterprises should be used in the national interest to pay off our debt and not to rack up profits for ring-ins. This is why we will attempt to limit foreign ownership levels in the privatisation of Qantas and other ventures.

We believe the Government's proposed 35 per cent limit on foreign ownership, with a 25 per cent limit on any one person, is too high. In the committee stage, we will attempt to reduce both of these limits. While the 25 per cent threshold per shareholder is below the legal definition of a controlling interest—Senator MacGibbon referred to this—under these terms foreigners would be able to exert effective, or de facto, control over the company.

We further reject the idea that a substantial foreign equity is essential to allow our airline to operate in the age of mega-carriers. While Qantas, even now that it has merged with Australian Airlines, remains small fry in this emerging age of mega-carriers, international evidence makes it clear that room exists for, if you like, boutique airlines. I would not quite put Qantas in that category, but I draw attention to the small time transatlantic carrier, Virgin Airlines, which started up in the 1980s covering one of the most cut-throat and competitive international routes, the Trans-Atlantic route, and which is making good profits. This airline is smaller than Qantas and operates on routes far more competitive than our airline's main international hauls.

In attempting to limit the amount of foreign equity in the privatised carrier as well as the total amount any one foreign player may acquire, we want to increase the scope for small shareholder participation for equity reasons. I was quite taken with Senator MacGibbon's idea of equity ownership by the workers in Qantas itself or Qantas-Australian Airlines. History reveals a significant transfer of wealth occurs during privatisation processes. Privatisation tends to involve underpricing of share issues, as we saw in the Commonwealth Bank share issue and the privatisation of both British Airways and Air New Zealand. Limits on foreign equity, such as the Democrats are proposing, will optimise opportunities for Australian shareholders.

Another key reason to limit foreign ownership is that, should Australians ever want to repatriate the airline, the smaller the foreign equity the easier the task will be. We also believe, given international trends towards mega-carriers with 40 per cent foreign equity, that it is highly likely a future government will attempt to increase the foreign equity threshold in Qantas. A low equity base rate provides a better chance to stave this process off; and that in the long term is in the national interest. The Democrats do not accept that Qantas must become a mega-carrier to survive. As I have already argued, international evidence exists to support smaller airlines and Qantas is further advantaged by operating in a partially captive niche market.

As I have said, Qantas has fostered exceptional goodwill in this country. It has helped countless Australians stranded abroad. It has provided assistance in times of internal turmoil and in the face of natural disaster. It is at the forefront of a burgeoning industry—one which will significantly contribute to reducing the blow-out in our foreign debt. As I said earlier, it also has an exceptional safety record. Australians have a great deal of confidence and pride in their national carrier.

The Democrats remain philosophically opposed to wholesale privatisation and believe that excessive foreign control of our national icons is against the national interest. The passage of this Bill will mark a very sad day for Australia. When this Bill is passed—as I am sure the coalition is supporting it—the flying kangaroo may then be declared an endangered species.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising that Senator Coulter, in his closing remarks, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, claimed that the passage of the Qantas Sale Bill, which will result in the privatisation of Qantas, will mark a sad day. He said in his opening remarks, about 20 minutes ago, that government ownership of enterprises is equal to the people's ownership of those enterprises. I was not surprised to hear Senator Coulter say that, given the general philosophical position of the Democrats these days. But it was certainly surprising that he should try to raise that discredited old socialist theory in this debate about Qantas, because a theory is all that particular claim is.

PARA.TAB: Ownership of an enterprise implies a measure of control. Certainly, direct shareholders who have invested in a private company do have a measure of control over that company. To suggest that the Australian people, through government ownership, have the same measure of control over a government-owned business enterprise is patent nonsense. People elect a government to deal with a wide range of policy matters and issues, not simply to manage one particular government business enterprise which, according to the socialist theory which we have heard Senator Coulter espouse, the people, through that government ownership, own themselves.

There is a very tenuous link between the people and a government business enterprise through that government ownership. That is one very important reason why governments have no business running business enterprises. It is a very important reason why government business enterprises ought to be privatised. There are other reasons, such as matters of efficiency, competitiveness and access to capital for the growth of that enterprise. Certainly, there is no justification for governments continuing to own business enterprises in the modern era. Even the Government has recognised that fact and is now proceeding to privatise Qantas.

Six months ago the Keating Government announced that Qantas would purchase 100 per cent of Australian Airlines and that this newly merged airline of the previous two operators would be completely privatised with a 35 per cent foreign ownership limit. However, in the previous year, 1991, the Government had announced that only 49 per cent of Qantas and all of Australian Airlines would be sold separately well before the conclusion of this year. Under those provisions, neither airline could bid for the other. In February of this year, there was yet another announcement that the two airlines would be allowed to bid for each other, that Qantas would fly domestic routes and that other local airlines would fly international routes.

What is clear from this continually changing feast with respect to privatisation of Qantas in Australia is the Keating Government's complete inability to conduct even an elementary exercise in privatisation. It is a very interesting time for the airline industry in Australia—for governments, passengers and airlines. On the one hand, we are faced with substantial policy changes that were initiated in the One Nation statement and their presumed implementation, however slowly. On the other hand, we are faced with the forever changing effects within the international airline industry itself. Both of these factors will have a profound effect on Australia.

Australia's policy of multiple designation, which it has pursued in negotiations with bilateral aviation partners, has become accepted in most parts of the world. In tandem with this pursuit has been the achievement of significant capacity increases in major markets, providing scope for entry by Australian carriers. There is agreement with New Zealand for a freeing up of the trans-Tasman route so as to service foreign countries from the other host country, and Qantas has obtained direct entry to the domestic market through its unused seats on domestic sectors of international services. All of this has taken Australia to a position where the unusual barrier between Australia's inter-national and domestic air service markets appears to provide existing carriers with an opportunity for expansion. Of course, it is the disappearance of that pre-existing barrier that will allow a great expansion in air services in Australia.

As a consequence of those changes, we come to the legislation before us today, the Qantas Sale Bill 1992, which gives effect to what is apparently the final decision of this Government with regard to the current state of Australian aviation. Although the Liberal and National parties are not opposing this legislation, it does astound me that this Labor Government has taken so very long to take even this degree of action and that its path has been so circuitous. The way in which this sale has been delayed and its status changed is simply further testimony to this decaying Government's incapacity to manage not merely this issue but, of course, the broader issues of the Australian economy.

The sad history of this Government's aviation industry policy and of the entire Qantas privatisation approach is simply one which highlights dithering and decay on the part of this Government. Foreign companies that want to buy into Qantas are still attempting to obtain information on the company. Privatisation initiatives should have been undertaken years ago by this Government, not merely in recent months. The real tragedy is that the privatisation of Qantas did not come about in the early 1970s, as many coalition members have long advocated. As I said earlier, governments have no place running businesses and they have no place running airlines, particularly in the way in which this Labor Government has done by incurring massive debts and losses and harbouring monumental internal inefficiencies—in effect, keeping a massive failure in the air at taxpayers expense.

Since the 1970s enormous changes have taken place in the aviation industry worldwide. Qantas has been a member of the premier international group of airlines—those airlines which flew what were previously known as the Commonwealth routes. Arrangements existed between Qantas and the former BOAC. Air India and even South African Airways were also involved as well as some of the other major leaguers. What happened at that time was an eventual disintegration of these players and the emergence of the ASEAN airline carriers.

The Government was caught out at that time, just as it has been caught out all this time later. Undoubtedly something should have been done during the years of the Whitlam Government because that is when new approaches to aviation were taking place. No action was taken and as a result the fit and proper expansion of our international airline did not occur. Two years ago the Labor Party was frothing at the mouth about Qantas and privatisation; it was very uncomfortable and very much at sea with this big issue. That is why it took the Government so long to get its act together—and it is still not there yet.

The Labor Party privatisation debate centred on the outrage of selling the so-called `family silver'—Qantas was regarded as such—rather than getting to the basics and finding out exactly what went on within the company. Not only has this Government impaired our own Australian international airline through too many years of protection; as we only too sadly know, it has also plunged more than 11 per cent of Australians into unemployment through similar inaction in other areas of much needed and desperately needed micro-economic reform. As we know, this Government has all but sent Australia broke as a consequence.

In the past two years there have been massive and fundamental changes elsewhere, but nothing has changed adequately in Australia under the Hawke and then the Keating governments. With the collapse of communism in eastern Europe we have even seen huge sections of Russia's Aeroflot airline privatised. But only now after years of procrastination do we see this Labor Government finally getting around to privatising Qantas and organising a firm and distinctive policy on the matter. As with everything else this Government touches, the go-slow effect seems to prevail and there is very little progress.

The four most profitable world airlines do not include Qantas among them. British Airways, Singapore Airlines, Cathay Pacific and Thai International take the four top spots. It is British Airways, now fully privatised, which is making real inroads into the requirement to have a staff shareholding. This is something which a privatised Qantas must also reflect, because it is this very factor which in large measure has assisted British Airways to get where it is today. Employee participation in ownership and a wider distribution of shares in the airline will prove positive steps for the community and should be encouraged.

It is a major shortcoming of this legislation that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) has chosen not to enshrine within it a mechanism whereby employees could participate in the ownership of Qantas. It should be readily evident to any clear-thinking person that it is extremely important for employees to participate in ownership, because having part-ownership in the enterprise in which they work provides them with greater motivation. Singapore Airlines has taken initiatives in this area and is now in a similar position to that of British Airways, despite still having some government money in the airline. We all know how successful Singapore Airlines has been. Both Cathay Pacific and Thai International are well on the way to privatisation and also reflect strong and high profits.

The coalition supports this Bill in the sense that it is well past time for the Government to unbind Qantas from its protective wrappings and to set it up to compete fully and aggressively for a share in the world's air routes. The Prime Minister was hopeful in his One Nation document that both Australian and Ansett would be operating across the Tasman by 1993 at the latest. Well, 1993 is not too far away and I find it difficult to believe, with this Government's record on micro-economic reform, that we will see that claim eventuate before the next year is out.

It is hoped that with the passage of this Bill the Government will set a better example—after some futile attempts to establish an appropriate aviation network and after having left the aviation industry in such a degree of uncertainty, following its various changes in direction in recent years. Fundamentally, at least, the Bill addresses a number of national interest safeguards, including that the headquarters of Qantas and its operations will remain in Australia and that the Qantas name is to be reserved.

Let us hope that the Prime Minister does not want to change the name as he does our national flag or we might even see competitions in our schools to replace the flying kangaroo as well as the Australian flag. Our internationally recognised marsupial is one of Australia's best national treasures and must remain identified with Qantas if any semblance of our international identity is to endure in the industry.

The Bill provides for the company to be incorporated in Australia and for the chairman and two-thirds of the board to be Australian citizens. Total foreign ownership is not to exceed 35 per cent, which I believe is the internationally accepted limit.

There are three final points to which I wish to refer. The first is that it is shameful that one of our most important pieces of legislation relating to our international aviation industry has come to us through the guillotine in the other place. Such constraints of time not only diminish the importance of the legislation for the future of the industry in Australia, but also confirm what many in our community have long thought: a government which rams important pieces of legislation through the Parliament without proper time for detailed debate makes itself less worthy to remain in government.

Secondly, while it is important for airlines from Australia to have access to markets in other countries when we give airlines from those countries access to Australia, Qantas should not be able to prevent those airlines flying into Australia just because it does not wish to operate on a particular route. I particularly refer to the continuing failure of this Government to allow the establishment of a convenient air link between Australia and Chile. The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's relations with Latin America emphasised the importance of improving air links between Australia and South America. The Government has provided a favourable response to this Senate report, but, as it did with the Qantas sale, prevaricates and fudges when it comes to doing anything practical about its recommendations.

During my visit to Chile in July, I had discussions with LAN-Chile, which was extremely hopeful that a visit from Australian transport officials a week or so later would finalise agreement for services to begin; but agreement has still not been achieved. It is my advice that this is because Qantas does not wish to operate the Chile-Australia route but is insisting on unreasonable restrictions before agreeing that LAN-Chile can operate the route. I understand that Qantas is insisting in particular that LAN-Chile should agree to operate a direct flight from Santiago to Australia and not be allowed to pick up passengers at Easter Island or Tahiti.

This is an unreasonable, dog-in-the-manger attitude on the part of Qantas. If Qantas is not prepared to operate a service itself, a service which is very necessary to the development of Australia's trade and investment relations with Latin America, this Government should not acquiesce in its demands for restrictions on the operators of an airline such as LAN-Chile, which is prepared to take the commercial risk of developing a new route which will benefit Australia and Chile. The Government should immediately conclude an air services agreement with Chile which is satisfactory to LAN-Chile so that this urgently needed service can commence forthwith. The Government should not be doing the bidding of Qantas when Qantas is being unreasonable in its attitude.

Given that the Opposition will not be opposing the Bill, my third point concerns the completion of this privatisation process in as short a time as possible. It is, of course, not the intention to sell Qantas lock, stock and barrel to overseas interests, because foreign ownership must not exceed 35 per cent. What happens in terms of the capital raising for the privatisation if there are no overseas bidders or if we choose not to accept such overseas bidders as are offering?

Qantas has enjoyed 45 years in government hands, and I would say that very little, if any, of that time was invested in finding out just how much flying the kangaroo was doing or what it could do given different conditions and different management. Given the changes in the Government's policy on that matter, it will not be surprising if the sale remains unsettled well into next year. Given the Government's past record and sullied reputation on the speed of micro-economic reform, it will remain a prickly affair of control with regard to the Government selling Qantas.

As I said, it is important that this privatisation be completed as quickly as possible, but that is not likely to occur given the Government's mismanagement of this issue over an extended period. It has long been the policy of the Liberal and National parties to privatise Qantas and it is on that basis, despite the fact that the Government, we believe, has mismanaged this process, that we support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to contribute to the debate on the Qantas Sale Bill 1992, to support the Government's action and to join with my colleague Senator Chapman in pointing out some of the deficiencies in the Labor Government's privatisation programs over the last few years and the uncertainty that these have created around the sale of Qantas. The Government can be commended properly for finally, after a number of years, coming to a sensible sale arrangement. As Senator Chapman said, the destruction of the artificial barriers between domestic and international air traffic in Australia will be a benefit to consumers. We would expect the privatisation of Qantas to have major benefits to consumers and to Australia's potential to develop its tourism market.

PARA.TAB: A brief look at the Government's privatisation program over the last few years shows that the targets for the proceeds of the sales, which are usually announced around about Budget night, generally wither away quite disturbingly as we move towards the end of the financial year. One needs to question—perhaps the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) will respond at some stage to this—the quality of advice the Government is receiving on the value of its proceeds.

The first privatisation program of this Government was in 1988-89 when it forecast an income of $700m in that year from privatisation. The actual achievement was only $535m, a shortfall of 24 per cent. For the following year, 1989-90, it estimated $1.2 billion and achieved $1.068 billion, a shortfall of only 11 per cent. In the next year, 1990-91, it made a target of $1 billion and achieved only $162m, a shortfall of 84 per cent. In the last financial year, the Government made an estimation of proceeds of $625m and made the remarkable achievement of actually having a negative income—obviously due to costs incurred in relation to organising the privatisation of some of these things—of $302m, a shortfall of 148 per cent. I think this highlights the point made by Senator Chapman in relation to the quality of the privatisation program operated by the Hawke and Keating governments.

From my memory of the privatisation debate, in the early 1980s when the Liberal Party first proposed privatisation as a way of making Australia more efficient, creating jobs and creating the opportunity for people and employers to get involved in these enterprises, members of the Labor Party were very strident opponents of privatisation. That was only a few short years ago. I remember advertisements appearing on television around Australia with none other than Graham Kennedy saying that the Liberal Party was proposing to sell off the family jewels to pay for next week's groceries. Of course, it was only a few short years later—only two years, I think—that the Labor Party embraced the privatisation policies which the Liberal Party had been proposing for most of the last decade.

Although privatisation has become a popular policy in Australia in the last few years, a lot of people mistakenly think it was Margaret Thatcher or Ronald Reagan who invented privatisation. I remind the Senate that it was Adam Smith who, in book 5, chapter II, part 1 of The Wealth of Nations, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In every great monarchy of Europe the sale of the crown lands would produce a very large sum of money, which, if applied to the payment of the public debts, would deliver from mortgage a much greater revenue than any which those lands have ever afforded to the crown . . . When the crown lands had become private property, they would, in the course of a few years, become well improved and well cultivated.

So it is not a modern idea. I am sure that not even Adam Smith would claim responsibility for the idea of selling Crown assets to ensure that a country achieves greater prosperity for its citizens. But, indeed, it was Margaret Thatcher who pioneered many of the privatisation processes which Australia is just beginning to adopt now.

PARA.TAB: It is of great benefit to Australia that, even though we have dragged our heels somewhat on the privatisation process in relation to our trading partners, we can, of course, learn a lot from the mistakes made by the Thatcher Administration and privatisation in other parts of the world. As someone who has studied privatisation for most of the last 10 years, I can say that it will be of enormous benefit to this Government, and to a Hewson government when it is elected next year, to be able to draw on international advice and experience.

Because of Labor's flirtation with privatisation in the last few years, we have already seen in Australia the development of some significant support advice on privatisation in the merchant banking area and amongst stockbrokers, legal and accounting firms and even advertising and public relations firms. It has become a specialist area for most of these disciplines and, of course, that will help the privatisation programs of both the Government and the Liberal and National parties should we gain government next year.

One of the objectives of privatisation is, of course, how one devotes the proceeds from those privatisation sales. The Fightback package proposes realising $15 billion worth of sale proceeds in the next three years. I certainly hope that our estimations are more accurate than those of the Government. One of the things that the Opposition puts forward in Fightback, in contrast to the Government, is the use of those privatisation proceeds. We intend to use the proceeds from the privatisation sales to reduce public debt interest. We have estimated in Fightback that in the year 1993-94 that reduction would be $228m, in 1994-95 it would be $504m—over half a billion dollars—and it would be the same in 1995-96. In other words, in 1990-91 constant dollars, over a three-year period there would be a total effect on the Budget of $1.289 billion.

That is in stark contrast to this Government's record. It is extremely unlikely that we will be able to achieve the $1.6 billion target for privatisation, of which the Qantas sale package is obviously a crucial element. The $1.6 billion is an integral part of the Government's current year Budget. It is worth considering that Australia's social security expenditure for 1992-93 is estimated to be in the realm of $39 billion, or $105m a day. If the Government achieves its entire privatisation program and gets the $1.6 billion in the kitty by the end of the year, that will have the remarkable effect of paying for 15 days of welfare spending.

The money has already been spent. We are talking about how we can get these privatisation proceeds in. Most Australians would be horrified to know that we have to sell these national business enterprises and put the proceeds towards current year spending. The placing of those proceeds towards repatriation of public debt would be far more beneficial to every taxpayer in Australia and every future taxpayer.

The objectives of privatisation should always be to increase the opportunity for consumers and taxpayers to maximise their investment, as to whether they should buy a slice of Qantas, or as taxpayers in the role of consumers who choose to use a previous public enterprise. We want lower costs and better service. The other objective, which has been referred to by Senator MacGibbon, is to broaden share ownership and particularly to encourage employees to take a stake in the enterprise in which they are employed. As Senator MacGibbon quite properly said, when there is an enterprise with 10,000 or 12,000 people involved in it, it takes an enormous achievement to ensure that each one of those employees is working very hard to achieve corporate goals.

Those of us in this chamber who are some of the most frequent fliers in Australia know very well that the service a person is rendered on an aeroplane is a mix of many hundreds of people trying to ensure that the travel experience is a good one. If one link in that management travel service is bad, then that person's experience with the airline will be less than satisfactory and, because of the choice there is now, he or she will not fly with that airline again. That applies to ticketing; the way a person is treated in the transit lounge or in any other lounge; the seating arrangements; the way the meal is served; the way the baggage is handled; and the way a person is treated when leaving the airport and jumping into a taxi or bus—it involves the whole travel experience. When people are travelling internationally and they are very tired, worn out, angry and grumpy, they appreciate the higher service levels. As I said, every employee of an airline must pull his weight and be focused on the achievement of the goal, which for an airline should be delivering a worthwhile service and leaving customers with a happy experience. These matters were well canvassed by Jan Calzon, the head of Scandinavian Airlines, in his book about service and the value of customers to airlines.

We believe in privatisation. We support this Bill because we want to see expanded opportunities for the private sector, the free enterprise sector, and a reduction in the total size of government, which therefore ensures that the burden of taxes on citizens is lowered and that they can invest further money in productive enterprise. The important thing about the privatisation of Qantas is that it is pushed out into the market where, if it succeeds and can raise more capital, it will get bigger and flourish, provide better services and better returns to the shareholders. That is something that has not been achieved. I think speakers from all sides of the chamber—Senator Bruce Childs and his faction may disagree—would realise that over the last few years Qantas has been stymied by lack of investment capital. It is not fair that an airline with such a tremendous reputation should be shackled in that way. The sale of Qantas in the next few months will unclip its wings.

I want to look broadly at some of the benefits of privatisation to try to convince Senator Coulter—which is probably a waste of my time—that privatisation can have enormous benefits, particularly for low and middle income earners. Australia now has over a million people who do not have jobs. We have an enormous foreign debt. One of the worst attributes of that enormous foreign debt is that there is now a whole generation of Australians—I am not talking about just the younger generation but of people in their 40s and 50s who have lost their jobs and are having enormous difficulties getting back into the work force to look after and maintain their families—who cannot get their foot on the bottom rung of the ladder in our society.

These people wake up every morning with a terrible outlook because they cannot find a job and they do not know how they are going to progress in this world. They have all been to school, and some have been to university. In some cases they have had jobs. It is a terrible position for them to be in. I am sure that honourable senators on both sides of the chamber have been exposed to hundreds of people in these circumstances. We, as a parliament, must ensure, then, that we create a society where these people will have the opportunity to get their feet on the bottom rung of the ladder.

If we stick with the old notions of saying dogmatically and philosophically that we must maintain organisations such as Qantas under the ownership of government, we will not achieve this objective. One of the benefits for Australia in being one of the latecomers to privatisation activity is that it has been proven around the world that bodies that have been privatised have been able to achieve outstanding growth rates, outstanding success and outstanding increases in productivity. A study done by the World Bank, called The welfare consequences of selling public enterprise, which involved a very thorough analysis of 12 privatisations in four different countries—namely, Britain, Chile, Malaysia and Mexico—showed that the average annual net gains for GBEs was 26 per cent. The study concentrated entirely on non-privatisation aspects of the increase; in other words, it took away all the factors not directly attributable to privatisation in trying to assess the average annual net gains in productivity. The bank identified some key factors in regard to why these achievements were made: firstly, higher investment; secondly, managerial innovation; thirdly, better pricing of services; and, fourthly, a more productive work force.

I put it to the Australian Democrats and to the chamber that if privatisation in those four countries—as shown in this thorough study—has been able to achieve higher investment, managerial innovation, better pricing of services and a more productive work force, then it is very dog in the manger-ish, very negative and very reactionary to oppose the privatisation process when we know very well that Qantas can achieve all of those things for Australia. The sale of Qantas can help to increase the number of jobs and the number of international visitors coming to Australia. That will create positive benefits that it just cannot achieve, and has not been able to achieve, for Australia as a government owned enterprise.

Finally, the Government deserves congratulations for its reforms to airline businesses over the last few years. They have certainly been late in coming, but they have been most worth while. One of the matters which concerned me at the time that Compass Airlines came on the scene was the matter of having a deregulated sky but a highly regulated ground. As I said earlier, the travel business is not just what the cost of the plane fare is or what the schedule is; it relates to the total experience of people getting to the airport, into the lounge, into the plane, and so forth. If Australia is to develop its airline industry and its tourism industry, then it is very important that we have sensible arrangements on the ground. Those of us who have had the privilege of travelling internationally and then have had to transfer to a domestic flight in Australia know that we have a major problem; that is, when one lands at an international terminal and needs to get onto a domestic flight, in most capital cities, one has to travel a long distance, put one's baggage into a taxi or bus, and then travel across to another terminal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you tried Heathrow lately?
—Yes, I have.
—Or half a dozen other places I could nominate.

—That is right. Senator Bell and Senator Collins are reinforcing my point. If Australia wants to be internationally competitive in this area, we need to look at the problem of facilities on the ground. The Opposition proposes to privatise airports. We hope that that will be a positive step in ensuring that there is even more competition between ground services and that airlines have equal opportunities to access services on the ground. Furthermore, we hope to encourage infrastructure expenditure on the ground so that we can have sensible ground arrangements for national and international travellers, because one spends a lot of time on the ground when travelling internationally.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition will be supporting the Government's Bill. We congratulate the Government on bringing it forward. For Senator Coulter's sake, I make it known that the Opposition will not be supporting any of the Democrats amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Campbell and the other speakers in the debate for their contributions to it. I also reject any ideological dogmatism in respect of privatisation, but I reject it firmly both ways. Some industries are truly competitive and operations are clearly enhanced when businesses are run in private hands. I believe that the airline industry is one of those.

PARA.TAB: But privatisation is not the cure-all of everyone's problems, as the Opposition would have us believe. A contemporary example of that is the Federal Opposition's proposal to privatise our ports. Because of our demography, the enormous capital costs of our ports and the fact that they are widely dispersed, they are not able to truly compete. Ports in Europe, for example, can be truly competitive because they are closely spaced with not very great distances between them; if people do not like one port, they can go to the next.

The same approach is evidenced by the conservative Government in New South Wales rejecting the privatisation proposition. The New South Wales State Minister for Transport indicated that, as far as the New South Wales Government is concerned, there are far greater advantages for it in the corporatisation of its ports than having them sold. I agree that at this point in our history—I am not suggesting that it should be fixed in time—that is the case.

The same applies to our airports. I am not suggesting that some airports may not at some future time be improved by sale. For example, at some future time when the second Sydney airport is truly competitive with the existing airport in Sydney it may well be in the national interest to sell both airports. But as overseas experience has shown—and Canada is a classic example—this issue is not something to be dogmatically approached.

I believe that it is in the national interest in a real sense for Australia to have a very fine, up to date, modern network of airport infrastructure around the whole country. Our population is not entirely concentrated in Sydney and Melbourne. There are Australians who, thank goodness, choose to live elsewhere. They are assisted by having a modern airport infrastructure which, I have to say quite frankly—certainly in the case of isolated places such as Darwin—would not be able to be provided if it were operated entirely on a private basis. The magnificent airport terminal in Darwin—which I believe without question it is in the national interest to have at that gateway—will probably not be fully in the black for something like 10 years. So there is a place for public ownership, but I believe that airlines have gone well past it.

I do not want to prolong the debate, but I want to lay to rest one great myth that there is some great public benefit in the government owning an airline. There was once. There was a time when Australian Airlines regularly serviced ports which it would never have serviced had it been a private commercial concern. But those days are long gone. Australian Airlines currently services about a quarter of the ports that it serviced in the 1970s. Even since that quite recent time, it no longer services 75 per cent of the ports it serviced in those days. It has been operating as a commercial entity for a very long time.

Senator Campbell correctly alluded to the very discerning demands of frequent fliers. He is absolutely right: business travel is a very lucrative part of the operations of any airline. Frequent fliers often make their decisions about on which airlines they will travel on quite small differences. Senator Campbell might be very interested to know that recently I was shown a computer print-out of one major Australian airline's revenue in terms of passengers per kilometre travelled. Top of the list was yours truly. Senator Campbell may be interested to know that he was No. 2. It might be a combination of having young children and coming from a long way from Canberra.

I was somewhat puzzled by Senator Chapman's contribution. I know it is heresy to say this, but sometimes I have wondered whether taxpayers get full value for money for the fact-finding trips on which politicians, ever assiduous in making endless sacrifices in the public interest, are sent overseas. Senator Chapman puzzled me somewhat in belting me around the ears about the Government's failures in providing a direct link from Chile to Australia. He advised us that he in fact had been there as part of a parliamentary delegation. In advancing the interests of Chile and its aviation interests, he wanted me to institute direct flights between Lima and Australia. I was a bit puzzled by that, considering that Lima is the capital of Peru. Perhaps when we are in a position to advance the interests of Chile we will do so by providing flights from Santiago instead of the port that Senator Chapman wants us to service. Obviously Chile made a huge impact on him when he was there.

I refer to the extraordinary contribution made to the aviation debate by Senator Short, a senior coalition frontbencher, in a speech that he gave in Sydney to an aviation seminar when he laid down the coalition's aviation policy. I described that policy as being an open skies policy. It was pleasing to note that some Opposition speakers during this debate supported my position on this. I took some exception to this because I said that it was important for Australian governments to be mindful of the interests of our own carriers and to negotiate these extremely valuable rights on a reciprocal basis.

Senator Short then went on three dot points later to make the extraordinary statement that under a coalition government other Australian carriers would have the opportunity to service international routes but only if Qantas was given first right of refusal. I thought that was an extraordinary statement to make. We have established a commission independent of the Government that will determine how these routes are distributed. It is an extraordinary thing, on the one hand, to say one will have an open skies policy and, on the other hand, say three paragraphs later that one will allow only Australian carriers other than Qantas to service a route if Qantas does not want to do it and brushes the crumbs off the table. I reject that position completely. I actually tabled the page from Senator Short's speech where he said that.

In a public response a few days later—it is still to be clarified by the coalition—Senator Short took me to task and said that I had misinterpreted the coalition's policy; I am quoting from his press release if people think I am making this up. He said that I had totally misinterpreted the coalition's policy; it did not have an open skies policy at all; it had an open up the skies policy. The question of only providing for international carriers other than Qantas to be able to service routes—if Qantas does not want those routes—is still to be clarified by the coalition. I look forward to that clarification.

So far as other matters that were raised during the debate are concerned, including the important question of the revenue, I make it clear that the $1.6 billion in the Budget does not simply refer to revenue obtained from the sale of Qantas. It in fact refers to revenue obtained by the sale of a number of government assets of which Qantas is a part. I was pleased to hear Senator MacGibbon comment very strongly in support of an employee share scheme for the company. The Government fully intends that to happen; it will happen. Indeed, Senator MacGibbon has no doubt seen the small—but important—technical amendment circulated by the Government. It will be moved during the committee stage and is to expedite the employee share scheme so that it can go ahead without any complications at all.

Senator MacGibbon referred to the number of employees of the combined Qantas-Australian. He is correct in saying that it is a very large company. The combined total staff is currently about 27,000—it is very large. That is despite the very significant staff restructuring that has occurred in the past and is still occurring as we speak. It is extremely important to ensure that those employees get an opportunity on an equitable basis to be part of that arrangement. I have been advised that there is a letter waiting for me after this debate from the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) on that very subject. That is being advanced currently by negotiations between the Government and the company.

In respect of Senator Coulter's contributions about wanting 51 per cent of the company retained, I have to confess that it hurts me deeply to have to agree with Senator MacGibbon about anything, but I strongly support the comments he made in that respect. He is absolutely right about the problem of the 49 per cent sale. As the Minister who took this matter to Cabinet, it was not just a question of the revenue that was involved; it was simply good aviation policy. The problem with the 49 per cent is that it actually gave the worst of both worlds. As Senator MacGibbon correctly said, it would have depressed the sale price for that 49 per cent because potential investors would find an entity that still had a government majority operating in it to be an unattractive investment. The trouble is that it would have left us with the down side, that is, having sold 49 per cent, the Government—having a majority shareholding—would still be responsible for recapitalising the airline to get it to a reasonable debt equity ratio. In terms of getting that gearing ratio to something respectable such as 60 : 40, the problem is that we are talking about expenditure off the Budget.

With the greatest respect to the Australian Democrats, if they want to take that off the Budget we are talking of a figure of around $2 billion. Frankly, I have to say to them, unblushingly, that if it is a choice between building schools, hospitals, railways and roads, or putting $2 billion of public money into an airline to subsidise the smoked salmon up in first class, then I do not think that that is a particularly sensible way in which to spend that large a sum of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still comes from the community.

—That is highly debatable in terms of the overall public benefit—and that is the test—that comes from continued public ownership of an asset. As I said before, there are clear cases to be made for public ownership of assets. I have mentioned two during this debate. One was airport terminals. At this point in our development in Australia, under certain circumstances we need to maintain the impetus of getting tourists here and ensuring that they have an enjoyable stay while they are here. Senator Campbell was absolutely right about that. Most tourists who visit Australia want to visit more than one port. Although most of them do want to start at ports such as Sydney and Melbourne, they want to go elsewhere after that. I think ensuring that tourists have a national network of high quality major airports is assisted currently by continued public ownership of those assets.

PARA.TAB: But I do not suggest—and I made that clear—that that is something that is fixed in time. As this country develops, as our tourist industry becomes more advanced than it is now, and as these assets grow—and currently the Federal Airports Corporation has a fairly aggressive program of some $2 billion worth of new capitalisation of airport infrastructure already in train around Australia—then it may well be that that is assisted in particular situations by the kind of airline process that we are dealing with today. But in an open, competitive area which the airlines are in now, I believe that the public interest without question is being served by the legislation that is in front of us here today.

I indicate also, in response to something that Senator Campbell said about the Democrat amendments, that the Government will not be supporting these Democrat amendments. The balance that we have in the legislation that is currently before the Senate has been very carefully and painstakingly assessed and measured. We believe that it is the necessary foundation for a successful sale and successful future operation of this very important asset, and we will not be making the quite significant changes during the committee stage that these Democrat amendments would cause. I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate and for their support for the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments to be moved to this Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 7, page 5, after subclause (1) insert the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(1A) For the purposes of this section, a person has a relevant interest in a share if, and only if, the person would be taken because of Division 5 of Part 1.2 of the Corporations Law to have a relevant interest in the share if section 33 of that Law were disregarded.".

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 7, page 6, subclause (6), definition of `relevant interest', lines 27 and 28, omit the definition.
(3) Clause 9, page 7, after subclause (2) insert the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2A) For the purposes of this section, a person has a relevant interest in a share if, and only if, the person would be taken because of Division 5 of Part 1.2 of the Corporations Law to have a relevant interest in the share if section 33 of that Law were disregarded.".

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Clause 9, page 7, subclause (3), definition of `relevant interest', lines 24 and 25, omit the definition.

They are simple technical, but important, amendments. The amendments proposed by the Government relate to the definition of the term `relevant interest'. The Bill seeks to use the concept of relevant interest from the corporations law—that is, the definition—to trace foreign ownership and control through company chains. Thus Qantas shares would be classed as `foreign' if foreigners either directly or indirectly have control over the voting rights of those shares or the power to dispose of them. The relevant interest concept could be used to determine the level of foreign ownership and to ensure that it stays within the limits imposed by the Bill.

PARA.TAB: However, section 33 of the corporations law could result in a foreigner being deemed as having a relevant interest in Qantas shares held by a subsidiary of Qantas. In particular, the one we are thinking of would be a subsidiary that would be established to conduct an employee share ownership scheme. This would have the unintended effect of adding those shares held by Qantas subsidiaries—and in this case, of course, it would be by the Australian employees of Qantas—to the relevant interests of foreigners, thus inappropriately restricting the level of foreign ownership beyond that intended by the Bill. So, essentially, these amendments make the provision for the establishment of an employee ownership scheme without any unnecessary complications.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing the amendments moved by the Government.
—In briefly supporting these amendments, I would like to correct a comment that was made by the Minister in responding to my earlier remarks.
—Sorry, Grant—a cheap shot.

—The comment was, of course, a cheap political shot, which the Minister is entitled to make on these occasions. He did pick up a slip of the tongue on my part in my speech at the second reading stage when I referred to Lima instead of Santiago when talking about the urgent need for air links between Chile and Australia. I must admit the slip of the tongue occurred because, at the same time as I was thinking of the importance of these air links, I was also thinking of the importance of developing shipping links between Australia and South America, which are particularly relevant to Lima. These slips of the tongue do occur from time to time. It is undoubtedly the air link between Santiago and Australia which is urgently required. I note that although the Minister did pick up that slip of the tongue, he failed to address the substance of my argument, which is the delay which is occurring and the way Qantas is being allowed to ensure that that delay occurs.
