TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 7, page 4, paragraph (1)(a), line 17, omit "35%", substitute "20%".
2.Clause 7, page 4, paragraph (1)(b), line 22, omit "25%", substitute "10%".
3.Clause 7, page 4, paragraph (1)(c), line 28, omit "one-third", substitute "one-fifth".
4.Clause 7, page 5, paragraph (1)(i), line 15, omit "two-thirds", substitute "four-fifths".
5.Clause 7, page 5, subclause (3), line 27, omit "15%", substitute "5%".

These amendments deal with the extent of foreign ownership and the degree to which foreign investment might control Qantas. The first amendment to clause 7, paragraph (1)(a), seeks to substitute for the 35 per cent foreign investment a much lower limit of only 20 per cent. While we have just voted against the privatisation, we believe—and I think the arguments were well set out in my speech at the second reading stage—that a smaller level of foreign investment would be advantageous. I think that was also supported by the remarks made by Senator MacGibbon in relation to the desirability of encouraging more Australian investment and also, of course, investment by the staff of Qantas.

PARA.TAB: The second amendment is to paragraph (1)(b) of clause 7 and it seeks to reduce the maximum allowable investment of an individual foreign person from 25 per cent to 10 per cent. The justification of this—as was pointed out both by me and Senator MacGibbon—is that 25 per cent as a single shareholding is a very significant block and can essentially hold the rest of the company to ransom by the threat to withdraw that shareholding, to sell it or to manipulate it in some way. We support the idea of reducing that individual foreign investment from 25 per cent to 10 per cent.

The third amendment is to paragraph (1)(c) and it seeks to reduce the level of impact of foreign investment at the shareholder level. It reduces the proportion of a director's position for which substantial foreign shareholdings can vote from one-third to one-fifth. It reduces the impact at the board level from one-third to one-fifth, again attempting to limit the extent to which that 25 per cent shareholding by a single person and the 35 per cent shareholding by foreign investors can significantly affect the direction of the company.

The fourth amendment—which also relates to that level—to paragraph (1)(i) increases the proportion of directors who must be Australian citizens from two-thirds to four-fifths. Again, it attempts to redress the imbalance caused by that high 35 per cent foreign investment shareholding and the 25 per cent by one foreign investor so that the influence is reduced at the board level.

Finally, the fifth amendment to subclause (3) seeks to reduce the minimum foreign shareholding which is defined as substantial from 15 per cent to 5 per cent for the purposes of determining the maximum proportion of directors' positions which such shareholdings can vote for.

These amendments are all related. They attempt to reduce the influence of foreign shareholding of individuals and foreign shareholding as a whole by affecting the percentage of foreign shareholding, the percentage which an individual person can hold and the impact of that foreign shareholding at the board level, so that the influence over the national carrier, Qantas, remains substantially Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is sympathetic to the views expressed by Senator Coulter on behalf of the Australian Democrats but, regrettably, they are not practical and we will be opposing the amendments which are before the Committee. I would like to take a few minutes to explain why they are not practical.

PARA.TAB: Earlier the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, said that it would cost $2 billion to refinance Qantas. I will not enter into a debate about that, but my memory goes back to 1988 when Senator Gareth Evans was in that ministerial portfolio. I thought the figure that Senator Evans was bandying about then was $5 billion. My memory may be wrong but, on the balance of probabilities—Senator Evans is sometimes a little erratic with figures—maybe he did use that figure.

But the point is that a great deal of money is needed to make it an efficient and effective company and we simply cannot afford it. So we come down to the business of having to sell the airline. I do not have any difficulty with selling the airline to private interests but, as I said in my speech, the quantity of overseas ownership is something we have to think about very carefully.

The advice that we have had, and a large part of it comes from the bureaucracy and the Government, is that a 25 per cent holding in one overseas block is the minimal figure that we can have in today's climate. I would accept that. There is enough evidence around that some overseas interests would be quite happy to buy 100 per cent. Fortunately, that is not before us. If we were proposing to sell 100 per cent of the airline, we would lose all those traffic rights which are so valuable and which Senator Collins talks about, and it would no longer be an Australian airline.

Furthermore, the nation would be bereft of an essential component in its independence. We would lose the independence of an Australian airline. As a by-line, such a sale would be politically unsaleable in my own State of Queensland, not only in the outback areas but in Queensland itself. When the idea was around that the Government might sell 100 per cent of the airline, the protests from the general public were enormous. If I could be allowed a moment of levity, I am sorry that the Government did not proceed with that because we would certainly have got a great deal of political mileage out of it.

The advantage with having an overseas shareholding is that it will provide, particularly if it is a major airline, essential strategic links. Most travel around the world now involves multiple ports of call for a traveller. The ability to plan that trip by getting access to a worldwide computer net and to make onward bookings is absolutely critical. A company can no longer operate in one nation and be able to provide an efficient travel service; it needs to have access to the resources of another company. That is what this 25 per cent holding will provide for Qantas. The other thing is that, if Qantas is in association with what must be one of the major airlines of the world to take up that 25 per cent holding, it would expect to receive quite a flow-on of traffic from that airline. Since it would have a financial interest in Qantas, presumably it would provide a preferential pathway for its bookings.

Australia needs not only the profits from the sale in this country but also the invisible earnings of maintaining an Australian airline. I think the invisible earnings from Qantas would be at least $2 billion to $3 billion a year, and if the airline is run in a better and more efficient way—as I am quite sure it will be as a private enterprise—those profits to the Australian nation will be commensurately larger.

One of the fallacies of the argument advanced by the Democrats this afternoon is the assumption that there will be no more profitability from a privately owned airline than from a government owned airline. I would differ from that very greatly. I well remember a conversation I had with one of the chairmen of Qantas in the immediate past, who came to the company with a long and successful experience in private industry. I will not mention his name, but I said to him in private, `What's it like running Qantas?'. He said, `You know, David, the big difference between Qantas and what I did before is the fact that there are no hungry shareholders. There is no pressure on me at all to perform. There is no pressure on the Qantas board to perform'. That is one of the realities of commercial life. There are not the pressures on a government business enterprise that exist in the straight commercial world.

I hope that, when we have the overseas shareholding in the company, the public benefactions in the national interest that have come from Qantas are not in any way diminished I am mindful that it was Qantas that really started the Flying Doctor Service. The friendship between Hudson Fysh, Fergus McMaster and John Flynn, who was a Presbyterian minister in western Queensland, led to the formation of the first emergency health services in the western part of Queensland. In 1927—a few years after Qantas started—Qantas provided the aircraft for the first Flying Doctor Service. That was as a private company. It was really a great public benefaction.

While I am on the same vein, it would be wrong to confine that public benefaction to only a private company. After the Second World War when Trans Australia Airlines was formed—the predecessor of Australian Airlines, which is now totally owned by Qantas—the support that TAA gave the Royal Flying Doctor Service, as it was then, was really quite considerable. It provided much of the maintenance support for the aircraft. The public commitment that both Australian Airlines and Qantas have made to the good of the Australian community is quite considerable. I hope that the injection of overseas shareholding in the company does not diminish that in any way for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting these amendments for the reasons already stated by Senator MacGibbon. As would most Australians, I would prefer to have all our major investments entirely in the hands of Australian entrepreneurs and entirely financed by Australian institutions. Regrettably, we do not live in that perfect world. It is important to access foreign investment in our aviation and tourism industries, firstly, to provide the equity, which we often cannot raise domestically, and, secondly, to provide those important links in international business which knows no borders in terms of the lines that are drawn on a map these days.

PARA.TAB: Our tourism industry has never been more important than it is to this country at this time and it is growing rapidly. In the year before last, tourism earned for Australia something in excess of $7 billion in foreign exchange. In the year just past, for which statistics were produced only last week, foreign exchange earnings from tourism in Australia exceeded $8 billion a year. Some 11 per cent of the total economic activity in Australia has been produced from the tourism industry.

Last year, international tourist visitation to Australia increased by over 13 per cent. This is in the face of depressed international conditions in many other parts of the world. Australia is ever more seen as an attractive destination. Domestic aviation numbers have increased by 18 per cent over last year. One very exciting statistic on our domestic deregulation, which impacts on the Australian operations of this combined entity for which we are processing this legislation, shows that prior to deregulation some 21 per cent of Australians travelled interstate by air. That figure has leapt from 21 per cent to 37 per cent. That is close to 40 per cent; it has almost doubled since deregulation. So the benefits of these changes are tangible; they are currently flowing through to the Australian economy and, in particular, to ordinary Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That consideration of the committee stages of the Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1992 and associated bills in committee of the whole after the second readings of the bills be an order of the day for the sitting day next occurring after the day on which the High Court gives its judgment in relation to section 3 of the Migration Amendment Act 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this is a most reasonable proposal. I am proposing that the committee stage consideration of the Migration Laws Amendment Bill and associated Bills be postponed until after the High Court brings down its decision tomorrow. I am not proposing, as I would like to have done, that the second reading stage be put off. A number of honourable senators have prepared their speeches and are willing to make them today. Also, some honourable senators who want to make speeches on Bills that will be called on after this package of Bills has been dealt with may have been disadvantaged had a motion to defer the second reading stage been successful. In that sense, my proposal is reasonable and has regard to the convenience of all honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: I believe that it is even more reasonable for the Senate to defer the committee stage of the Bills until the High Court delivers judgment on questions which these Bills deal with. In Lim v. the Commonwealth the High Court has been considering a claim by Lim, on behalf of a number of Cambodian refugees, which challenges portions of the Migration Act that relate to refugees, particularly those portions which relate to mandatory detention.

The Bills that are currently before us, particularly the Migration Reform Bill 1992, go to that part of the Migration Act. In those circumstances, it would be reasonable for the Senate to defer consideration of the committee stage until the judgment of the High Court has been delivered. It may be argued that the High Court will indicate its disapproval of those sections of the legislation which mandate detention in a discriminatory manner. There again, it might be said that the Bills currently before us seek to remove that problem.

As I will be indicating later in the debate, the problem is that a more serious question may arise. The question goes to lawfulness and whether the individuals have been lawfully detained. As I understand it, this legislation seeks to identify a class of people and determine that detention as lawful under those circumstances, thus seeking to remove considerations of the provisions of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

I am really going to the heart of the legislation which I do not want to do. I simply want to speak to this proposition. The case, which has been heard and upon which a judgment will be made tomorrow, arose out of the decisions of the Parliament when it last considered the migration legislation. I and a number of other senators vigorously opposed section 54S, which has been appealed against. Section 54S of the Migration Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: A court is not to order the release from custody of a designated person.

When was this legislation decided? It was decided on a day in May. It was rushed through the House of Representatives and through the Senate on one day—the day before the Cambodians were to appear before the Federal Court seeking their release from detention pending the outcome of their applications for refugee status. These people were denied their day in court. Had the Government listened to me and other senators, it would not have found itself before the Federal Court because it may have more properly considered the legislation on that occasion and not rushed it through.

PARA.TAB: I believe that it is now unreasonable to refuse again to listen to what the High Court may say. It is unreasonable to refuse to listen to what others might say following the High Court decision. It would indicate to me that those who vote against this motion have a closed mind on this matter, and my concern is that too many people have a closed mind about refugees. They tar them with the same brush. They think that there is an enormous problem out there; whereas in fact of all the refugee status seekers, there have been fewer than 500 boat people. But the public has been given the impression by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) and some others that there are hundreds of boats out there between here and China and Cambodia being swept down by trade winds or something else and we are about to be overburdened by the rush of asylum seekers.

What Mr Justice Einfeld has stated should be heeded. No-one in this chamber would question Mr Justice Einfeld's competency when it comes to refugees or when it comes to human rights. He said that Australia's treatment of refugees is a matter of national shame. I also say that it is a matter of national shame. I believe that the Govern-ment's treatment and administration of the issue of refugees are disgraceful. It is callous, it is uncivilised, and it is bordering on the barbaric.

Tonight we heard on SBS another person who had been working for the Department at Villawood saying quite intentionally that it was a deliberate policy to keep these people in detention and to make them snap, so that when they returned to their country of origin they would be a walking advertisement to discourage further departures for Australia. A senior officer of the Department also appeared on television and stated that, when it came to refugees, the Department had a culture of rejection. That is a matter of national shame. When people who raise this concern are branded by the Minister as headline seekers, to me, that indicates a closed mind. It indicates an unreasonable attitude; certainly not a caring and compassionate one.

Those Cambodians have been here for more than three years. They have been locked up—in detention—suffering enormous psychological damage. Anyone who has seen the film The Killing Fields will have got a glimpse of the enormous trauma that people in Cambodia suffered. Those of us who have studied the issue further will recognise the extraordinary problems faced by these people.

To say, as the Minister has, that the boat people are queue-jumpers is absolutely false. Are Cambodians queue-jumpers? What do honourable senators think queue-jumping means? Queue-jumping means that people do not go through the normal processes; they do not apply to the Australian Embassy in their own territory or country for entry into Australia. To say that Cambodians are queue-jumpers is a nonsense. It is a legal nonsense as well because at the time of their departure,

SPEECH.PARA: and for some years before that, Australia had no representatives in Phnom Penh. It did not recognise Democratic Kampuchea, as it was called. Are these people queue-jumpers? They had no facility to seek entry into Australia. They are refugees.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday I took the opportunity to visit Villawood and I was concerned to see the effect of long term detention on these people. It was absolutely disgraceful. They are fed, they are clothed—not by the Department but by charity organisations, and the St Vincent de Paul Society was there—and they are housed. They are in detention with tall wire fences around them and are not able to get out. They are changed from one location to another. They came from Melbourne to Sydney. They were woken up early in the morning and they had two hours to leave Melbourne. Is that the action of a compassionate government?

I want to hear what the High Court has to say. It might not say anything, but it will make a judgment in respect of the last lot of laws that we passed and which I and a number of other senators opposed. Nobody opposed it in the House of Representatives, but here at least we did oppose it, and we did hold the matter up for a while. The legislation went through the Parliament so quickly that, prior to the legislation being determined, the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was unable to give us the benefit of its deliberation. I notice that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, in its seventh report after the passage of the Bills, took the extraordinary measure of commenting on this legislation, which is the subject of the High Court challenge to be determined tomorrow.Of the legislation which was passed in this chamber and the House of Representatives, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: The combined effect of new paragraph 54R(3)(e) and section 54S is that a `designated person' is effectively denied access to the courts for the purposes of determining whether or not they should continue to be detained. This may be considered to be contrary to Article 9, paragraph 4 of the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights, which provides:

Anyone who is deprived of his liberty by arrest or detention shall be entitled to take proceedings before a court, in order that that court may decide without delay on the lawfulness of his detention and order his release if the detention is not lawful.
It may also be contrary to Article 10, paragraph 1, which provides:
All persons deprived of their liberty shall be treated with humanity and with respect for the inherent dignity of the human person.
The provisions may also be contrary to Article 14, paragraph 1, which provides, in part:
All persons shall be equal before courts and tribunals.

I will not go into the general comments. They are there for everybody to examine on pages 128, 129 and 130. These are the issues which the court is considering and will be determining at 10.30 tomorrow morning.

PARA.TAB: Our nation's record of social justice is tested by our attitude and treatment of those least able to defend themselves. In Australia at present they are the refugees who have fled from persecution and who have a well-grounded fear that if they are returned they will suffer persecution. I raised in the Senate Estimates Committee, and I think Senator Chamarette raised it the other day as well, the question of what guarantees the Government had got from the PRC Government dealing with the Chinese who were forcibly deported by this Government from Port Hedland. It has not said so, but I know what the guarantees are because I have seen the decision of the PRC Central Council of, I think, 12 August, which was well-sounding. Two days later we sent one Chinese student there from Villawood and he was bunged in the slammer immediately, although he is out now.

The seven people who were deported forcibly from Port Hedland, including a 15-year-old boy, after having gone through enormous problems and enormous torment, are now languishing in torment in a Chinese gaol, and have been since their return. I know that, and I will tell honourable senators later how I know it. I believe that we should pass this motion, as all it does is to say, `Let us listen to what the High Court says about a matter with which this Bill deals. Let us hear what it may have to say about the administration by Australia of the laws relating to refugees'. What is wrong with that? All I am asking the Government for is 24 hours. What reasonable person would refuse that request in an important matter such as this?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has given a very rhetorical speech in which he has accused, for example, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) and the Government of having a closed mind in relation to certain persons who have been detained, and some of whom have been removed from Australia. Quite consistently throughout his address he spoke of such persons as `refugees'. In other words, Senator Harradine made the determination without any scrutiny of the individual claims of the persons concerned. He has come to his own conclusion—which speaks to me of a closed mind—in relation to this matter, rather than there being an individual scrutiny of the particular cases of the persons who have arrived on Australia's shores in an unheralded manner.

PARA.TAB: He also has accused the Government of deliberately pursuing a policy of psychiatrically wounding these people by the means and process of detention within Australia so that they will return to their homelands as, I think he said, walking advertisements for the sort of treatment they might expect in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not me who said that. That was a departmental—

—Senator Harradine read it and adopted it for the purposes of his address to this chamber. It is an unfair and untrue reflection on both the Department and the policy of the Government. Senator Harradine spoke of people approaching this matter with a closed mind, but I believe that he has brought forward some evidence of the same malady which is the subject of his accusation.

PARA.TAB: I return to the core of the matter that Senator Harradine has brought to the attention of the chamber. Tonight we are engaging in a parliamentary activity as the legislators of the Commonwealth of Australia who are elected by the people. In this case we are trying to deal with the difficult question of the arrival of persons into Australia who do not have any lawful right to be here—I put to one side whether they can subsequently claim refugee status and have that claim recognised—and are without any of the normal visas and so on which characterise most people who come here.

The question is how we deal with these people: what sort of review process they are to be allowed to participate in in order to ensure that their cases are fairly scrutinised; what sort of detention they may be subject to; and what sort of removal process they might then be subject to if their particular claims to stay in Australia are not regarded as substantiated by the merit review process which is to be provided. In other words, we are looking to create a new statutory scheme to deal with these matters that, I remind honourable senators, will come into operation later next year—not immediately, not within a few weeks and not even within a few months.

The High Court will be making its decision on the basis of the current statute. It may be that it will come to a decision that is adverse to certain sections within that statute. If it does, the status and future of the persons concerned will be determined according to the current statute over the next few days, weeks and months. Nothing we do tonight to substitute a completely new regime to operate from later next year will affect the way in which the High Court's decision is given weight and has consequences from tomorrow onwards.

I believe that we are in a position tonight—unlike last time, when Senator Harradine's castigation of the process through the Parliament may have had some substance—to deliberate upon and consider in a fair way whether to support the policy behind the Migration Laws Amendment Bill and associated Bills. What the High Court says about the present Act is really irrelevant to our consideration of putting in place a completely different regime which will displace that from later next year.

So I believe that we can go ahead in good conscience and good faith tonight. We can act as a parliament and let the High Court do its work in relation to the present Act. Consequences will flow from its decision tomorrow, but not in a way which can fundamentally affect our consideration of the proper policy to embody in the statute law of Australia tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the motion moved by Senator Harradine. The case before the High Court, Lim v. the Commonwealth, challenges the provisions that were passed by parliament in May this year. I was one of the senators, backed by the Australian Democrats as a party, who strongly opposed the Parliament's intervention, in a court case then proceeding, in a way which gave a direct instruction to the court to find in a particular way. The court could not address the substance of the question as to whether people should be detained. It was simply directed by that legislation to find in a particular way.

PARA.TAB: At the time that amending legislation created a different class of persons—persons who do not have the same legal rights as every citizen of Australia and, for that matter, the world; that is, they do not have equality before the courts which judge his or her behaviour or which make decisions on his or her fate.

If parliament in May of this year had not passed that legislation, we would now not be faced with this particular case and the judgment that the High Court will hand down tomorrow. That legislation forms the basis of the law as it stands in decisions on asylum seekers and whether they are allowed to remain even on a provisional visa or are to be detained and deported. The amendments that are now before us will be affected by that High Court judgment, which is due to be handed down tomorrow, because that judgment will affect the very basis of the legislation as it stands, which we propose to amend tonight. It almost sounds like a re-run of what happened in May.

May I also say very briefly, because I believe the substance of the amendments will and should be dealt with later, that the number of people we are dealing with is small—fewer than 500 in four years. Yet the Government is prepared to pass legislation to `protect' Australia against such people through means which affect a very basic principle of universal justice, namely, that all people deserve equality before the courts of whichever country they happen to be in which determine their fate. On this basis, the Australian Democrats strongly support the proposition that consideration of this Bill be deferred after the second reading debate to enable the Parliament to take account of the High Court judgment to be delivered tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on behalf of the Opposition. The legislation that was before us earlier this year was supported by the Opposition as we believe that it is important that the people of Australia's interest in a sound immigration process and a refugee determination process be just, careful and, after due process, followed through. Similarly, shortly this evening the Opposition will be supporting the Migration Laws Amendment Bill and associated Bills, which are the subject of this procedural motion. We do not believe that this is the time to be in any way soft or weakening in representing the interests of the Australian people in the determination of illegal entry into Australia of persons who are not bona fide refugees being able by some mere compassion to remain in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I listened very carefully to Senator Harradine's speech and Senator Spindler's remarks. I note that they voted against the majority of this Senate, and against the majority of the Parliament in the adoption of the original law. It may be the case that they will put contrary arguments when we debate the migration legislation before us this evening.

I do not believe there is any reason for delay in the Senate's determination of the Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1992 and allied Bills, which are before us. However, two Bills are separate from the matters which are before us now—that is, matters relating to the adult migrant education program—and there happens to be considerable interest in a briefing which will occur tomorrow. It is for that reason only that I expect the Government will initiate a delay of the committee stages of two of the Bills which are before us tonight.

With regard to the Bill which is the subject of Senator Harradine's motion, I am not convinced by the arguments which have been put that there is a delay. Senator Harradine has asked for one day more, and I hear his plea very clearly. But in fact the terms of the motion ask for consideration the day after the High Court hands down its judgment. For all we know, there may be some slippage and we in the Opposition make it entirely clear to the Senate that we support the Government in the clarification of the law in regard to the detention of persons and the process for determining refugee status. It is for these reasons that the Opposition will be opposing the procedural motion that is before us.

Nevertheless, I take this opportunity to agree with that part of Senator Harradine's remarks with which I believe the great majority of Australians, and indeed international observers, would agree concerning the deplorable record of this Government in the handling of those illegal immigrants who have arrived in this country by boat and who are subject to the process of determining their refugee status. Hundreds of illegal immigrants in this country have been detained behind barbed wire for more than three years. It is totally inadequate for the Labor Government to excuse the accusations that are made—some just, some exaggerated—about the denial of these persons' human rights.

It is intolerable to the Opposition that persons who arrive here illegally do not have the determination of their status within six months or, at the most, 12 months. But it has been more than three years. I regard that as a failure of government administration and, as has become apparent, a failure to ensure that the law is of such clarity that these matters can be determined justly and fairly on the basis of evidence and with proper representation—and determined within a reasonable period.

I draw attention to two articles which appeared in the Australian of last Thursday, 3 December. One was written by Jennifer McAsey and the other by Greg Sheridan. I have already brought these articles to the attention of officers advising the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) who are in the chamber tonight. I ask that the allegations which are made in these two articles be answered by the Minister, point by point. These two articles give a description of the deplorable inadequacy of the handling of more than 300 persons who have arrived in Australia illegally. I will quote a few paragraphs of Jennifer McAsey's article, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: They were to spend the next five months there. `We had to sleep on the floor without a mattress,' Cong Binh says. `We were not allowed to use the telephone, and if we wrote to our family our letters were opened. It was very hot, and often there was no special food for the baby.'

PARA.TAB: They saw no lawyers for nine months, no welfare workers; their applications for refugee status were filled out with the help of an interpreter and camp security guards.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an uncorroborated article. I would regard it as inexcusable that, in Australia in the 1990s, baby food was not available for babies or that people had to sleep on the bare floor for months without a bed or at least a mattress. I do not believe, on face value, that this is the full story in relation to these boat people in Australia. But I ask the Minister that, for the benefit of the Senate and for the benefit of the entire public of Australia, there be some refutation if it can be made out. To the extent it will not be refuted, it is all the more condemning of this Government and its total inadequacy. I conclude by confirming that, whilst the Opposition is entirely critical of the Government's behaviour in the handling of this process, no case has been made out for any delay in this legislation, and we do not support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Harradine's procedural motion. I will speak only briefly on this matter as I intend speaking later during the second reading debate. The reason I support Senator Harradine's motion is twofold. Firstly, as was mentioned by Senator Spindler, this situation smacks too much of an earlier deliberation we had in this very chamber in which we pre-empted a High Court appeal. I think the previously debated Migration Amendment Bill 1992 which pre-empted the appeal to the High Court cast a shadow over this chamber. As Senator Harradine said earlier, the rushing through of the legislation deprived a particular group of people of their day in court and also contravened the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

PARA.TAB: I was glad to see that Senator Tate did not like the accusation of closed minds being made. A way of refuting that is very simple: just a delay of 24 hours, which would allow us to take into consideration the decision that may be brought down in the Federal challenge, is one way of establishing that we do have open minds. Senator Tate said that nothing we do tonight will affect the High Court decision. That may well be so, but it is not the same as saying that what the High Court says about the present Act has nothing to teach us, in light of the mistakes that we made earlier. We cannot act in good faith by acting precipitately once again.

My second reason for supporting Senator Harradine's motion is that it is relevant to this particular legislation. This legislation involves the consideration of mandatory provisions. Any consideration of mandatory provisions necessarily moves outside judicial discretion and threatens access to due process. Because the legislation we are dealing with tonight involves such mandatory provisions, we again place ourselves in jeopardy of contravening our duty in relation to the judicial process and international covenants.

I conclude by adding my support for, and urging honourable senators to give due consideration to, Senator Harradine's motion. It is all very well for Senator Teague to talk in a very concerned manner about the human rights of people detained in custody for years, but I ask him to remember that it was this Parliament that actually pre-empted the appeal of some of those very people who were detained for years awaiting completion of the processing of their refugee status application, depriving them of the right to natural justice and the ability to remove themselves from the dreadful conditions he talked about. I urge all coalition senators to join him and to defer the final consideration of this legislation until after the High Court challenge, as Senator Harradine has proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will be very brief in closing the debate. I have heard no valid reason to reject this most reasonable proposal. I will summarise Senator Tate's reasons for opposing it. They appear to be three-fold, two of which were given in response to my initial contribution. He said, first, that I had a closed mind because I called people refugees. He seems to be under the impression that a refugee is not a refugee until that person has been granted refugee status and has been recognised as such.
—Of course. We are dealing with the law, not with assertion.

—Senator Tate does not understand, nor does he realise, what is contained in the United Nations convention relating to the status of refugees. The UN convention uses the term `refugees' in the same manner that I used it. Part one of the Handbook on procedures and criteria for determining refugee status, which is headed `Criteria for the Determination of Refugee Status', states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person is a refugee within the meaning of the 1951 Convention as soon as he fulfils the criteria contained in the definition . . . Recognition of his refugee status does not therefore make him a refugee but declares him to be one. He does not become a refugee because of recognition, but is recognized because he is a refugee.

The definition is quite clear; it relates to the person's well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, et cetera. In the mind of that person, he is a refugee. This is one of the problems that the Government has with this matter. It deems every one of those people to be guilty until they can prove somehow that they are innocent. That is a real problem. In my view, that is a contravention of our obligations under this convention.

PARA.TAB: For the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to say that I have a closed mind simply because I used the title `refugee' in the same manner as the UN convention uses it, shows the ignorance and the closed mind of the Government in this respect. These people are called queue-jumpers—I have said that it is tragic to call them that—and rorters. The Minister's own departmental official said on television that there is racism in the Department, that all Chinese are liars—no Chinese tells the truth, and that Bangladesh has no refugees. The Minister should look at the transcript of the SBS program.

The second reason Senator Tate opposed my motion is that I accused the Department of carrying on a deliberate policy to make people snap `so when they return they would be walking advertisements to discourage further departures from Australia'. I did not say that. I quoted what an officer contracted by the Department of Immigration, Mr Andrew Biro, said tonight over SBS news. If the Minister had listened to the SBS news, he would have seen that that is precisely what he said.

The final statement that Senator Tate made against my reasonable proposition was that the legislation with which we are dealing does not come into effect until next year. I thank Senator Spindler, of the Democrats, and Senator Chamarette, who both dealt with that matter. If it is not proposed that it come into effect until next year, what is the reason for so vigorously opposing my motion, which simply proposes to delay consideration at the committee stage until the High Court delivers its judgment tomorrow?

Senator Spindler, Senator Chamarette and I might have the last laugh in that perhaps the High Court will deliver a judgment which rules the legislation which we opposed and which the Government adopted last time this matter was before the Parliament to be unconstitutional or ultra vires the obligations of Australia in respect of the UNHCR or the ICCPR. Perhaps the judgment will also say something about this Government's deplorable human rights record when it comes to the question of refugees. But that is not why I wanted the delay; I wanted it so that we would be able to consider what the Court has to say. The Court may or may not say what I have indicated, but at least let us see what it says.

I am very disappointed that the Opposition is not supporting my motion. Senator Teague gave two reasons. First he said that the Opposition was not going to begin to be soft or weakened in its attitudes to illegal immigrants. That is not the issue here. Clearly, there must be fair, due process. Everyone realises that. Those who have spoken in favour of my motion realise that as much as anybody else. We realise the need for fair, due process and proper consideration of refugee status applications—indeed, of all immigration applications—in order to prevent queue jumping, et cetera. We agree with what Senator Teague said about that, but I cannot understand why that is an argument for opposing this quite reasonable proposition.

The second and only other argument adduced by Senator Teague was in relation to the words `be an order of the day for the sitting day next occurring after the day on which the High Court gives its judgment'. I am quite happy to seek leave to amend my motion to read, `for the next sitting day' which will be the day the High Court delivers its judgment. As I understand it, the High Court will be doing so at a quarter past 10 tomorrow morning.

I therefore seek leave to amend my motion by deleting the words `for the sitting day next occurring after the day on which the High Court gives its judgment in relation to section 3 of the Migration Act 1992' and substituting the words `for the next day of sitting'.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that is my last attempt to gain some reasonable support for this proposition. I commend the motion to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1992 and five associated Bills, which are all significant. All of them have been very carefully determined by the Government in consultation with representatives of the parliamentary parties, including my colleague the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, Mr Phillip Ruddock. There has been careful consultation in the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I will be raising a number of specific matters with regard to each of the six Bills, the Opposition will not be opposing the second reading of any of the six Bills. However, I make it entirely clear that the Opposition has no confidence in this Government's ability to maximise the Australian people's confidence in immigration programs in this country. We need a change of government in this country, not least to ensure that, with the precise policies of the Liberal and National parties, the Australian people's confidence in the immigration policies of the Government of Australia will be regained.

Under Labor we have been let down very badly by a succession of Ministers. Let me refer to the continual amendments of legislation that have come before the Parliament in recent years. Firstly, I was a member of the original committee on migration regulations of this Parliament and over several years have spoken for the Opposition on migration legislation before the Senate. In every speech, I have noted the inadequacies of the Government in putting together legislation that can stand and be sound and stable. We have had amendment upon amendment upon amendment all reacting to the failures of this Government.

Secondly, erratic decisions have been made by the Labor Government. The most notorious of these was the decision made emotionally and subjectively by the Prime Minister at that time, Mr Hawke, when he exempted what turned out to be 40,000 students from China to enable them to stay in Australia for four years, virtually indefinitely, without a clear definition of their status in Australia. We argued that that decision should never have been made. I still believe that the decision was made without consultation by the Prime Minister over the head of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs at that time, Senator Robert Ray. That sort of erratic decision has blown apart the integrity of Australia's immigration process.

I believe that those cases should still be determined on merit case by case. Of course, where after due process there is a case for refugee determination the refugee should be allowed to stay, but I still fully expect three-quarters—even more—of those students to return to China and serve their own country. We should not give a special advantage to the people of one nation.

Thirdly, the Labor Government has exercised inadequate control, taken the easy options and adopted wrongly balanced immigration policies. I have frequently pointed out to the Senate the Government's inadequate control of the entire migration program and the undermining of the integrity of the program that this has meant.

Fourthly—and we have just touched upon this area—the Government has failed in relation to illegal entrance to Australia. There have been intolerable delays in refugee determination, especially with regard to the boat people. This period will go down as a black mark on Australia's immigration policies and administration. Some people have been behind barbed wire for more than three years. Surely we can have a sensible, lawful and due process that is just, that considers evidence and that reaches determination after six months or, at the most, 12 months.

I stand apart entirely from this episode of Australia's history. As an Opposition senator, I am not responsible for the Labor Government's failure to achieve determined status for the refugee applicants amongst the up to 400 boat people who have arrived on our shores over the last several years. It is only this year that the Government has put in place laws that will enable a more definitive process. It is too late; it is too slow. The Australian people condemn the Government. We have put Australia's name in disrepute. We are charged with failures in human rights when Australia should be a beacon of example in human rights. It is intolerable that people who come to our shores, however misled they are by being told that inevitably they will be received, be kept behind barbed wire and inadequately treated. It is a disgrace on the part of this Labor Government.

Fifthly, this country is in economic recession. We have one million unemployed, we have a huge Budget deficit and we have a huge balance of payments deficit. We are in huge debt, yet this Government has an immigration program that we as a nation cannot sustain. This Government should be thrown out for its inadequacies in immigration policy. Is it right to accept the applications of persons from all over the world to immigrate to this marvellous country and to see them unemployed and lining up for benefits at the expense of the Australian taxpayers? Australia loses and those individuals and their families lose. The Government should not lure people here beyond a reasonable quota. In past recessions, the immigration program had rightly fallen to between 50,000 and 70,000. It is greater than that at the moment. It has been too slow getting down to what it is now. Is it 85,000? We will lower net immigration.

The sixth problem is that the Government does not protect taxpayers' interests. It lacks discipline. It fails to put responsible checks on the extension of benefits to newly arrived migrants. I notice in the legislation before us tonight that the Government has copied a small amount of what the Liberal and National parties have announced as proper policy. The Government is introducing through this legislation a six-month period of exclusion from benefits. We welcome that, of course, but we think a two-year exclusion from benefit is appropriate. Let us not forget that we in this Parliament represent the Australian people and the national interests of Australia. Sure we have compassion, but let us not lure people into thinking that they can go into the social security system straight away .

Finally, there is the question of refugee determination, not only with regard to the boat people but also with regard to the Chinese students. Besides you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and me, I do not think there are more than a half dozen people who understand China and seek to be sympathetic with respect to the real needs of the Chinese people, Australia's relationship with China and, indeed, the Chinese students who are here. No-one can accuse you or me of any kind of racial hang-up or any kind of difficulty in dealing with this matter on its merits. But not even my friends should be given positive discrimination or special treatment.

Australia is all about equal treatment. We must have an immigration program which lives up to our standards of being non-discriminatory and equal to all. There should be no unfairness and the Australian people should be able to say, `We really believe in the immigration program'. I believe that only a Liberal and National party government will provide the disciplines that are needed once again to give the Australian people confidence in the immigration program of this country.

I now refer to the six Bills. The Migration Reform Bill 1992 is the largest and most important of the Bills that are before us. The Opposition welcomes what this Bill seeks to achieve, although I remain critical of the Government for not going as far as the Opposition is advocating in a number of respects. Clause 3 inserts an object into the Migration Act and I welcome this.

Control of our borders is to be reinforced by a one-visa system which will simplify and standardise the documentation needed on entry to Australia. One aspect of this is the requirement that Australian citizens should use their Australian passport or other acceptable evidence of Australian citizenship when entering or leaving the country. I realise that some Australians who are dual nationals and have not travelled on an Australian passport may be concerned about this. However, I make it clear that the Opposition firmly supports this step. Our belief is that Australian citizenship is very important and should not be undervalued. It does not reflect well on Australian citizenship if a citizen wants to travel abroad on a passport issued by another country. So the Opposition certainly supports this aspect of the Bill.

Proposed new section 54V of the Bill puts an onus on non-citizens to provide evidence of their authority to be present in Australia when required to do so by a departmental officer on reasonable suspicion. I acknowledge that this can be an important tool to assist in the discovery and deportation of illegal entrants.

I note that the Bill introduces the concept of a bridging visa which will be available for certain unlawful non-citizens and will give them lawful status and release from detention. The emphasis on unlawful non-citizens having to be detained and the possibility of a bridging visa then being granted to some is sound and I raise no objection to it.

The Bill proposes a major shake-up of the procedures for the review of immigration decisions. In the future we are to have an immigration review tribunal and a refugee review tribunal, with significant questions to be referred up to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Opposition regrets that the Government has not followed the views of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations on this matter. The Committee's approach is that, within the system of tribunals, there should be an appeals panel to consider questions of principle and to ensure consistency in tribunal decisions. Instead, the Bill will allow a reference of matters of principle to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

In the past we have found that the courts to which immigration matters have been appealed do not always have an appreciation of the impact of their decisions on the effective and tight administration of the immigration program. I believe there is a risk that the AAT will similarly not always be in touch with the particular requirements of immigration decision-making—that is, the intentions of this Parliament; the intentions of the law—even with a senior member of the Tribunal on the AAT for a particular case. This is not how the Opposition would have proceeded in this matter, and we think we can improve on this. I seek leave to incorporate the next few pages of my speech in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill seeks to increase the Government's capacity to control the entry into Australia of non-citizens through executive decisions. Secondly, the Bill seeks to limit possibilities of appeals to the courts against such decisions. In other words, the Bill seeks to limit judicial review.

PARA.TAB: The Bill's focus is on the entry of refugees and reflects the Government's concern about the current processing and review of claims made within Australia by people seeking refugee status. Yet Australia's refugee problem is very small indeed. The panic engendered by the arrival of a few boats to the north of the country has been out of all proportion to the so-called threat posed by the people in question, or to the portent they represent for a future influx of people from the north. Five hundred-odd asylum seekers over a period of four years surely does not constitute an invasion.

The nature of the Government's response to the new so-called wave of boat people seems in itself to have created a vicious circle. The Government seeks to justify the gross violations of human rights that are occurring with the continued isolation and detention of asylum seekers at Port Hedland. To do so it is striking out at anyone who tries to stand up for the individuals involved; yet it must be said that not since the passage of the War-time Refugees Removal Act in 1949 has Australia seen anything as shameful as the detention centre at Port Hedland.

The recent repatriation of 113 PRC nationals without giving the group access to independent legal advice is a national disgrace at a time when China is accepted as one of the leading producers of political refugees in the world. It is equally shameful that the Government denies that the Cambodian asylum seekers have reasonable grounds for fearing for their lives if forced to return to that country. Senator Evans's efforts to achieve peace for Cambodia are laudable; however, our involvement in the region should not blind us to the real and ongoing difficulties and dangers faced by Cambodian people while the Khmer Rouge is still a force to be reckoned with.

The Australian Democrats support some features of the Bill, including the establishment of a better merit review system which will probably reduce the number of judicial review applications going to the Federal Court. However, the Government's attempt to deprive asylum seekers of equal legal rights is shameful and unworthy of a civilised nation. In this Bill the Federal Court is deprived of its existing jurisdiction to review migration and to review decisions under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 or the Judiciary Act 1903. Instead, the Bill provides for a statutory code of judicial review in the Federal Court with substantially narrowed heads of judicial review.

Under proposed section 166LB, a breach of the rules of natural justice and an unreasonable exercise of power—in other words, so unreasonable that no reasonable person could have so exercised the power—are excluded as grounds for review. So are irrelevant considerations, perceived bias or bad faith. However, direct appeals to the High Court under placitum 75(v) will still lie because they cannot be abolished and the High Court will be inundated, as pointed out by the Chief Justice in his letter to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy).

Indeed, there are good objective reasons in support of the expectation that the High Court will be flooded with judicial review applications, particularly since the heads of judicial review proposed to be eliminated under this Bill for the Federal Court figure prominently in cases where Commonwealth administrative action has been held to be unlawful. For this reason alone, persons aggrieved by migration and refugee decision making are highly unlikely to be satisfied with a statutory code of judicial review which denies them the opportunity to raise many of the most significant and effective grounds of challenge. Since such grounds will be available only in the High Court, such persons will naturally pursue the judicial review remedies in that forum.

Such a scenario is thoroughly undesirable for several reasons which affect not only applicants for review but also the Commonwealth itself. As Australia's ultimate appellate court, it is highly undesirable that the High Court's finite resources be diverted by the necessity of having to process numerous applications for review arising in its original jurisdiction. To suggest that the High Court will be able to remit such matters to the Federal Court under section 44 of the Judiciary Act is to ignore the operation of proposed new section 166LK(3) of the Bill. The effect of that provision is to limit the Federal Court to the much narrower scope of judicial review available under the statutory judicial review code. Clearly, the High Court will be left with no real alternative but to hear itself the applications for judicial review of migration and refugee decisions brought in its original jurisdiction.

Of course, proposed section 166LK could be constitutionally invalid. It may be invalid as imposing an impermissible limitation on the High Court's inherent power of remitter. The effect of the proposed section will be to shear from matters in their remitted form the plenitude of jurisdiction exercisable under placitum 75(v) of the Constitution.

In summary, the effect of the Bill's proposals is to deny persons aggrieved by migration and refugee decisions the protection of the law available to persons aggrieved by Commonwealth administrative decision making generally. Such an approach discriminates against migrants, their families and sponsors, refugees and other persons affected by migration decisions.

The Government proposes that asylum seekers be denied equal rights before Australian courts even though these courts are making decisions on their fate. It gives rise to the serious question of whether the Bill meets Australia's obligations under article 26 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which deals with equality before the law and provides that all persons `are entitled without any discrimination to the equal protection of the law'. Clearly, it does not.

On what basis can the Government effectively invite the merits review bodies to reach decisions on the basis of irrelevant considerations or in bad faith, safe in the knowledge that such decisions will be unreviewable on those grounds in the Federal Court? It is also difficult to see any justification, for example, in the exclusion of the rules of natural justice or unreasonable decisions.

The Government seems to be proceeding on the basis that the establishment of merits review procedures somehow obviates the need for efficient and effective judicial review of migration and refugee decision making in accordance with well established principles and procedures which are available to other persons adversely affected by Commonwealth administrative action. But the mere provision of procedures for merits review does not mean that such processes will always operate according to legal principles and requirements. There is clearly a continuing need for effective judicial review to guard against unlawful administrative decision making in all its various forms, including unreasonableness and all the other traditional heads of judicial review identified above. Clearly, this Bill does nothing of the sort.

The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's second reading amendment. The Opposition says in this amendment that the Government has failed to control the refugee determination process. The Opposition exhorts the Government to limit judicial appeals—the very purpose of this Bill to which we object strongly—and it says that in particular it regrets that the Government has failed to control the refugee determination process of the students from the People's Republic of China who are in Australia. The Australian Democrats believe that a promise by one Prime Minister should be kept by the next Prime Minister and any other Prime Minister following him. It is a promise given by the Australian nation and it should not be subverted by obstructive bureaucratic procedures.

I listened in vain to Senator Teague for the spirit of liberalism that we have come to expect from the Party of John Gorton, Harold Holt, Malcolm Fraser, Peter Baume, Ian Macphee and even Robert Menzies. What I heard came from a party that could be called the party of Mrs Thatcher—a party that was able to introduce a poll tax and a party that did not concern itself with individual civil liberties and social justice. I regret that this is so. I confirm that the Democrats will not be supporting the second reading amendment.

PARA.TAB: I have always said that Australia is too hasty to grant citizenship to migrants. The Minister details the offences committed in Australia prior to the granting of citizenship which may render those granted citizenship status liable to deportation. These include:

SPEECH.PARA: .serious sexual assaults, whether or not accompanied by other violence (especially where there has been more than one sexual offence);

—I thank Senator Teague for that. I quote from the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 June 1992, which states:

PARA.TAB: Australia is persecuting hundreds of Cambodian boat people, Federal Court judge and former human rights commissioner Justice Marcus Einfeld said yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the sort of thing one would expect from somebody compassionate about this situation, like Senator Spindler, Senator Chamarette and certainly Senator Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even me.

—And, very importantly, Senator Teague. I emphasise the point Senator Teague makes, because it is a good one. Senator Teague is saying that he is moved compassionately and is desperately keen to see that as many migrants and refugees, people whose lives are twisted by the misfortunes they suffer overseas, should come to this country.

PARA.TAB: But there is a limit, and every country around the world has put a limit on it. That is the problem. We come back to the proposition: of these very people who deserve to be treated better than they are, who deserves to come? Who should come from the camps on the borders of Thailand, the camps in Pakistan, Afghanistan, the Middle East, Bosnia and so on? Who will make that choice? In the end that choice comes down to the Department and to the Minister.

Just as Senator Teague is compassionate—just as anyone must be compassionate in this circumstance, given the dreadful sufferings these people undergo—the Minister has compassion. But he has to face the reality of making decisions according to the law and the law has to be passed by people in this Parliament acting responsibly. That is what is happening here tonight. Both the Labor Party and the coalition have decided that this legislation is the best that is available to meet the situation we face. Given that, we are making our decisions accordingly. On the other hand, the Democrats, Senator Chamarette and Senator Harradine say that there ought to be a much more expansive program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a just one.

—I do not want to take up too much time, but Senator Spindler says, `Just a just one'. He has made the decision—and he is entitled to do so—that the Democrats, Senator Powell, Senator Chamarette and Senator Harradine are the ones who are just, and the rest of us are not. He may be right, but as I look around this chamber I see people of outstanding integrity on both sides. To accuse them, by inference, of being unjust seems to me to be a little harsh and perhaps an unjust judgment in itself.
—Subjective.

—As Senator Baume says, it is perhaps subjective. It is all very well to make out a case based on an interpretation of facts. If those people who come to Australia by boat are refugees who would be shot, tortured or otherwise outrageously treated if they return, of course we would all object. But what are the facts? That is the real issue. What are the facts? It comes down to who will judge those facts.

PARA.TAB: This legislation sets up a procedure whereby that can be done. If it comes down to the point where parliament and parliamentarians make the decision, then, given the fact that this is a political chamber, judgments will be made on the basis of political perception. That is the reality.

TALK.START.PARA: —So we exclude natural justice?

—Nobody has ever said that we will exclude natural justice. What we do say is that in the deciding of facts natural justice should be adhered to. But Senator Spindler suggests, by inference, that one will get more natural justice here amongst senators, whose purpose by and large is to debate in an adversarial way across the chamber and score points, than one would get in the courts—and these cases can go to the courts—and in the procedures set up by this Bill for independent tribunals which are overseen by the courts. That is stretching the issue too far.

PARA.TAB: Those are exactly the sorts of criticisms that the Minister has to face the whole time. He is criticised and condemned. At times not only is the Minister criticised but also the shadow Minister, Philip Ruddock, is condemned and brought into disrepute on the interpretation of `facts' which are just not true.

I do not want to take up any more time, but it is proper for this chamber to look at the legislation on its merits and not be swayed by natural sympathy for anyone who is in a position of disadvantage and who has suffered tremendous hardship and all sorts of problems. That natural sympathy for them must not at the same time overbalance and discount the fact that we have limited resources and capacity to bring people into this country. That is illustrated by the very fact that nobody is suggesting for one minute that every refugee on the Thailand border, Pakistan, Palestine or Bosnia be brought here. That indicates straight away that there is a limit and the real argument here is what that limit should be.

The report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, entitled Australia's refugee and humanitarian system: achieving a balance between refuge and control, was presented earlier this year. The Committee heard in camera evidence from the Refugee Advice and Casework Service. Eve Lester, Ms Margaret Piper and Mr Seth Richardson earned the accolade of being perhaps the worst set of witnesses that have ever appeared before a parliamentary inquiry. I think that when people are designing zoos they think about the conditions in which the animals in their cages would be best able to live a comparable lifestyle to that which they have in their own homes, in their natural environment. The conditions in the camps in Hong Kong are the absolute antithesis: they have taken away privacy; they have taken away freedom of choice; they have taken away any decision making capacity for these people and have provided them with next to no recreational facilities. PARA.TAB: When I was making the tabling speech for the report on behalf of the Standing Committee in this place, I mentioned that the Government should look at where public funding is being spent. I do not think that the citizens of Australia are getting value for money. I certainly do not think that the asylum seekers in Villawood or Port Hedland are getting value for money. I have gone on much longer than I had intended to, but we are debating six very important Bills tonight. I note that last week teachers from New South Wales were demonstrating outside this place about the provisions of the Bill. I also note that in another State of Australia teachers are also demonstrating—demonstrating for a completely different point. I just draw that comparison to show where people set their priorities. Government is legislating in this Bill for a minimum of 510 hours to be available to newly arrived non-English speaking migrants—an improvement on that which they had before. I would suggest that some of the teacher organisations that came here to this place last week which continue to write letters to me and to other members of the Senate have vested interests and are more concerned with their continued employment and their continued remuneration from the job rather than the provision of English language lessons to newly arrived non-English speaking migrants.
