TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Immigration Education Charge Bill 1992 and the Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1992 in this package of Bills. I was listening with interest to the contribution by Senator McKiernan, especially on the last point he raised. He certainly raised a number of interesting issues that I will be canvassing in my speech. I also note with interest that a further addition to Senator McKiernan's most colourful wardrobe is being exhibited to us in the Senate tonight. There seems to be a growing trend amongst honourable senators—male senators at least—to wear more colourful clothes in this place. It is a tremendous delight to women senators to see male senators actually adding some colour to the chamber for a change.
—I apologise for the socks. The socks were not up to it today, but tomorrow.

—We will look at Senator McKiernan's socks tomorrow. The main intention of these two Bills is to recover costs of English language training for adult migrants. This legislation allows the charging of fees for the training of Australian residents who enrol in courses arranged under the adult migrant English program. The Australian Democrats have many concerns about the intent of this legislation and support many of the letters and petitions from community groups, including some of the issues raised by the New South Wales Teachers Federation and ethnic councils of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The fundamental problem with this legislation is the concept of charging migrants in Australia for the purpose of assisting them in language. These moves by the Government symbolise the entrenchment of user pays principles in all areas of education in this country. What could be a more basic need amongst our migrant communities than assistance with the common language—a tool which will assist them in their everyday lives? Migrants from non-English speaking backgrounds traditionally fill jobs in industries such as motor vehicles, textiles and steel. These are the very industries where structural change and job losses have been the most severe. English skills are increasingly important in redeploying workers laid off in such industries and helping new arrivals find work—particularly the latter since the unemployment rates for those who arrived in 1991 to May 1992 is 47.4 per cent.

It has been shown that State Budgets bear the brunt of immigration program costs and that the States are not adequately compensated by the Commonwealth for this. This was most recently borne out in a paper by Professor Russell Matthews, an expert on public finance, at the recent Second National Outlook Immigration Conference in Sydney. If we support the principle of providing immigrants with sufficient resources so that they can fully integrate into Australian society, then there are only two solutions: firstly, to increase funding to the States for ESL teaching and other services or, secondly, to reduce the number of immigrants, particularly those from non-English speaking backgrounds, to fit what can be afforded. Obviously some balance is required.

Despite extolling the virtues of our education system and capitalising on its marketability abroad, the Government and our education institutions still fail to provide basic bridging and other introductory courses for overseas students—a point that I made when addressing the Overseas Student Charge Amendment Bill in the Senate last week. We share some of the concerns raised in letters that we have received from the Ethnic Communities Council of South Australia, the New South Wales Teachers Federation and the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia. The President of the Ethnic Communities Councils in South Australia writes:

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget's introduction of fees will mean that some migrants . . . will not be able to access English language training. This will significantly restrict the successful settlement of such migrants and their ability to effectively contribute to the Australian community.

He also raises the all-important question of equity. I stress that the case of women in the migrant community is one that disturbs me at this time. Many women face not only the language barrier but other barriers as a result of their religion, cultural background and financial difficulties. These changes in this legislation will affect the already restricted opportunities for English language training for women.

PARA.TAB: It is recognised by the Government that participation by women in English language training is low when compared with that of men. Part of the problem relates to child-care, in that there is inadequate child-care for migrant women to enable them to access English language training. We certainly hope that additional funding in the long term can be provided to ensure that these women have access, through child-care, to English language training. The Australian Democrats are committed to a publicly funded, accessible and equitable education system for all Australians, regardless of their sex, age, race, religion or cultural or economic background. The proposed fee scale from $50 to $4,080 for ESL is a financial barrier that will prevent migrants from even considering training and is a feature of this Bill that the Democrats will not support.
In his second reading speech, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) justifies his argument for user-pays English language training by stating:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . proficiency in English benefits individuals. It is reasonable therefore that individuals who benefit from the adult migrant english program should contribute to its cost.

Are we to deduce from this that the Government believes that basic English training should not be available to all Australians, new arrivals or otherwise, and that a natural advantage should be conferred upon those who have an ability to speak and learn English and who have the ability to pay for that training? The connection between wealth and education is a sad feature of today's education system, and these Bills are a cynical revenue raising exercise by the Government, as evidenced by other aspects of this year's Budget.

PARA.TAB: This legislation also sets a maximum entitlement for newly arrived migrants for English language training of 510 hours. The Government is to be commended for literally setting in concrete a minimum number of hours of English language training for each student. As the Minister has outlined, no government has ever given this kind of guaranteed commitment, and I think the Government is to be commended for that. I further note that providers will have the ability to roll over unused hours from one student to the next, which provides a small degree of flexibility in the provision of tuition. However, the limit of 510 hours has no educational or linguistic basis, even though it is recognised that most migrants require a minimum of 900 hours of English to enable them to find meaningful employment or access to further education.

The conditions that prescribe that a migrant must register with the AMES within three months of arrival is impractical and unfair, as is the necessity that refugees and migrants begin these new classes within 12 months. While it is true that 90 per cent of migrants would fall easily within these parameters, we are concerned that they may be unduly restrictive for the 10 per cent of migrants who are too traumatised or dislocated to register in time. The Minister has told me that he intends to make regulations to provide for cases of special hardship. We would like to see that regulatory power spelt out more clearly in this legislation.

Other issues that arise in these Bills and with which community groups have concerns, include the test procedures; that is, what are the purposes of the testing and for what purposes will the results be used? Another issue relates to the tendering processes. It is our understanding that none of the DILGEA money will be open to tender. However, a maximum of 40 per cent of the DEET money for ESL courses will be tendered, according to the Minister. The Minister concludes his second reading speech by claiming:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the benefits of charging go beyond any contribution to revenue.

PARA.TAB: Client contribution to cost will encourage greater motivation from students . . . places a greater obligation on service providers to meet the expectation of clients.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely the highest standard of service should be expected anyway, and the concept that fees will make migrants appreciate any more or less the value of being able to communicate in their new country is farcical.

PARA.TAB: The Minister recognises that proficiency in English is an essential part of Australian life and that it facilitates communication and, hence, equality of opportunity amongst Australians. Despite this acknowledgment, the Government has based access to English language training on unequal opportunities and financial ability. Surely it is of community benefit to educate new arrivals in the common language of their new country. Why unnecessarily add to the trauma of displacement and isolation the inability to communicate?

The Democrats do not support the fee charging arrangements but do support a guaranteed provision of English tuition, even though the hours suggested may need attention and we would like to see some prescription of the regulations regarding exemptions and special hardship cases spelt out. I am relieved to see that refugees' preferential family members and those wholly dependent on social security payments are exempt from the charges, which the Government describes as constituting `a better managed client responsive program'. It is a pity that changes designed to create a more client responsive program could affect as many as 4,000 Australian students and deprive them of the opportunity of learning English.

At this point I would like to thank the Government for agreeing to hold off the committee stage. It may in fact be that some of the queries we have will be answered by the briefing we are to have tomorrow. We probably will have some amendments to move to this legislation, but I do thank the Government for having acceded to the request of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training to at least hold off the committee stage to enable the Committee to examine the legislation in more detail—and I do thank the Minister for that.

In conclusion, it is the view of the Democrats that education should be publicly funded and the community should pay because the community benefits. This should be the guiding philosophy of our education system and, in our belief, should prevail in the case of providing English for migrants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I am dismayed that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) has taken the opportunity, in the second reading speech on the Migration Reform Bill, to cast hostile and deeply divisive remarks about the Refugee Council of Australia specifically and other people who seek to represent refugees in Australia generally.

PARA.TAB: The Minister may feel angry and frustrated by the efforts of lawyers who are seeking to protect the interests of the unfortunate people who end up in detention centres and I, too, would not want to unduly delay the processing of people seeking refuge in Australia. I would certainly not want to raise unrealistically the expectations of these people. But it is a mark of a great and humane society to hold the rights of individuals, be they citizens or not, above all else. It is a sad indictment of this Government's immigration policies that it is the lot of some 450 refugees to carry the full weight of punishment and bear the brunt of Australia's fear of a flood of boat people. Never have 450 people been the object of so much legislative action.

Equally, the conditions in which the majority of boat people are held is a shameful mark on Australia's human rights record. The detention centre at Port Hedland is a disgrace and not worthy of a civilised nation such as ours—or at least one that calls itself civilised. I, too, refer in passing to the article in the Australian on 3 December. From all the reports that I have received, the article by Jennifer McAsey is an accurate reflection of what our present policy is.

There is a lack of recognition, at least at the Port Hedland centre, of what people have been through by the time they get to this country. Even if we kept them in motel-like conditions, we would still be subjecting them to a continuation of the victimisation and persecution that has led them to depart their own countries. There is also a failure to recognise that if these people are faced in a fair way even with a negative decision they should be entitled to think through their future prospects and come to terms with that in their own time, rather than being whisked off at very short notice and taken out of their detention cells in the early hours of the morning in such a way that they can only be put in a situation of fear.

It may be that the Government wants to set an example—this seems to be the underlying assumption—so as to deter others from entering Australia in this way. But how can we, in all conscience, accept this? In the criminal system, the principle of general deterrence—that is, punishment of one person's offence in order to influence the behaviour of others rather than simply as a penalty for that individual alone—violates justice. It is unjust, as C.S. Lewis pointed out many years ago, to use the principle of general deterrence to contain people in a way that does not apply to their own situations. Much more so is it an offence against justice when no offence has been committed and people have simply sought refuge on our shores. Detention in this situation for people who are being processed for refugee application status is a crime against humanity.

I am very concerned that the Minister in his speech could wax eloquent about how the procedures in this Bill will replace the somewhat open-ended doctrines of natural justice and unreasonableness. The Bill seeks to exclude breaches of natural justice, unreasonableness, bad faith, irrelevant considerations and perceived bias when the Federal Court is reviewing immigration decisions. Surely these doctrines should be uppermost in the minds of the people who are here to represent the views of a fair and reasonably minded nation such as Australia.

Senator McKiernan spoke of natural justice as needing to be paid for and also to be discriminatory; that is, to be available to Australian citizens only. This is not acceptable—and it is not acceptable in the eyes of the world. While I am pleased to see that the Department affirms that it wishes to build processes which do provide fairness and certainty, that fairness and certainty should not be at the cost of natural justice. Whilst this package of Bills deals with a wider range of issues than refugees, it is these provisions which colour the whole intent of the legislation.

Australia's refugee policy is founded on the myth that we face floods of refugees. Margaret Piper, in her paper Recent trends and legislative changes relating to refugees and special humanitarian entrants, says:

SPEECH.PARA: While the number of asylum seekers we have at present (some 20,800) is greater than at any time in the past, it was created by factors that are arguably idiosyncratic. About 70 per cent of the current caseload are Chinese students allowed to enter Australia after the events in Tiananmen Square.
The reality is that Australia has the most impenetrable barriers to migration of any country in the world and has had since the 1850s.
Later she states:

Why too is the government so obsessed with the illegal arrivals? Of the 22,500 asylum seekers awaiting processing, about 500 arrived illegally by boat . . . in other words, only about 2 per cent of the total.

Does fear of numbers underlie the persistent attempts in this legislation to limit the role of the courts in determining refugee applications. The role of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal bears looking at here. I would like to refer to the excellent analysis that was presented in a Canberra Times article of 10 November by Mr Rod Campbell. Mr Campbell, in his article entitled `Judges on the outer in laws on migration', draws to our attention the role of the AAT in relation to this legislation. The article states:

The respective heads of the IRT and the RRT can refer issues of `general application' to the AAT if they wish. The AAT can accept the referral if it wishes. The theory, it seems, is to have a high-status AAT resolve some of the more important general issues relating to immigrants and refugees, for the benefit of the other tribunals and departmental decision makers.
The article further states:

PARA.TAB: The word `theory' is used deliberately. There are many public servants, and some entire bureaucracies, that refuse to accept that an AAT decision has any precedent value. If they do not like a decision, they refuse to apply it to any other case (until and unless forced to by the Federal Court). The AAT's role in immigration cases of general importance will be neutered if its rulings are not accorded precedent value and decision-makers can pick and choose between decisions they like and those that they do not.

SPEECH.PARA: This transfer of attention is presumably based on the presumption that judicial interference is inappropriate as access to Australia's territory by aliens is a matter of state sovereignty and therefore should be dealt with by the government of the day. Yet we have obligations as a signatory to the 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees. These are legal obligations and therefore must be overseen by the judiciary.

PARA.TAB: Australia will have to bear the diagnosis of history. Relative to many other countries, we have much better opportunities to offer assistance. These people are in our region. It is primarily our responsibility to offer justice, compassion and to respect their human dignity as they access their rights to due process of law.

Having dealt with the unfortunate situation presenting to people who are applying for refugee status and saying that this hard line against them is an indictment of Australia in the eyes of the world community, I now turn to the two Bills that refer to the education facilities available to those who are fortunate enough to have received acceptance into our country. The Migration Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and the related Immigration Migration (Education Charge) Bill 1992 set out a means by which the cost to government for provision of English language courses to migrants can be recovered.

The adult migrant English program enables people of non-English speaking backgrounds to acquire functional English upon arrival in Australia as permanent residents. Clearly, this is a major factor in their ability to make their way into the community and to make the greatest contribution that their talents and skills allow. It is self-evident that lack of functional English is a barrier to employment in this country, but there are other barriers for those who are not fluent in English and this is one of our objections to the legislation.

The purpose and the driving force of this legislation are to be found in that wonderful adage of user pays. It is a measure driven by the forces of economics, not the desire to foster multiculturalism and social cohesion. There are many people of non-English speaking background whose desire and, dare we say, need to speak English are not driven by their desire to work. There are many people whose role is in the home, raising children and helping them through their school years. They have day to day contact with trades people, shopkeepers and the like and they need English every bit as much as someone working in paid employment.

It is fair to say that many of the people I am referring to are women. This point was raised earlier by Senator Sowada. In the migrant community, whether we are talking about those who arrived in the years after World War II or those arriving now, the job seekers are mainly men while the home-makers are mainly women. This legislation, in seeking to recover the cost of English classes from those learning English, is putting financial pressures on families, particularly in the first couple of years after they arrive when they are least able to afford extras. One of the negative side effects of that will be borne disproportionately by women.

Clearly, the Minister will tell us that certain people are exempt from having to pay for their English courses—those who are registered job seekers and those who hold health care cards. It is pleasing to see that the Government has at least made that provision, but there are lots of people who do not fit into those categories. For example, there are families in which someone is working and earning a moderate income. That does not mean that money for such courses is going to be available for other adults in the family. That is one objection I hold to the legislation. I foreshadow my support of the Australian Democrats' amendments.

DEBATE.TITLE: MIGRATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1992IMMIGRATION (EDUCATION) CHARGE BILL 1992MIGRATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992MIGRATION REFORM BILL 1992MIGRATION (DELAYED VISA APPLICATIONS) TAX BILL 1992MIGRATION (OFFENCES AND UNDESIRABLE PERSONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —Another objection to the Migration Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) is the limit of 510 hours of tuition as set out in the legislation. People who teach adult migrant English have contacted my office and have made it perfectly clear that 510 hours is nowhere near enough time for people to acquire a second language at a functional level. Again, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) will no doubt point out that there are courses available through the TAFE system at little cost, but I point out that the number of places available is limited and that the demand exceeds the places available considerably.

PARA.TAB: A third objection lies in the distinction drawn between the Government's obligation to provide the courses and the client's ability to take them up. Past practice has been to offer a client a course of a particular number of hours duration and, if the client is unable to take up the offer, the hours offered are deducted from the total number of hours made available to that client. I have been told of this happening time and time again, and without the clients being notified that their inability to take up a course will not be taken into account when keeping a tally of their hours.

There are any number of reasons why clients may not be able to take up a particular course being offered. As I mentioned earlier, it may be home duties, an inability to negotiate time from work or being in an isolated community. Therefore, the obligation to provide courses should include an obligation to work with the clients to find appropriate courses.

The Bill sets out certain conditions of eligibility and, again, it would seem pointless setting these out without providing the mechanism by which the client is supposed to discover this information. For instance, a client must register with a course provider within three months of the commencement date of his or her visa. That is fine if the client is in touch with an immigration office frequently early in his or her time in Australia. It may even be noted in big bold type in information kits clients receive when they arrive. But if clients choose not to stay in one of the major cities, move into an isolated community or are swept up into their family or ethnic community, three months will not be a long enough time. Three months is certainly not a very long time if the clients have to overcome family insistence that they do not really need to learn English, a story which is common for women in strong ethnic communities. This then results in disempowerment.

Lastly, a recent DILGEA instruction to adult migrant English program staff indicates that people who arrived in Australia prior to July 1991 and who have not yet attended any classes by 1 January—the date this Bill takes effect—will not be eligible for any government provision of language courses. Perhaps the Minister could take time to explain to the Senate the background of that instruction, as it does not seem to be related to this Bill in any way at all.

The Immigration (Education) Charge Bill, like the Migration Laws Amendment Bill, seeks to recover costs from the non-English speaking recent arrivals in Australia. This seems totally counter to notions of easing people into the community, letting them know they are welcome and fostering good community spirit. As this measure is directed at people at the point at which they apply to come to Australia as permanent residents and potential future citizens, it seems odd that we bail them up at the first point of contact with Australian consular officials with the bright news that we want them to pay for their English language courses before they can even be granted a visa. Apart from raising questions about the image Australia wants to project overseas, there is a more sinister side. This measure discriminates against people who do not have functional English, to use the term as it is presented in the literature.

In the terms of most equal opportunity legislation, this Bill sets out a means by which we as a nation can indirectly discriminate against certain ethnic groups. Indirect discrimination, of course, is a measure which appears ethnically neutral at first glance—after all, if we apply this measure to all people who apply to come, then we are not discriminating on grounds of race—but on closer inspection it becomes clear that certain groups will be more likely to be affected than others.

So this measure discriminates in favour of those who come from English speaking countries against those who do not. The discrimination is there because the Bill exempts those who have functional English from the education charge. The measure is classic user pays. But it goes further than that. Clearly, the measure discriminates against people who are poor. While we may well decide as a nation that we do not want poor people as migrants, let us at least make such a decision consciously and openly if that is what we want—and I must add that it is certainly not what I want—and not by some back door method of saying to someone, `Of course our doors are open, but if you can't pay for your English classes that's another matter'.

There is provision for the Minister to decide that particular applicants can be exempted. While that may seem a worthy measure, and all legislation should be subject to review in individual cases, it means that for some people their application may depend on a further decision-making process, with yet more delays. And there is more: the Bill allows for the charge to be levied at different rates for different categories of applicants, up to an arbitrary maximum of $4,080. That means that we could find governments using this legislation to shape the ethnic make-up of our migrant intake not on the basis of open community discussion but on the basis of making the charge higher or lower for some groups as against others so as to discourage or encourage migrants from particular places. It does not take much of a leap from there to project us back into the white Australia policy.

This Bill is a disgrace, just like the others. It may purport to be about cost recovery, but it contains enough powers for the Government to exclude from the migration program almost any non-English speaking group it wants excluded. It may well be that the Government wants such powers, but if it does then let it go out into the community and come into the Parliament and say so clearly and openly and debate the issue properly, rather than take such powers by stealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to speak particularly to the Immigration (Education) Charge Bill 1992 and the Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1992. The Opposition supports these Bills, as my colleague Senator Teague has pointed out. The teaching of English to new arrivals, where they do not have an English language capacity, is one of the most important aspects of their successful settlement in Australia. We have done the migrant community—indeed the whole nation—a disservice in the past because we have not devoted enough resources to this area. People cannot become fully functioning members of Australian society unless they have the ability to communicate. Their contribution to this country reaches its full potential only if they have this ability. For this reason, the teaching of English to our migrant population is fundamental.

PARA.TAB: Currently several programs exist to assist adult teaching of English to speakers of another language. There is the adult migration education program, English as a second language courses, workplace reform programs, English as a second language provision within higher education, and State funded programs through TAFE, ELICOS and other courses. There is enormous complexity in the number of programs and the number of people who are involved in the teaching of English in Australia.

Under this legislation, once the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs finishes its requirement of providing 510 hours of English tuition, the student will have to go on to other programs run by other departments—in most cases the Department of Employment, Education and Training. This just creates more bureaucracy. Why not simplify the structure under one articulated program rather than complicating it through a number of departments? In fact, the Government needs to develop an overall policy to achieve better outcomes by ensuring that there is a rational framework in which these programs can operate, but it is the lack of resources that prevents such an approach.

This legislation addresses the very significant outstanding problems relating to the provision of resources for teaching English to new arrivals to this country. Presently it is impossible to provide sufficient teaching of English to all the people entering Australia under the immigration program.

We had an example of this in Adelaide last year when we were conducting hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into adult and community education. Appearing before the hearings was a Turkish lady who was a qualified accountant in Turkey. She had no English language skills. When she came to Australia she was given 300 hours of basic tuition in English. After that she lost priority and went onto social welfare. It would seem an absurd allocation of resources in this country that we pay an enormous amount of money into social welfare and do not provide the comparatively minor additional cost for getting her up to a standard of English proficiency where she could practise her profession.

This legislation greatly improves that aspect. But 510 hours is not sufficient, particularly if people want to go into a profession. As a matter of fact, depending on the proficiency of people in English when they start a course, probably more than double those hours are needed. Therefore, the whole question of resources and the way in which people are admitted to migration programs needs to be addressed.

We have recently seen changes in the requirements for people entering Australia. Those entering under independent migration categories will now be subject in their points testing to an assessment of their English language capacity. This is necessary because of the costs to taxpayers of the migration program. These costs in the short and medium terms are quite significant. It is only after a period of 10 years that one starts to see the economic benefits from immigration in terms of Commonwealth outlays. Naturally, under current economic conditions, these outlays need to be rationalised as much as possible and, therefore, the Opposition has supported the moves for English competency testing. We still have, however, some serious concerns about the way in which this testing will be carried out and, in particular, whether such testing will be conducted equitably across a wide range of countries.

The legislation before us also addresses the issue of a user charge in the area of teaching English to new arrivals. It introduces a scheme in respect of new migrants entering Australia who do not have functional English. The charges are introduced in two forms. There is a maximum of $4,080 for applicants from 1 January 1993 who are issued visas or entry permits after 1 March 1993, and a charge of up to $250 a year for current residents enrolling or re-enrolling in adult migrant English. In return for this charge, the Commonwealth undertakes to fund up to 510 hours of tuition.

Whether or not 510 hours is sufficient is a matter of debate. It depends on the various English competency levels of each person when starting the program; it depends on the different educational levels of each migrant; and it depends on their ability as language students. Therefore, the 510 hours seems quite arbitrary. But the Government feels it is sufficient to ensure that immigrants can find their way around and function and communicate at a basic level. It is not necessarily a vocational or employable level of English.

I return to the initial point in my speech: how can we expect people to achieve their full potential if they cannot function properly in society and in the workplace because of insufficient instruction in English? I am aware that they can go onto other work related programs, particularly under DEET. But how many of them will do this and how many of them will successfully complete the programs and reach an adequate level of English for the workplace? How many will be left functionally illiterate and unable to achieve their full potential not only in the workplace but also in society? This has been noted in particular in a number of articles in the press recently, and I quote from two. The Sydney Morning Herald of 26 November 1992 told of Dr Carl Mahfouz, who speaks fluent Russian and Arabic. Dr Mahfouz said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . other countries have spent hundreds of thousands of dollars to train us. All it needs now for Australia to get the benefit of our training is the minor expense of providing advanced English courses.
Dr Beata Niechoda, a surgeon trained in Poland who was also featured in the article, said:
We are not allowed to do anything, just wait, or I can work as a labourer for $7 per hour. But the longer we wait the more we will lose our skills.

These are two examples of the types of dilemma that arise under our current program. We must ensure that migrants, such as those who have access to English language programs, can make the fullest contribution to our society.

PARA.TAB: The scheme presented in this legislation deals with charging for educational services. Some of it goes some way towards providing the additional resources that are required, hence the boost in the number of guaranteed hours. There are exemptions in it. In reality, this addresses many of the concerns that Senator Chamarette and Senator Sowada raised. It covers the disadvantaged categories, including refugees and special assistance and those who are here for humanitarian reasons. In effect, it appears that only those entering through the concessional family and independent categories will be required to pay the full tuition fees. This will operate on a sliding scale with the maximum fee of $4,080.

Given the exemptions and the application of user charges to those who can afford them, it was interesting to see several comments incorporated by the Minister in his second reading speech for this legislation. The Minister stated that proficiency in English benefits individuals as well as Australian society as a whole. It is reasonable, therefore, that individuals who benefit from the program should contribute to its cost. He also made the statement that the benefits of charging go beyond any contribution to revenue; that client contribution to cost will encourage greater motivation from students; that charging places a greater obligation on service providers to meet the expectations of clients; and that charges will result in better managed client responsive programs.

The coalition applauds this type of thinking, but it really begs the question: why can the Government not adopt such market oriented approaches to teaching in other areas of education if it does so for migrant education? Surely if charging for the teaching of English language programs improves the motivation of students and the responsiveness to providers, as the Minister stated, the same applies to both vocational and higher education.

The Government still chooses to apply a different standard in this area due to an outdated, one-eyed ideology. Even though the Government is inconsistent, any adoption of freedom and responsiveness in this area of education must be welcomed, as the coalition welcomes this measure. I therefore accept the Government's position on these charges for the teaching of English to migrants, but at the same time condemn it for its hypocrisy and inconsistency on the issue of charging for educational services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the second reading debate on the Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1992 and associated Bills. This is important legislation. In listening to the debate, one could be forgiven for getting the impression—which I think is a complete misdescription—that Australia as a society is heartless or not welcoming. There did not seem to be any appreciation or noting of the fact that 80,000 people will be welcomed to Australia this financial year in very difficult times—times of great stress in our society. Amongst them will be 10,000 refugees—that is, persons who have been assessed as having a well-founded fear of persecution for their political beliefs and who seek refuge and haven in the democratic society of Australia.

PARA.TAB: That all has to be given much greater weight than has hitherto been given in the course of this debate when trying to describe how Australia and its migration and refugee system works. This system puts Australia at the forefront of countries that have a practical willingness to show compassion, certainly to those many thousands of Cambodians and other South East Asian refugees who have found sanctuary and a future for themselves and their descendants in Australia. That is my first point.

Secondly, it is important to emphasise that certainly the Parliament of Australia and the Government of Australia elected by the people have an obligation to maintain the integrity of the borders and to ensure that those who come to Australia and seek to stay here have a real entitlement to do so, whether that entitlement is made under our own domestic approaches to these matters or whether it is in recognition of the international conventions which, for example, regulate the granting of refugee status. But we certainly have an obligation to the Australian community to ensure that those who want to stay here have a real entitlement to do so. They do not establish their claim to stay simply by arriving on our shores as boat people.

It is no use pre-determining proper categorisation by stereotyping all boat people as refugees. The 113 Chinese nationals who arrived in Australia in late October were interviewed separately by Department of Immigration officials. As I am advised—and I have advised the Senate before—none of them made a claim to refugee status. Obviously they were seeking a better life. They were seeking to establish a future for themselves other than in the homeland of their ancestors, but they did not claim to be refugees and they were returned to China. That is a proper response by the Australian community to those who arrive on our shores, even if it is in circumstances of peril in crossing the waters to land on our shores.

The Migration Reform Bill principally seeks to provide a system whereby it is much clearer who falls into the lawful and unlawful categories as far as their presence in Australia is concerned. It then tries to indicate those decision making procedures which enable the merits of any particular claim that is made to be assessed. Of course, there are questions that can properly be raised about that process. Nevertheless, for the first time we are trying in this particular Bill to put forward a comprehensive and much more simple system that is better able to be understood by those who are to be subject to it and those who have to operate the system of decision making, whether within departmental structures or within the various boards and tribunals which will carry out merits review.

A number of matters will probably be raised in the committee stage in relation to that Bill. I need not pause now to answer all the points made during the second reading debate on that Bill. Other Bills in the package deal with capping legislation which enables a system of caps to be put on the various allocations at various posts in the granting of various visas. This is a more refined and accurate way of tackling the problem rather than the present broad brush requirement to suspend the whole processing arrangements. I understand that that is supported around the chamber.

The Migration (Offences and Undesirable Persons) Amendment Bill 1992 has not had much mention tonight. It really arises from the decision to exclude from Australia non-Australian members of the Hell's Angels Motor Cycle Club. There has been quite a deal of scrutiny of the decision making process in relation to the type of decision where one finds within the Australian community a necessity to exclude persons of bad character who might undermine the values of the Australian community which they are coming to as visitors in this particular case. This certainly will enable the exclusion from Australia of persons of bad character. Once again, that can be subject to further elaboration in the committee stage. Quite clearly, if, for example, a person represents a real danger to the Australian community, is likely to engage in criminal conduct in Australia, foment discord or vilify certain segments of the Australian community, then there should be the capacity to exclude such a person.

Finally, I want to mention very briefly the Immigration (Education) Charge Bill and the Migration Act amendments dealing with the offering of English tuition to those people who come to Australia. I do not think that it has been sufficiently emphasised that the primary and paramount feature of this Bill which will make a greater impact and be accepted as a real reform as it is better understood is the entitlement which it vests in a person coming from overseas to settle in this country or who is currently here to 510 hours of tuition in the English language at the expense of their fellow Australians. This is a very considerable benefit which is now an entitlement and which the Parliament is conferring on such people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a guarantee; it's an obligation—for the first time.

—It is a guarantee for the person and an obligation on the Australian community which is being accepted on their behalf and made real by the Australian Parliament by means of the passage of this legislation. When one looks at it that way, the primary and paramount feature of this legislation is indeed a great reform.

PARA.TAB: As I am advised, the average hours of tuition undertaken in the various adult migrant education programs is some 370 hours. That is what clients receive on average at the moment. This is a considerable advance on that entitlement. Of course, it is not a maximum in the sense that the person can then avail themselves of further programs within the TAFE system or suchlike in order to top up what they receive by way of entitlement to this 510 hours of tuition.

For example, to ask and require those who come here as business migrants to pay $4,000 or so for a course to help their proficiency in English in order for them to engage in business—it is their intention when they come to Australia to engage in the commercial, trading and business life of this community and quite clearly they have a real incentive and need to acquire a proficiency in English—would not be excessive. There would be various gradations down from that which, I am advised, will be set by way of regulation. That debate will therefore come before the Senate and no doubt will be the subject of discussion at that time.

In relation to those persons currently onshore who want to enrol or re-enrol in 1993, many of them will be asked to pay $250—50c an hour—for tuition in the English language. One may say that this comment comes from a person in a privileged position so far as income is concerned, but that does not strike

SPEECH.PARA: one as an excessive amount to pay in order to acquire proficiency in English, which is so necessary for one's social and recreational interaction in the Australian community, let alone engaging in business or commercial life of any sort.

PARA.TAB: Exemptions will apply to health care card holders and registered job seekers. That would cover at least some of the concerns that have been expressed in the chamber this evening about economic hardship. Some half a million dollars has been set aside particularly to deal with the question of women's access to these programs. I think I read that in one of the briefing notes. For incoming migrants granted visas after 1 March 1993, exemptions apply to whole categories of migrants, including refugees and special humanitarian and preferential family categories. So in those particular categories too there is a recognition of an incapacity to make even the various modest payments which would otherwise be required.

The program embodied in the Immigration (Education) Charge Bill 1992 and the amendments to the Immigration (Education) Act are well worth supporting at the second reading stage. I understand that whilst the Bills themselves will not be referred to the Committee meeting tomorrow, there is an expectation that the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training will be briefed on the underlying principles and expected operation of this part of the bundle of Bills that we are discussing tonight. For that reason we will not be pursuing the committee stage of debate this evening.

In so far as these Bills deserve support in principle, I recommend them all to the Senate and I indicate that the Government will not be supporting the second reading amendment moved by Senator Teague, which basically laments the fact that we have not operated the refugee determination process in a way that commends itself to the Opposition. It is a very difficult area. We believe we have been, up until now—perhaps in a more reactive, piecemeal way—trying to deal with the situation. Tonight we are taking a more comprehensive approach and, I believe, a more defensible approach. Therefore the criticism is probably belated and in any case not fully justified. I commend the second reading of these Bills to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 33, pages 97 and 98, proposed section 166LB, line 8 (page 97) to line 19 (page 98), omit the section.
2.Clause 33, page 101, proposed section 166LK, lines 23 to 37, omit the section.

I wish to address a couple of the comments that the Minister for Justice made. It seems to me that he is putting up straw men to be better able to knock them down. To my knowledge nobody has said—and I certainly have not—that asylum seekers should have the automatic right to be regarded as refugees. All we are asking for is that a due process of law be applied to that decision making procedure.

PARA.TAB: We also acknowledge that the Government has the right and the responsibility to safeguard the integrity of our borders. Of course it has. What is at issue is how that is done and how the people who are on our shore without the requisite visas having been issued prior to their arrival are treated. All we are asking is that principles of justice be applied to them as we expect them to be applied to Australian citizens.

It seems to me an extraordinary proposition that the extent to which legal rights may be enjoyed by a person being dealt with by our legal system and by our courts should be dependent on whether this person is an Australian citizen or not, rather than by the universally accepted legal principle that all persons must be equal before the courts. It seems to me that the integrity of our courts depends on that. Indeed the level of civilisation of this community will be judged by how we handle these processes.

I should also acknowledge that Senator Cooney sought me out to rectify a mistaken impression that he had. He thought that when I asked for natural justice to be applied in this process I meant it should be applied by this chamber. I assumed until this moment that this chamber would have the deepest respect for the application of natural justice in the legal system of this nation. I must say I now have some doubt that this is so.

These amendments would have the effect of ensuring that people who wish to appeal immigration and refugee status decisions before the Federal court are not limited in the grounds of appeal that they may take; that they may use the ground that a breach of the rules of natural justice has occurred; that the decision has involved an exercise of a power that is so unreasonable that no reasonable person could have so exercised the power; that the decision was made on the basis of irrelevant considerations; and that there was an exercise of discretionary power in bad faith or bias. I believe that is all.

It is necessary for this amendment to be taken extremely seriously because it strikes at the heart of these provisions and, as I said, at the heart of how we treat our legal system and how we want our legal system to be applied—whether we want it to be applied in the service of narrow self-interest and without regard to the principles of international human rights or whether we want to stand up and be counted as a civilised nation and say that people coming before our courts are treated as equal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be resisting these amendments. I think it has to be made clear that persons are not being stripped of their various rights to have their claims exhaustively evaluated. The various steps for merits review are quite elaborate, including not only review by the Refugee Review Tribunal but also the process which allows for the presidential powers of the AAT, or the prestige of the AAT at that level, to be invoked in order to provide some general guidance to decision makers in relation to the principles that ought to be applied.

PARA.TAB: Of course, when it comes to review of decisions by the Federal court, it is not as though persons are being stripped of a right to approach that court, which would be one extreme way in which Senator Spindler's worst fears might be realised. What is done is a setting-up of a process of approaching the Federal Court which says that that court is to take into account a codified set of matters which, if they were not observed, could lead to a proper accusation that there had not been procedural fairness in the course of the decision making. It is codified and each ground is important in itself, although there could be some mutual overlap and reinforcement between various grounds. But to simply rely on the common law evolution of principles of so-called natural justice, now more commonly known as `rules of procedural fairness', does not give sufficient guidance either to the many decision makers who have to make thousands of decisions in this area every year.

The Government considers it best that the various grounds be set out in a codified way, as they are. I believe that they are comprehensive in that, in effect, the sorts of considerations that are familiar to those who deal with the rules of natural justice find an echo in many of these provisions. I believe that there is good provision for grounds of review here. I am advised that the United States Supreme Court has held that a range of immigration decisions are not subject to the full due process provisions of the Constitution. I do not think that means that we should exclude grounds of review which are important to ensuring a certain amount of fairness in these assessments. They are set out in some detail in proposed new subclause 166LB(1), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) that procedures that were required by this Act or the regulations to be observed in connection with the making of the decision were not observed;-
that is a ground for review—
(b) that the person who purported to make the decision did not have jurisdiction to make the decision;
(c) that the decision was not authorised by this Act or the regulations;
(d) that the decision was an improper exercise of the power conferred by this Act or the regulations;

(e) that the decision involved an error of law, being an error involving an incorrect interpretation of the applicable law or an incorrect application of the law to the facts as found by the person who made the decision, whether or not the error appears on the record of the decision;
(f) that the decision was induced or affected by fraud or by actual bias;
(g) that there was no evidence or other material to justify the making of the decision.

It is when we see those items listed that the further part of the clause, which indicates that it is not a ground but `a breach of the rules of natural justice', can be seen in the proper context. As I said, it provides—on the basis of the foundation of a very comprehensive system of merits review—a very fair process which is made available by the Australian community to those who seek a review of decisions made in relation to their claims to stay in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Tate to outline to the Committee why the Government is proposing to remove review rights which currently exist under the AD(JR) Act and in common law. Senator Tate has to tell the Committee why he is proposing to limit judicial review rights of essentially administrative decisions.

—I have just made the point that it is up to the Australian community to decide what grounds for judicial review will be permitted in a sense that acknowledges the fairness that is required in the processes of decision making by those within the departmental structure or in the various tribunals. That is provided for in a very comprehensive codification of the grounds that will be available to the Federal Court in reviewing judicially decisions taken lower down.

PARA.TAB: We are also very conscious, as I said, of the need to create a degree of certainty in the way in which the various grounds might operate in the minds of decision makers. For that reason, for example, the question of unreasonableness is a very difficult one. The decision, whilst it purports to deal with an unreasonableness in the process of decision making, can very easily move into the area where the Federal Court substitutes its own decision on the merits of the decision taken lower down.

For that reason, the Government has decided that that particular ground ought not be available. But the grounds that are available—I have read them out, some six or seven of them—will provide a safeguard for those who are subject to this decision making process which, as I say, will enable the Federal Court to exercise that review jurisdiction which is proper for it as a judicial body but not as a decision making body in itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no objection to the codification to the extent that it does provide a greater degree of certainty in the administration of the law. But I just want the Minister to admit that what is being proposed here by the Government is a limitation on the judicial review of administrative decisions; that is, a limitation by comparison to the entitlements of applicants under the current Migration Act.

—In the same vein, I ask the Minister: is it not true that the grounds which have been excluded are the ones which in the past have been most often successful in the overturning of administrative decisions by the Federal Court?

—I am not in a position to say whether or not that is the case. But certainly the seven grounds which I have put forward are very fundamental grounds, which would enable a Federal Court very properly to criticise any process of decision making which failed to observe those particular grounds, and a proper foundation for decision making. The balance between those grounds and some grounds which may be excluded is something which I am not in a position to advise Senator Spindler on.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Government given any consideration to the likely success of refugee status applications under the new provisions compared with the old provisions? If the Government has given any consideration to this matter, would it be good enough to bring the Committee into its confidence?

—I am advised that there is no expectation of a considerable or significant difference between what might have been the outcome under an old common law regime, if I can put it that way, as opposed to this codified regime. No figures have been compiled and, of course, the section of the whole project in either case has to be put in the context of a realisation that there has to be individual case by case assessment. I do not think any broad assessment has been done of whether 100 would have been able to get through under the old provisions and 98 or 102 under these provisions, as far as I am advised.

—That goes to a question concerning a previous part of the Bill before us in respect of a `delegated person'. Can the Minister explain to the Committee how the existing legislation will be subsumed by this legislation on the question of mandatory deportation provisions? Can the Minister explain to the Committee how the mandatory deportation provisions in this legislation compare with the mandatory deportation provisions in the Migration Act?

—As honourable senators will know, a person who makes a claim to refugee status at the moment is assessed by the Refugee Status Claim Review Committee. The change envisaged by this particular Bill is, of course, that that claim would be assessed by the Refugee Review Tribunal, and the processes and powers are set out in the Bill. That is the major difference. At the end of the day, if the claim is not successfully made out and recognised through the decision making process, the person, by law, is required to be removed from Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister to paragraph 47 of the explanatory memorandum that was provided with the Bill, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years, the increasing frequency of unauthorised boat arrivals at Australia's northern frontier, the need to protect Australia's international fishing zones from being illegally exploited, and the close scrutiny by the Federal Court directed towards relevant sections of the Principal Act, have exposed a need to provide a uniform regime for the detention of persons illegally in Australia and for the recovery of costs associated with such detention and removal.
I ask the Minister to compare that regime with the current regime, particularly as it applies to refugees.

PARA.TAB: The current regime as it applies to refugees is set out in the Migration Amendment Act 1992—the one which has been the subject of a High Court challenge. Under that legislation, there is provision for a person to be declared a `designated person'. That person, having been declared a designated person, is held in mandatory detention. What will be the difference between that regime and the regime that is proposed in this legislation? Is it expected that there will be more persons detained or fewer persons detained? In either case, why?

I think that is a reasonable question to ask and to have answered.If fewer persons will be detained under this new regime, I am sure the Committee would be obliged to know why. If more persons are likely to be held in detention, again, I believe we should be told and given the reasons for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope I have understood Senator Harradine correctly. In relation to those non-citizens who are in Australia without valid visas, this Bill provides that they will be regarded as unlawful and will have to be held in detention. However, they will be able to get bridging visas. But those who arrive at the border without any authority to enter are not entitled to that bridging visa and will be held in detention until their claims are assessed.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that that particular mandatory requirement does not necessarily mean that any more will be held in detention than in the past. But that is the regime, that is the difference, and that is the way in which it is structured to try to provide for simplicity. As Senator Harradine knows, those who are in Australia are here either lawfully or unlawfully. The great majority of unlawful non-citizens will be able to get a bridging visa, but not those who arrive in Australia without authority. So those who arrived, for example, as boat people, would be held in mandatory detention under the provisions of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that the capacity to obtain a bridging visa depended on the ability of the person to regularise his stay. I am asking the Minister whether asylum seekers, and again I use the word `refugees' deliberately, who are refugees—I use the word `refugees' in the terms that it was used in the 1951 United Nations Convention relating to the Status of Refugees; I am not saying that they will be recognised as refugees, but that they are refugees on the basis that they have a well-founded fear—are entitled to seek a bridging visa under this legislation?

—I think there may be a misunderstanding. In relation to those who arrive in Australia without any lawful authority—for example, boat people—there is no way in which they can move into the Australian community by some attempt to regularise their presence here, to use something of the language of Senator Harradine. If they arrive without lawful authority—whether at an airport, fishing village or a major port such as Darwin—they must be held in detention, and they will be detained whilst the processes which are outlined in the Bill for the assessment of their claim for refugee status are carried out. The various reviews can then take place. All that has to occur whilst they are in detention. They cannot move into the community.

—I come to the next point: the primary assessment of the application that is made by a refugee—an asylum seeker, if you like. The primary assessment is done by the Department after the application has been made.

PARA.TAB: A number of things were said in the second reading debate about which I became a little concerned, to be quite frank. I believe aspersions were unfairly cast on some organisations which have done a quite reasonable and valiant job. They were not made by the Minister, I am not suggesting that at all, or officially by the Government. I refer to the the Refugee Council of Australia and its subsidiaries. Also, there was some reflection made upon individuals who have served refugees well, and who have worked amongst the refugees. I am concerned about this. Apparently no-one can criticise the administration of this legislation without being bagged and being called a number of things, including headline seekers.

Mr Chairman, I can assure you and the Committee that in this area that is the last thing that people want to be called. There are no votes when it comes to refugees, and any politician who stands up for refugees cannot expect to be immediately understood. But sooner or later I believe that the people of Australia will understand that the test of Australia's compassion and Australia's adherence and commitment to human rights will be in how it treats the most vulnerable and the most defenceless of individuals who come to its shores or who are already here. That is why this legislation and questioning about this legislation is so important.

I do not accept—I am sure the Minister and the Committee will not mind me saying this—accusations being levelled at a person like Justice Einfeld, who apparently cannot say anything about refugees because he is a judge. Father Larry Rightmeyer, although he spent an enormous time in Port Hedland—because it was in his parish—assisting refugees and the Department, cannot say anything about refugees on the ABC because he sounds like an American. The officers of the Refugee Council of Australia cannot say anything about it because they are lawyers, despite the fact that many of them have served those persons who have come to Australia—the refugees—to the detriment of their own practices. Teachers apparently cannot say anything about refugees and the teaching of migrants because they somehow have vested interests.

We really should not have that sort of closed mind. But I am getting off the point, Mr Chairman, and I know you are going to pull me up. I come to the point about the lawyers. Is it the intention of the Government to ensure that, if further refugees arrive by boat, they will be entitled to legal assistance so as to enable them to understand their obligations and rights under international treaty and national legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that if a person makes a claim to refugee status then that person will be given access to legal advice. I presume that that will enable the person to better advance the claim and put it in a way which will be helpful to the decision maker.

—I have a couple of questions about the Refugee Review Tribunal. What has influenced the Government to abandon the RSRCs, the refugee status review committees? Those committees comprised five people—one each from DILGEA, DFAT and AG's, a community representative and an observer from UNHCR. I and the Committee would be interested to know why.

—I understand that there has been concern in the community that the committee system was only recommendatory and that it was not able to come to a determination on the matter. It has been decided that what was needed in response to the various requests was a clearly independent, determinative body which would make decisions from a certain independent status that would be clearly perceived and give confidence to those who were submitting their claims to that process. As I say, the committee system was only recommendatory and, as I understand it, the composition of the committees was such that they had a large portion of bureaucratic and departmental members, as well as a refugee council nominee. But it is a completely different merits review and determining process.

—If the Minister does not now have the following information, would he kindly provide it at some stage: how many decisions of a refugee status review committee that were favourable to the applicant were overturned by the Minister's delegate; how many of those decisions were unanimous; and how many were decided on the basis of 3 to 1 or 2 to 2? I would appreciate some information about that. The other information that I want is the number of applications for refugee status that were rejected by the RSRC with the representative of the Attorney-General's Department supporting the application.

—Several questions were raised by Senator Harradine. One concerns the reversing or overturning of decisions where there is a 2 to 2 recommendation by the committee. It may take a little while, but the Department will find the figures for that. As to how individual members of the committee voted on any particular application and therefore any cumulative list or voting pattern that might be discernible in relation to, for example, the Attorney-General's member of those committees, we do not have that sort of voting information. I understand that the committee does not keep such records. I am therefore unable to assist Senator Harradine.

—I go to the question of the new body, the Refugee Review Tribunal. Why did the Government propose that it should be a single member tribunal? Is it not a fact that New Zealand has a review tribunal which has two members?
—Order! The Chair is finding it a little difficult to hear the speaker, and that is one of the Chair's main responsibilities. I hope that those honourable senators on the left might assist me.

—Canada also has a review tribunal which has two members. The advantage of at least two persons being on the Review Tribunal is that it would enable the Tribunal to discuss the relevant merits of the particular individual case at length. It would also enable each member of that tribunal, in a frank and open way, to bounce his or her assessment of the case off a peer review within the tribunal. That is the case in Canada and in New Zealand. It is also the case in this legislation as far as the Immigration Review Tribunal is concerned. The Immigration Review Tribunal need not be a single member tribunal; it can have more than one member. It seems to be an odd situation, if that is that is the case, that it should not also be the case for the RRT.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 10 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will an investigation be conducted into the processes involved in the withdrawal of security screening services at regional airports like Rockhampton, Mackay and Mt Isa.
(2) Which airline initiated this economic decision.
(3) Was a compromise strategy considered.
(4) How many airports throughout Australia will be affected.
(5) Why is security to these regional airports of less concern.
(6) Will security be similarly withdrawn from capital cities.
(7) Will airlines be required to take out additional insurance to cover increased risk to passengers flying without adequate security screening.
(8) Has the impact of a possible serious security breach on regional airlines been calculated in terms of the reputation of the Queensland tourist industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No investigation is necessary into the withdrawal of screening arrangements at the regional airports listed.

(2) Ansett Express has already withdrawn screening at all three ports. Australian Airlink has placed the future of screening under active review at Rockhampton and Mackay. Australian Airlink has terminated service to Mt Isa for economic reasons.

(3) Any compromise strategy is a matter for negotiation between the airline and airport operators concerned. It is understood that Australian Airlines, on behalf of Australian Airlink, is currently discussing alternatives with local councils.
(4) Rockhampton, Mackay and Mt Isa are the only three airports affected at present.

(5) The Air Navigation Regulations do not require screening for domestic Regular Public Transport aircraft configured to seat fewer than 100 passengers. Both Ansett Australia and Australian Airlines have in recent years passed responsibility for these Queensland services to Ansett Express and Australian Airlink respectively, who operate Fokker F.28 and BAel46 equipment seating around 70 passengers. The former Boeing 737 equipment seating around 120 passengers had apparently proved too large for these routes.

Given that smaller aircraft have been substituted by the airlines for both economic reasons and to increase flight frequency, there is no legislative need to maintain security screening at these ports.

The background is that routine screening of domestic flights in Australia occurs when a variety of requirements have been met, including assessed level of threat and size of aircraft. The Government monitors the situation closely, and will always introduce appropriate security precautions, irrespective of the size of aircraft, where warranted by the circumstances.

It has not however been deemed practicable for the routine screening threshold to be reduced below 100 seats. This is because the expense of screening aircraft seating fewer than 100 passengers becomes such a major component of overall operating costs that fares would have to be raised to cover this expense. The result is that patronage is discouraged and the viability of the service itself may be threatened.

The Government cannot countenance a situation where provincial centres are denied commercial air links because of security requirements intended more to protect interstate trunk and international routes. While monitoring the situation closely, the Government therefore permits flexibility at provincial centres where smaller aircraft operate, thereby ensuring that these commercial services can remain viable.

(6) Security will not be withdrawn from capital city airports because of the nature and extent of traffic. The same applies to other major Queensland airports such as Cairns, Townsville and Coolangatta.
(7) The airlines will not be required to take out additional insurance on remaining Rockhampton, Mackay and Mt Isa flights.

(8) The Government maintains flexibility in the application of security measures at all airports. This is especially relevant in keeping pace with the rapidly changing requirements brought about by the dynamic nature of Queensland's tourist industry. Therefore, while screening is no longer required at some provincial airports, it is being progressively introduced elsewhere (as at Maroochydore) where larger aircraft are now catering for rapidly expanding traffic. This reflects the Government's determination that security should be applied on both a

ANSWER.PARA: cost effective and a realistic basis. There is certainly no overall downgrading of aviation security underway in Queensland, especially given the importance of the Queensland tourist industry to Australia as a whole.
